Dovetail Games do a very poor job with the trains, almost every train you buy has terrible sounds and only just about acceptable looks, you need to buy third party trains for them to be at all realistic.

Be prepared to spend a lot of money on DLC and have a lot of storage to enjoy it, if you manage to get your hands on routes you like and good third party trains then the game can be very good.

It's a train simulator where some of the most basics of operating a locomotive don't work properly. The main issue being disappearing switch gear. Sometimes the model of the switch gear is there. Other times it's invisible but will pop up if you click your mouse when the activation icon appears. Most times it just stays invisible and nearly impossible to use, if it works at all. In one of the engines there is a indication light in behind and in between to panels. You can tell it's supposed to be a 'line volt light' icon, because there is an identical one properly placed on the pan panel. Also, they're pretty nervy charging what they do, for you locomotives considering the amount of work it takes to model one, i.e very little. With errors in them yet! This is to name but two problems with the game. There are many more. Thankfully I purchased this game on sale. There is absolutely no way this is worth what they're asking at the regular price. Not at least after a lot, and I mean a lot, of bug fixes. It's getting sickening what developers are getting away with charging what they are for their "games" these days. Dear developers of Train Simulator, if you happen to read reviews and actually care what your customers think of your game; you require direction, organization and some basic business ethics, feel free to contact me. You're simulator is a joke. You need help polishing and completing this game. My consulting fees are very reasonable.

Second day with this "simulator" and I can tell everyone to just walk away. Do not purchase this so called game. There are way too many bugs and glitches. It's not fun. it's just frustrating. Purely aggravating. It's as if someone let a bunch of elementary students loose with a crap game engine. I can't believe adults had the bald faced audacity to release this drivel to the public and actually charge money for it. Even if this was a free simulator I would consider it a waste of money. I feel like Dovetail should pay me for the time I lost with this inferior software. $133.77 should just about cover my base frustration. Plus $10.00 to $50.00 for every bad emotion after frustration. Disregard my offer of consultation. I wouldn't want to tarnish my family's good name being associated with Dovetail.

Ok. This is my opinion before I play this game: "OMG OMG OMG I FINNALLY CAN DRIVE A TRAIN AND SEE HOW ALL IT WORKS!!!". This is my opinion after 8 hours of game : "I CAN'T BELIEVE I JUST SPENT MY MONEY IN THIS GAME!!! ". 

1st of all, the academy is so bad that I needed to search and learn the rules by searching on Google. 2nd, To make matters worse then I thought the game is so bad optmized. Even Euro Truck Simulator 2, with better graphics, all in high!, has a better performance. 3rd, you made a tab in the menu saying "Tutorial" but nothing was shown, so I really don't know what's the point of it. 4th, I learned very well the controlls, but why can't I increase the brakes level? I have used all the ways you teach, but no matter what train, no matter what scenario or difficulty, the breaks never increased. 5th,why doesnt the TGV speed up after I stop it?  I had always to stop the engine and start it again, and that was the only way to speed up normally again. 6th,  in one of the missions (4 or 5 counting from the  beggining) in career mode, you tell us to move the container carriages to one of the lines, but one thing? all of them? To that line? the why you tell us to move them to another line? is it supose to move all of them? which one then? why do you have so many numbers after "Marshall" ? You don't explain that?

I'm just a gamer, I shouldn't need a degree to have fun while at the same time learning the train mechanics, this game does a poor job in that departmen. And my point is, once I can refund, I wouldn't recommend the game meanwhile you don't fix this problems.

Absolutely fantastic game to have if you enjoy trains, i have only a couple concerns with this game. 1- Cost of DLC's. 2- For the price of them some are shocking detail. 3- Some trains are horrible and aren't anywhere near the real thing and unless you have enhancement packs from Armstrong Powerhouse or ATS they are sometimes unbearable. Other than all of this its a decent game. Make sure you have a lot of money if your not buying during a sale for DLC's

Overall its a fun simulator for enthusiasts, and easily moddable, with great modded DLC creators (such as SamT and Armstrong Powerhouse), but the community involved with this 1 game is somehow probably the most toxic community i've ever been involved in, and the price of DLC is quite literally the most abysmal I have EVER seen. For the price of all the DLC in this game combined, you could buy yourself a car, maybe even a few cars. (im not even joking, as of 2020, the combined price of all the DLC is around £8,100 GBP, or $10,300 USD)

I have several issues with this game.
Firstly, there is little content in the base game and the DLCs are expensive for this game. Sometimes the DLC is more expensive than the game itself.
Secondly, this game runs disappointingly poorly for the amount of money they are charging for it. I have encountered several glitches including tasks not being registered as complete on career mode, career mode levels not being scored or registered as completed, and routes with glitched speed limits.
After dropping $50 on a game and DLC, basic issues like this should be solved by Dovetail Games instead of the player having to look up fixes online and modifying the game files. Very disappointing

I find the simulation gives a realistic feel to operating a train. Principles of operation in real life are accurately reflected in the simulation.

Surprisingly addictive. There is a lot more to driving a train than most people probably realise: timing, signals, speed limits, safety. The game however has serious flaws that have remained unfixed which spoils the user experience.

Obvious flaws exist that in particular impact the Career mode. This  often makes it impossible to achieve a successful career score which is part of the challenge of the game. 

These obvious flaws have been present for literally years and this is a reflection on the attitude of developers. They display the stereotypical attitude where "technical debt" is left unaddressed whilst they concentrate their efforts on new features. The result is that the users have a negative experience with the product. Given the high price listed for DLCs this is not acceptable. 

Sadly software developers seem to be immune (at present) from trading standards rules although one hopes this will change in the future given so much of our lives depend upon IT now.

This is game has a LOT of DLC content. So here's how it works. There is no base game, you're just buying a license to use their game engine. Then you need to buy the DLCs, witch is the locomotives and routes. Everytime you buy a locomotive you need to be sure it is compatible with the routes you have (or you can buy a locomotive + the route it's intended for). Good thing is that often they sell package content, so you can buy a route with lots of locomotives for this route. If you are unsure on where to start, just search for a route that you know, a country that you want to try. Every route and locomotive comes with a manual that you NEED to read. There you will have route's history and description, and how to control the locomotives. This is a simulator so there is a learning curve that you need to go through.
This game is looking beautiful nowadays with their engine update. The models are old crap. So buildings and cars and etc will look like you are playing a 2000s game. But overall it's still beautiful when you play it (I think it's the lightning system).
One major let down. A LOT of missions are broken. When you buy a route or loco, there will certainly be a mission or two that will be broken somehow. Consequently not all achievement are gettable.

I started playing this game from around 2017 having seen many videos of it on YouTube. When Train Sim World came out, I significantly reduced my playing time of this game as the newer title made this game feel incredibly outdated. Roll on to 2023, I have started to play Train Simulator Classic again as the routes I would love to see on Train Sim World are not present, and I am a big fan of the Chatham and Medway Valley lines.

The controls of the game are supporting of an Xbox Controller as well as a mouse and keyboard, and I prefer to play with a controller in "expert" mode which I find easier than the simplistic mode. My only complaint is with the door opening. Looking down at the platform does not always work, and it makes the service I am playing late sometimes.

I am sure I will continue to play this game whilst I wait and hope for the Chatham Mainline & Medway Valley Lines to go on to Train Sim World. Would I recommend this game from 2009 in 2023? If you want more route variety, yes. In terms of graphics and controls, I think Train Sim World looks and plays a lot better.

Been playing Train Sim sporadically for years. Game has its flaws for sure, but I continue to get enjoyment out of it.
After screwing up in many different ways I learned to save often while on a scenario. 
DLC is a big part of this game, base price is too expensive, definitely wait for it to be on sale. The quality of DLC ranges from great to unusable so seek out reviews for the specific DLC you're looking at. 
The community for this game is great, lots of scenarios and routes on the community hub and a lot of good mods you can find online.
If you are looking for an accurate simulator, this is not it. Some trains do an alright job of it but a lot of them are really screwy when it comes to the first person controls, gauges, valves, etc. 
A vast majority of the time I play this game in third person using the HUD controls or the keyboard controls. If you are looking for a game to drive trains in a glorified model railroad style, and possibly make your own scenarios and routes, Train Sim Classic is good for that.

probably the best arcade style train simulator game, very worth the price. Of course, you may need some 3rd party patches if you want a more realistic experience. For example, the Armstrong Powerhouse Track Enhancement Pack is a must if you cant stand those ugly decade old Kuju tracks. You may also need to buy a lot of routes to not get bored, or maybe even make your own. For QUALITY routes, however, i suggest looking at 3rd party created routes, by developers like JT (JustTrains), TTB (TrainTeamBerlin) and so on. Also, community websites are great for repaints, route enhancements, patches, bug fixes etc etc etc. I recommend rail-sim.de. Its got a wide library of content.

Overall, great game, its finally starting to be optimized by the developers and i hope they can bring it up to the standards of the more recently released sims.

This beats other train simulators due to the variety of routes on offer as both payware and freeware. The latter through the large groups of builder enthusiasts.

Train Simulator, previously known as RailWorks, is known for its realistic depiction of train operations and routes. Here are some key aspects to consider:

Pros:

Realism: Train Simulator is praised for its attention to detail and realism. The game provides an authentic experience for train enthusiasts, offering realistic train physics, accurate controls, and detailed recreations of real-world routes and trains.

Expansive Content: The game features a vast amount of downloadable content (DLC) that includes various routes, locomotives, and scenarios. This allows players to customize their experience and explore different aspects of train operations.

Graphics: The game has improved its graphics over the years, providing detailed train models, realistic environments, and dynamic weather effects.

Community and Mods: Train Simulator has an active modding community. Players can create and share their own content, including routes and scenarios, enhancing the overall gaming experience.

Cons:

Cost: The base game itself is relatively affordable, but the cost of additional DLC can add up quickly. Some players feel that the pricing structure for additional content is on the higher side.

Learning Curve: The game's realism can be a double-edged sword. New players may find the learning curve steep, and it might take some time to fully grasp the controls and operations, especially for those not familiar with real-world train procedures.

Performance: Depending on your computer's specifications, the game may demand significant resources. Players with lower-end systems might experience performance issues or need to compromise on graphics settings.

User Interface: Some users have criticized the user interface for being somewhat clunky and not as user-friendly as they would prefer.

Conclusion:

Train Simulator is a solid choice for those who have a genuine interest in trains and want a realistic simulation experience. The game's attention to detail and the extensive library of downloadable content contribute to its appeal. However, the learning curve and cost of additional content might be drawbacks for some players. If you enjoy simulation games and have an interest in trains, Train Simulator is likely to provide an immersive and engaging experience.

The game engine is getting on a bit now, and the graphics aren't amazing, but I really enjoyed driving the trains and routes in the US, Europe and the UK that came with the version of the game that I purchased.  There's lots of costly DLC available, but you don't have to buy it all, and if you're after something in particular, just wait for a Steam sale.

Not perfect, there are now new versions with better graphics, but there is so much DLC to choose from there will be something for every train driver whether you prefer high speed, commuter, freight or shunting.  You do not have to buy it all!

This game is for people who love trains and I mean LOVE trains. If you are not into trains, this game will put you to sleep because they don't condense anything. Every route is recreated 1:1. Amtrak's Pacific Surfliner takes 3 hours to go from LA to San Diego, and it will take 3 hours in this game.

Most of the gameplay will be you trying to balance the Throttle and the Brakes to achieve that perfect speed. This game has a reputation of having the most expensive DLC on Steam and while that is true that there is a lot for a lot, you don't have to buy every single thing.

Some things I would like to see added to this game are; 
1. The Coast Starlight, because I used to take that train when I was a kid.
2. The Class J 611 Locomotive. One of the most iconic Steam Engines ever made. It's a crime that it's not on here.
3.An occasional car stuck on a track would be interesting.
4. An occasional group of foamers chasing down your train until they get stuck on a track would be fun too.
5. If you're driving a Pennsylvania Train, have Rodney Kantorski show up to flip you off.

It's good, an expensive hobby to get into but once you've established a good collection of routes, the game is really enjoyable. The great thing is it has a massive community who provide both freeware and payware, with a fair amount that exceed even DTGs standards, including AP, Just-Trains, ATS and more. I personally only really drive UK stock so I cannot speak on behalf of other regions, however I see that Europe and USA get a lot of love, and there are a good amount of Asian routes to play around with. The game itself has a very simple premise, which is to drive trains. DTG seem to reuse a lot of stock, which does make sense as why do you need to recreate a train that exists? However there are some older stock from the Kuju days that really need to be brought up to date, such as the HST and Class 165/166.

I personally really enjoy making my own routes for my enjoyment as opposed to driving all the time, and that's what I love about TSC. It gives you the creative freedom to do whatever you want. You can make good scenarios for routes you play, and base them off real or fictional timetables. You can also create real or fictional routes. If you want to  you can even make your own train and assets, however I cant do that, it's too complex for me lol.

There are quite a few things which are made to a questionable standard, such as the 700 which was released not too long ago, but payware developers like Armstrong Powerhouse provide good EPs, which not only greatly improve the sounds and physics, but can also improve the visual appearance by improving textures. If you aren't happy with APs 700, Semaphore Sims have provided a freeware pack to further enhance the trains. All in all a good game once you build up your collection.

[u]First and foremost:[/u]
I highly recommend it to every railway enthusiast on the planet.
There is a myriad of routes and trains from all over the world available for it on steam, at third party developers' shops and also to some extent freeware portals.

[u]Now a little foreword before I continue:[/u]
I've been a tremendous fan of Microsoft Train Simulator back in my teenage years and even created a little bit of content fot it; the whole file structure was easy and accessible enough to figure out.
I've also been a big fan of Auran's, now N3V Games', TRAINZ franchise ever since TRS 2004.
I got my first copy of, then branded as Railworks, Train Simulator back in 2009, when my machine couldn't really handle it.
Gave it another go on my next machine a few years ago and it didn't run to my expectations.
Now oddly enough, on my current and actually graphically less powerful laptop (!) it does finally and suprisingly run well and I've been stocking up on all the add-ons I've missed out on in the last decade.

I am satisfied with TS [u]now[/u].

In the past I was a student, so I didn't have much money, barely enough to get by. So add-ons for TS were mostly not affordable and therefore I wasn't really getting my needs satisfied on just a few standard routes I never even knew in real life.

Train Simulator [b]is[/b] a fun pastime [b]if[/b], and that's a [b]big if[/b], you can afford rather pricey payware on a regular basis.
If you're a student, an apprentice, stuck in a low paying job and don't have the knowledge, skill nor the programs to create your own content, you're far better of with TRAINZ.

Contrary to TS, TRAINZ has a built-in download station with over 600,000 assets on it for free (if you don't mind really slow download speed without a pricey subscription) plus a wide array of freeware assets on thrid party community platforms from around the globe. Its filing system is as understandable as the old MSTS one, modding content is easy as fishin' so to speak.

Yet TS provides you, at least if you're looking for german content, the realism of at least 3 different safety features in the cab. Granted, there was a custom TRAINZ version by a german publisher that featured these as well. That was nearly 15 years ago though, there won't be any new content for it by the publisher ever and they stopped producing ten years ago.

When it comes to content creation using the game itself, for routes, consists, scenarios, TRAINZ provides a much more intuitive and fast route building tool in my opinion.

So having played both big franchises for decades now my final recommendation is:

Got cash and in your spare-time want to pretend your second job is train driver:
[h1]Get Train Simulator.[/h1]

Short on cash, don't wanna pretend your second job is train driver and just want to create layouts, see the world, tinker with content or don't have the space and money for a model railway layout:
[h1]Get TRAINZ.[/h1]

The first thing you will notice when you run this game is the outdated graphics. The trains look plasticky and the environments are bland and lifeless. The game also suffers from poor optimization, and even high-end computers can struggle to run it at a smooth framerate.

The gameplay is also quite shallow. There are a few different scenarios to play through, but they are all very repetitive. You will spend most of your time driving trains from one point to another, and there is very little to do in between.

The biggest problem with with this is the sheer amount of DLC that is required to get the most out of the game. There are hundreds of DLC packs available, and each one costs around $10, you will need to spend a lot of money.

Overall, Train Simulator Classic is a disappointing train simulator game. It is outdated, buggy, and shallow. The only reason to buy this game is if you are a die-hard train fan and you are willing to overlook its many flaws.

But those are my only gripes with the game, yeah sure I could say "Ohh it doesnt have this or that train and makes me feel sad" but that isnt really an issue for me. Yeah sure there are trains that I wish were in the game but aren't (yet) but that doesn't ruin it for me.

Would I recommend the game? Well this is a hard one for me because I love trains but for a beginner i'm not sure. It is quite expensive to get new Add-Ons and since I don't have any other train games (besides TSW 2 that I got for free on Epic Games) I don't have a comparison. So If you have the money and are really into trains I would say YES get it. If you are tight on money and want a beginner train game... do your own research since I have no basis.

Train Simulator, released in 2009, remains a captivating and immersive railway simulation game that has stood the test of time. The vast array of downloadable content (DLC), particularly from third-party developers like Armstrong Powerhouse or Just Trains, enhances the depth and realism of the game. The strong community and abundance of user-generated content on websites like ATS and the Steam Workshop offer endless variety and enrich the gameplay experience. The ability to create custom routes and scenarios adds a creative aspect, while the extensive customisation options allow for personalisation. Although the graphics may not be cutting-edge, they still provide an immersive experience. Train Simulator is a timeless game that offers limitless possibilities for railway enthusiasts and is a must-play for fans of railway simulations.

This game is what happens when you give an EA-like company a simulator. When I first started playing, the game ran like a early 2000's dell work computer. I pushed past this and got into the gameplay, and may i say.
THIS GAME IS BORING AS HELL

The only way you can find some sense of enjoyment out of this game is emptying your bank account and buying the $8.5k in DLC.
The last time i've seen a price for a game like that was the Nintendo world championships 1990 cart.

And dont even get me started on the fucking graphics. If I wanted to play a game with graphics this bad, i'd pull out my damn atari 2600. And even that thing runs better than this god forsaken game.

While yes, this game is for the simulator fanatics out there, I found this game to just be a quick cashgrab in an overpriced shell.

In conclusion, this game is nothing but a crappy shell of a game with with EA levels of DLC ontop of it.

Edit: I just wanted to add a bit more context. A lot of the trains purchasable through DLC have buttons that are just for show but serve a purpose in the actual train. This is just lazy. I've played sim games such as Assetto corsa where modders charge $3 for an F1 car with absolutely incredible amounts of detail and physics. This game's DLC on the other hand charges almost triple for sub par quality.

Good heavens this game is immersive.

Though the game's graphics are a bit dated and the dlcs end up draining your bank account, the imersivness at times make me hallucinate the smell of a steam locomotive, coach interior, or other environments. The only thing holding you to reality is the real life surroundings outside your monitor. this game is an absolute BLESSING FROM ABOVE to those who have interest in trains, especially of they're American, British, German, Austrian, or Swiss. This game has such a degree of activeness that it's entered the podium of my most played games, and I never can get enough of this blessing.

Train Simulator, developed by Dovetail Games, is a game that has been around for quite some time. Unfortunately, despite being one of the only games in its niche, it is plagued by a number of issues that make it difficult to recommend.

The first and most obvious issue with Train Simulator is its outdated graphics. While the game does offer a wide range of routes and trains to choose from, the visuals are often muddy and unattractive. The textures are low-resolution, the lighting is dull, and the environment lacks any real sense of life or vitality. This makes it difficult to fully immerse yourself in the game and detracts from the overall experience. Another issue with Train Simulator is its lack of gameplay variety. While the game does offer a large number of routes and trains to choose from, the actual gameplay itself can be quite repetitive. Essentially, you're just driving a train from one station to another, with little in the way of obstacles or challenges to overcome. This can make the game feel quite dull and uninspired, especially after extended play sessions.

One of the biggest problems with Train Simulator, however, is its pricing model. The game itself is relatively cheap, but in order to fully experience everything it has to offer, you'll need to invest in a large number of pricey DLC packs. This can quickly add up to a substantial amount of money, and it feels like a blatant cash grab on the part of the developers.

In addition to these issues, the game is also prone to bugs and glitches, and the AI can be quite frustrating to deal with at times. Overall, while Train Simulator may have some appeal for fans of the genre, it's difficult to recommend due to its outdated graphics, lack of gameplay variety, and aggressive DLC pricing model. There are certainly better options available for those looking for a train simulation experience.

Train Simulator is a game that has captivated train enthusiasts and hobbyists around the world. As a trainspotter and train hobbyist myself, I can confidently say that this game is one of the most realistic and immersive train simulators available today.

The attention to detail in Train Simulator is truly impressive. From the authentic sound effects to the meticulously rendered locomotives and routes, the game is a true homage to the world of trains. As someone who has spent countless hours observing and studying trains, I can say that the level of accuracy in Train Simulator is unmatched.

The game features a wide variety of locomotives, from historic steam engines to modern high-speed trains. Each one is faithfully recreated and offers a unique driving experience. The controls are intuitive and responsive, allowing you to truly feel like you're in the driver's seat.

But what really sets Train Simulator apart is the routes. From the bustling streets of London to the scenic countryside of Germany, the game features a diverse selection of routes to explore. Each one is rich in detail and offers a unique perspective on the world of trains. As someone who loves to travel by train, I appreciate the attention to detail that has gone into creating these routes.

But Train Simulator isn't just about driving trains. The game also offers a range of scenarios and challenges that will test your skills as a train driver. From navigating through tricky terrain to dealing with unexpected obstacles, each scenario offers a new and exciting challenge to overcome.

And let's not forget about the community. Train Simulator has a dedicated following of players who are passionate about trains and train simulation. The game's modding community is also incredibly active, with new mods and add-ons being created all the time. This community adds a new level of depth and immersion to the game, allowing players to customize their experience to their liking.

In conclusion, Train Simulator is a game that is sure to delight any train enthusiast or hobbyist. Its attention to detail, diverse selection of locomotives and routes, and challenging scenarios make it a truly immersive experience. As someone who loves trains and train simulation, I can wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who shares my passion.

Train Sim World 2, then 3 have led me to discover the bigger more interesting and engaging routes of Train Sim Classic, also we have player mod support for classic to fix the enfless buga haha.
Seriously, TSW 2 and 3 are good, but have issues with new DLCs until patched., I do like 3, I don't play 2 anymore because 3 is better. As for classic, it is the length, challenge, and depth to the routes, and scenarios means I like spending more time in classic now.  By the time you grab some of the outstanding community content, RW enhancer pro, TS tools plus a real long visit to Armstrong  powerhouse https://www.armstrongpowerhouse.com/  and Alan Thompson https://alanthomsonsim.com/ , and https://www.trainsimcommunity.com/ plus a huge amount of others, and of course Steam workshop, you'll find an amazing amount of content, stuff that really makes Classic Train sim stand out.  Watch for those sales and grab some interesting routes, TS Classic is like iRacing, you don't need to buy everything- just what you want to play, and over a longer period of time. With this in mind I love that classic has so much content, I just bagged the Japanese routes, fantastic I love them. It will be interesting to see the changes in Train Simulator now that Focus owns Dovetail.  I recommend Train Simulator classic, collect stuff over time, tinker with it to get the best from it, accept that the trade off for so much content, and so much free content, the variety, length and depth of scenarios, will be a few bugs, a few crashes, ( I use large address aware and 4gb patch for ALL older games so its much better.) chill out with a beer after work and have some fun. Much preferred in my opinion than watching some of the crap on TV. Whatever you choose to play, go and enjoy it. :)

Train Simulator by Dovetail Games has garnered mixed reviews, with both positives and negatives to consider.

On the downside, some players have noted that the game engine is outdated, as the game was originally released in 2009. This can make the game look and feel like an older title, which may not be to everyone's liking. Additionally, the basic version of the game only offers three routes, which some may find disappointing. And for those who purchased the LIRR trains add-on, they may feel disappointed to find that there are no corresponding LIRR routes to use them on.

However, on the positive side, Train Simulator is a great game for train enthusiasts. It offers a vast array of trains, routes, and scenarios to explore, and players can easily spend hundreds of hours enjoying the game. Some players have reported spending over 250 hours on the game and loving every moment of it. Others have found themselves unexpectedly addicted to the game after trying it on a whim.

Moreover, while Train Simulator may not be as realistic as other train sims like TSW, it still offers an entertaining and enjoyable simulation of the real world. Players can customize the controls to their liking, and the game can be played with or without DLC. Additionally, some players have noted that the game provides a safe way to experience the thrill of rail fanning, without the danger of being out on the tracks.

Overall, while Train Simulator may have its shortcomings, it remains a great game for train enthusiasts who are looking for an immersive and enjoyable experience.

It's hit or miss whether the braking controls are actually playable in this "simulation". Wonderful driving experience when the locomotive actually performs properly and you can complete the scenario without penalties that are literally out of your control.
If someone told me that quality control tests are performed on each scenario, I'd laugh in their face until they broke down crying, and superglue their eyelids wide open while showing them a UP Big Boy that can apparently propel itself like a jet with brakes still applied and throttle at 0%, a BNSF train with brakes that either fade away instead of maintaining pressure or just lock up and cause horrible drive quality, a Norfolk Southern train that doesn't brake at all, and as a bonus how about a UP FEF that just loses steam before even getting out of the yard.
Why did I buy this again? Why did I buy so much DLC for this? Why did I bother trying this instead of staying loyal to Trainz? These are questions I'm not even sure I WANT the answer to, because I'm only going to get even more infuriated and embarrassed.

Oh great, now I have a UP train that decides to register as an "Invalid Consist" 2/3rds of the way into my trip and deducts 500 points off of my score? Thanks for changing your dumb mind!

OOO!!! Now I have a GTEL that's expected to spool up to operational RPM in under 10 seconds to keep to the timetable, and along the way let's pretend our brake pads are sponges with downhill speed limits that drop from 70mph to 30mph, and let's have an unposted 20mph limit too... G A R B A G E

I could write a long, rambling essay but I think that'd be pointless. Let's be concise.

Positives:

1) Base simulation engine is solid and smooth under most conditions.
2) Allows great scope for varied scenarios.
3) Some excellent DLC.

Negatives:

1) Scenario editor returns nonsense errors (e.g.: Line blocked by train which has been deleted; "Unknown error").
2) Unclear or absent instructions.
3) Defective pathfinding AI.
4) Defective dispatching AI.
5) Defective base physics modelling for wheelslip, steam production/consumption rates, injector operation.
6) Low-detail graphics for background features.
7) Frequent signalling bugs (e.g. signals displaying permanent Danger aspect when line ahead clear).
8) Frequent collisions due to defective pathfinding AI.
9) Frequent scenario initialisation errors due to defective dispatching AI.
10) Numerous startup crashes with unusuable .dmp file output (han't found a .dmp reader that actually reads these things so far) (since v59.2a, may be corrected).
11) Accurately-modelled vehicles etc. only available by DLC.
12) Defective modelling of structures (e.g. rain passing through solid roofs).
13) Unindicated pathing restrictions (i.e. unidirectional line not marked as such; passenger/freight-only line not marked as such).

In summary: A basically decent game that has been released in a state best described as half-finished, and which you will have to fight tooth and nail to make work properly. When it does work properly, particularly when using some of the more advanced DLC, it's excellent. Much of the time, however, it's a shoddy, bug-ridden excuse for a game which milks its customers by ensuring the content they actually want is only available via DLC, bugs be damned.

Edit: After yet more play I've decided it's ridiculous not to recommend the game, warts and all. It's a mess, but it's still a basically enjoyable mess, and when it does work, it works well. Just don't go mad on the DLC.

Oh my buffers! I have just played a game called Train Simulator, and I must say, I am feeling quite perplexed! At first, I was chuffed to bits to have the chance to take control of my own train and chug along the tracks, just like I do in the real world. But then, things started to get a bit confusing. There were so many different types of trains to choose from, and I couldn't quite figure out which one was the best fit for me. Should I go for a diesel locomotive, or stick with my trusty steam engine? And what about the electric trains? They seem so modern and fast, but do they have the same charm as my good old whistle and smoke? And then there were the routes! Oh my coal car, there were so many routes to choose from, I didn't know where to start. Should I stay in my familiar UK routes or explore the tracks of faraway lands? And what about the different time periods? Should I stick with the present day or take a journey back in time to the golden age of steam? And don't even get me started on the controls! There were so many buttons to press and levers to pull, I felt like I was trying to crack the Enigma code. I just couldn't figure out how to make my train go faster or slower, or even how to stop it properly without crashing into the buffers. I must say, Train Simulator has left me feeling quite bewildered. While I enjoyed the chance to play with trains, I just couldn't wrap my funnel around all the options and controls. But perhaps with a bit more practice and some help from my fellow engines, I can get the hang of it and become a true master of the rails!

It's an addiction that through sheer lack of quality has forced me to spend countless amounts on enhancement packs and 3rd party add-ons. The game itself is basically the same as it was on release in what I can only assume was mid 1880, the frame rate remains a stable 15fps. The redeeming factor is that as it is so old, there are a plethora of different routes (of differing quality), and it feels ironically more immersive to me than TSW3, and the limited routes and rolling stock over there. 
Train simulator sees your RTX3080, 11th gen i7 and 32gb ram, and chuckles. it does not care how good your PC is, it WILL run like trash, and you will like it. 

Overall, alright as long as you're willing to throw money at all 3rd party developers, (looking at you Armstrong and the madmen who dedicate time to creating add-ons for a virtual train game) its okay. otherwise, please just get train sim world, it actually has a graphics engine.

Really good train game, would recommend. The way I would describe this is like a life size train set, allowing you to assemble your own train and cars and drive around either on set paths (quick drive) or free roam scenarios. The biggest asset this game has if you ask me is the tremendous amount of DLC available, I've only dipped my toes in so far but it gives you so much variety in what to drive and where. 

Full disclosure I'm not a train driver or even a train enthusiast so I have no idea how 'real' the physics actually are, but coming from someone with no prior experience they definitely feel real enough. Trains feel and sound powerful in a very satisfying way, but also have a tremendous amount of inertia as I imagine real trains would. That's the real challenge, managing energy. 

The graphics are of course sub-par for 2023... let's be real they would be sub-par for 2013, but it has a good 'visual' if that makes sense. Also this game has been a bit idiosyncratic at times, but I haven't seen anything majorly broken. I would definitely suggest checking out the community hub, there's a lot of useful guides and help there. 

The game Runs fine on my machine, which is an I5 6600 and GTX 1070. I will point out I have not run into any of the massive stuttering issues I've seen people complain about. The one big technical issue I do have is that I can not alt+tab at all, the game crashes if I try to switch windows. Somewhat major issue but the only major one I've had so far.

In summary, if you're willing to put up with an old looking, slightly clunky experience in exchange for great freedom and a massive collection of add-on content, the game is definitely worth it, even at regular price. I will point out though, as with any Dovetail property, sales are common and generous so you can get an even better deal if you wait and keep an eye on it.

DOWNSIDES: The graphics look pretty outdated. Lots of DLC's for this game are pretty expensive but their price is better during sales. Some DLC's can rather be a disappointment as some have bland assets, trains with bland default horns, and quite buggy.
Brilliant game well worth the money !!!!

As a big fan of train simulators I've played quite a lot. I liked this game at first and actually played it quite a bit but the more I got to know about the game and its interface the more I started to hate it.
Driving the train is fine, but everything else I dislike.
I hate that I have so few choices of what trains to drive or what routes to use without buying a lot of DLC, I hate that I can't get community routes to even show up 90% of the time. I hate that I get no credit for having completed a career mission because at one point in an hour long play-through I went 51 in a 50 for 2 seconds. 
I keep trying to find a way to like this game again, to get back to that initial feeling when I first installed it but its just not happening and I find myself just looking at that shortcut on my desktop and getting mad at it.
The most important thing: When you put out a fragment of a game, what is essentially a playable demo, and expect your customers to continually pay for DLC in order to get the whole experience then A) I'm not doing that and I'll just uninstall your game, and B) I won't be buying anything else from you either because I just generally don't like how you operate as a business.

I'm not impressed. The gameplay is standard for a simulation game, but the amount of DLC you have to purchase to get the full experience is ridiculous. It feels like you're constantly being nickel-and-dimed by the developer.

One of the things that really annoyed me about Train Simulator is the fact that so much of the content is locked behind paywalls. It's frustrating to see all of these cool trains and scenarios that you can't access without shelling out more money.

The graphics are also a bit underwhelming. While they're not bad, they're not particularly impressive either. It's a bit disappointing given the high-stakes nature of simulation games.

Overall, I can't recommend Train Simulator. The constant need to purchase DLC and the underwhelming graphics make it a sub-par experience. There are probably better simulation games out there.

If you love driving real trains like me, then this is the game for you. The variety of different DLCs that can be seperately purchased for the game only add on to your driving experience. Countries like: Britain, France, USA, China, Japan, Germany, Switzerland etc... , offer a variety of different challenges and driving experiences. And separate companies like: Armstrong Powerhouse, Bossman Games and many others offer very detailed and entertaining trains to drive to further enhance the immersion. Furthermore, companies like Just Trains offer a wide selection of not only trains but also routes to drive on such as the Western Mainlines (London Paddington to Oxford, Bristol Temple Meads and Cardiff Central). This route can also be extended further southwest by the addition of Extension Routes (South Devon Mainline: Exeter St Davids - Plymouth, Paignton Extension: Exeter St Davids - Paignton and Cornish Mainline: Plymouth - Penzance) .

I love this game, I honestly do. I love it so much that the sheer level of content I have for it appears to have bricked it. So I'm writing this review as an appeal to DTG; PLEASE FIX YOUR BROKEN GAME! I accepted running the game on 64-bit. I even upgraded my PC hardware to help compensate. That got me back the consist editor for a short while. But eventually, the game will get to a point where it will fail if you have too much content installed no matter what you do. Not long after losing the consist editor again(crash to desktop, out of memory) and trying to pare back some of the content I had installed to make up for it, the game started crashing as soon as I tried to load anything up. With this game being targeted at enthusiasts the way it is, it disappoints me immensely that people who spend years acquiring content will eventually suffer the fate I have. The issues regarding out-of-memory crashes have been known for a very long time now and DTG has dutifully ignored them, instead pursuing the visually stunning but less interesting Train Sim World. With Train Simulator officially being marked as "Train Simulator Classic" they really ought to take the time to iron some of the long standing bugs out of the engine. The amount of money I've thrown at this game is frankly embarrassing considering the result I've gotten to. Please, Dovetail, fix these memory issues.

I'm a die hard rail fan, so a lot of people will think I'm just going to praise it and not mention any cons, but in the interest of fairness I will list the Pros and Cons: 

Pros: 
It has a wide selection of routes from different countries. 
It has community created routes, locos, rolling stock and scenarios (missions) that are beautiful to look at, listen to and drive. 
There's third party content from people like Victory Works, Digital Traction, Caledonia Works and Smokebox that are brilliant. 

Cons: 
Some of the DLC's are Overpriced, siting at around £11-£24. 
The third party content can be hard to download if you don't what to do. 
Some parts of the game can feel unrealistic a times. 

Final Thoughts: 
If you're looking for a completely accurate simulation of the railways I'd say look else where, but if you want a railway simulator that doesn't try to completely replicate the railways, but still give you a good idea of what it's like, then you're in the right place.

Yes, it runs like ass, no, the graphics won't blow you away.... however it can be modded within an inch of its life and can look and sound fantastic.

Basically, it's a DX9 title and as such is designed for hardware of that era, dual and single core CPUs. You could be running a threadripper or Intel 1000th gen and it will still run like crap. This is a very old game engine so unless the devs decide to upgrade it and risk breaking every addon ever made (literally thousands, highly doubtful), it's just something you have to accept. Hmm, this gives me an idea.... I may build a 2009 era gaming rig just for this and see how I do.

As for the sim itself, you can drive many different trains on many different routes. You can add new trains, new routes, you can even make your own route or scenario, adding in AI trains on schedules. For anyone new to the game, go to Armstrong Powerhouse website and watch some of the videos of upgraded sound packs and other mods for trains. Beats TSW on every level (apart from graphics), mostly due to its moddable nature.

I am afraid my feelings are mixed about this game. First of all, let's start off with the positives.

What I like about the game is that it is pretty chilled out and relaxing. You get to actually drive the trains which is awesome and you get to actually use the controls inside the trains which makes operating the train an interactive experience. I also enjoyed doing some of the scenarios where you pick passengers up and take them from A to B and freight cargoes from A to B as well. I also like that you have to keep an eye on the fuel and you get to use fuel stations to replenish the fuel of the locomotive you are driving.

Now for the negatives

I am afraid I have more to say about the negatives than the positives. For a start, you don't get many official scenarios unless you are willing to use mods or buy DLC. In short, you will not get so much when you only buy the base game. You have to pay a lot of money if you want to enjoy this game to the fullest. I understand that the devs need to make money, but they could have added a lot more to the base game instead of having to pay large amounts of money for DLC. It's a disappointment to be honest with you. This ends my complaint about the paywall.

Another issue is the game keeps crashing and saying that I need to lower the graphics settings, and I did so but it still crashes. I also played the 32 bit edition and it still crashes.

On the academy, there are 2 tabs: Academy and Tutorial. While there are missions in the Academy, there is absolutely nothing in the Tutorial. I find this somewhat unhelpful and silly. If the tutorial is in the Academy tab, then get rid of the tutorial tab or add things to it.

While Free drive is nice and relaxing,  you don't achieve anything for them. This is ok if you don't mind that and you just want to enjoy a relaxing drive of your favourite locomotive and you don't have to worry about points and score, but it would be nice to gain something from the experience.

This is a game that has potential to age well but isn't because of the lack of effort being put in by the main developers. A lack of understand for the game engine and care for the community has really disintegrated the quality of life for this game. Despite this game still holds up as a good representation as a simulator with a LOT of community contribution 15 years after its first edition.

DLC is often released then forgotten about, Dovetail Games do not seem to care about the majority of their products but more the profit they can make. The Class 700 is the worst example of DLC I have ever seen.

Its Okay. Not Woaw, just Okay. If you expect highly accurate controls and physics as a "Simulator" type, you may get disappointed a bit, but if you not the SIM Perfectionist type, then, well as I said, It's OK.
Pros/Cons:
- Fairly high graphic details of the machines / Not so much of the scenery due to the fact that it is still on an old graphic engine technology
- Large amounts of third party content / But they often require purchase of additional DLCs to use them
- Lots of available DLCs / If money is no factor... I saw somewhere that you can easily spend over $10k if you were to buy them all. Also, you cannot run just any train on any routes, so often enough you will be required to by 2 separate DLCs in order to play the scenarios. One for the scenery and one for the locomotives
- Have decent amounts of controls, buttons and levers to interact with / No support for custom controllers aside X-Box type, meaning if you have "joystick" types, none of the control levers can be mapped to axis functions. Also, no key mapping available.
- Decent variety of scenarios (although all very similar in actions) / Lots of mismatch consistencies, especially with the signals and what the scenario expects. Example of that which was the most frustrating to me is when the scenario dictates a certain speed but the track signals tells you something different. Meaning, do not get surprise to be penalized for over speeding due to a reduction of max speed in your current zone, although no signs were telling you this on the track. Or, the track shows an increase to 80, but your scenario keep you stuck at 50.
- The routes (game scenario) are fairly long / The needed interaction is pretty monotonous (accelerate/decelerate, accelerate/decelerate, accelerate/decelerate and maybe a stop or two, and repeat, repeat, repeat).

Was it worth my $34.99 for the USA Delux edition? Yes, but I will not buy any more of the DLCs due to the Con factors above.
In closing, I did see various negative comments when it come to LOW FPS display and the game freezing, which I did experience myself, but it was only temporarily and not often. For me, a full power down of the PC typically fixed it when it happened.

I advise you to stay away from this game. Nothing good has came out dovetail since 2010. 
>Overpriced DLC's 
>Awful optimise 
>DLC's from 2012 being revamped into a 2022 pack for >  exactly £29.99 
>Game refuses to use the brain to acknowledge that the game has loaded
>Awful compatibility 

What do I mean for 'Awful-Compatibility' 
You have to buy all of the DLC's, Install all the third parties assets and Install a bucket load of 2012 files just to play one scenario that only last... 4 hours which is split into 5 different scenario and if you don't have the all of the 'requirements' installed. The gameplay will give you a box saying 'What's missing' and gives you a 'clear indication' on what you need. 

I say I would rather jump off a building then sitting down to at least spend more than 2 seconds on this game. However if you are sad, lonely and obsessed with trains. Good news, this is your game that ticks every box on your whatever board or list. If you think the word 'classic' often means 'hopelessly outdated' you are probably right but here is my story.

I bought Train Simulator Classic after using Train Sim World 2 for 1.5 years and I somewhat like it. The Interface is ancient but surprisingly easy to use. The maps are bigger than what you get in TSW looking better detailed and busy with working excavators etc. and if it is a parking lot it has a hundred of cars, no less. The graphics wasn't too advanced even in 2010 when the first TS was released but detail level is actually very good as the game uses basically the same models as TSW (at later routes at least) with only difference being the renderer itself. Of course it is prehistoric and struggles to keep FPS over 30 due to its one-threaded nature and legendary lack of optimisation but somehow delivers quite a nice picture (you just have to increase contrast, sun light and add a bit of ambient occlusion - they put all the necessary options in this final version). The good consequence is TSC's so light on your system you can basically keep it as a background process, such a contrast with resource-hungry TSW. 

Of course there are bugs (12 year old ones) but not much as most of major ones were corrected. Of course it's the same old cash grab but you don't have to buy all the DLCs, get a few ones on sale or get a bundle (UK or Germany are good).

The only real drawback of all the TS series is there's no playable timetable services and there're no passenger rides. More missions can be downloaded from the workshop just within the game but free roam isn't available at all, sorry.

So what's the verdict? If you are bored with all this modern power-hungry 3D technology then try the good old 'Classic', you may like it. Among the latest games promoting bright, high contrast agressive picture it looks way more natural and offers a variety of vast routes, a lot of different trains and scenarios for any taste from 15 minutes to several hours long.

P.S. Steam installs 32-bit version by default but I recommend you to launch 64-bit from the game folder. it is somewhat quicker probably because it can use more memory (and can handle more AI trains for the same reason). And add -FPSLimit=61 -fastload as launch parameters.

Update - 9-17-22: Tried installing and launching - got as far as the options menu. Changing graphics settings gives a crash with an 'out of memory' warning. Abandonware it seems, same problem not addressed since 2019 at least.

Updating my review on October 5th, 2019. Nothing significant has changed, especially the technical problems and game crashes. The game has frequent crashes, and eventually stops opening altogether with the message "out of memory". This crash has existed nearly since the game was released. This crash, and several others like it, have continually plagued this game. When it works, it can be a lot of fun, but unfortunately Dovetail Games doesn't seem to have been able to keep this game stable and/or functional.

[h1]PROS:[/h1]

- Convincing simulation: In cab controls (lots of dials/switches/buttons), conducting each train feels different and unique enough to be a new experience
- Built-in scenario/map creator
- Difficulty scalable from practical free roam to very strict failure
- Trains are modeled nicely, pretty to look at
- Variety of camera controls
- Tutorials (can even learn a lot about how trains function IRL)
- Tons of DLC to add variety (this is a PRO assuming that money is not an obstacle)

[h1]CONS:[/h1]

- Base game feels bare and stripped of content, DLC almost required to keep interest
- Sound is unpolished/unfinished: trains virtually silent, very little ambient/cabin sound (no immersion via audio at all)
- Graphics specifically pertaining to scenery are awful (trains look great, but you're going to spend hours staring at fugly low quality scenery)
- Performance: even on a high end machine, you can count on regular FPS drops and chattering of all sorts
- Game play (almost by nature) is very repetitive, with long periods of do-nothing.  After ~20 hours, I'm done with it.
- Technical difficulty galore... occasionally patches will break the game and leave it unplayable for months on end.
- Very little to no developer/community relationship and communication

[h1]GOOD BUY?[/h1]

I regret buying this game even at the sale price at the time.  If you absolutely love trains, I would still wait for a deep deep sale.

[h1]RECOMMENDATION SUMMARY[/h1]

I can't recommend because the cons outweigh the pros by a fairly large margin.  The core of the game is great fun, but where the idea is nice, the execution and details completely fall through.  Adding salt to the wound:  terrible community relations, technical support (most of my emails/tweets/communication went completely unanswered - still have pending support request unresolved from a half year ago).  Even though the game has its fun moments, it's fraught with holes, and is not good value.

Ah yes, the meth to my crippling addiction to the Thomas The Tank Engine Classic series that has gone on since I was 2. This is probably the best and worse steam train simulator out there for a multitude of reasons.
The Pros: 
- Steam train controls are as comprehensive as they can get, from the simple reverser, combination brake and regulator to the  injector valves, vacuum ejectors to the damn cutoff levers for boiler water level.
- The train physics are quite realistic from what I can comprehend.
- The maps are quite large and open so you can just hop into a Black 5 and drive around the Riveria line in a Freeroam session.
- This game despite being 8 years old still has an open modding community that specialises in making models for trains and scenarios of which are to very high detail (hell you can even get the Billinton E2s somehow).
Unfortunately, thats where all the positives end. The negatives are:
- Money hungry developers. They have essentially thrown this game under the bus and buying every DLC for this game is enough money to afford a 2012 Toyota Kluger. To include as well, they recently released a Train Sim World 3, when the 2nd game was remotely even complete. Kinda sets the tone of these devs.
- Very very very very very poor optimisation. The game just does not like high frame rates and that is somewhat of a big deal breaker for me. Enough to play the 2nd game even if it only has 2 steam locos available for driving.
- A lack of detail and inconsistency. This game has gems of locomotives, such as the GWR 57XX Panniers or the LMS Black 5s but some locomotives just don't give as much control as you would like. Some trains lack realistic water feeding into the boiler as you literally just click a button and water is just fed with minimal consequences. In something like an LMS Black 5, you have to prepare the train for water feeding by adjusting the injector and tender feeding valves inorder to get an efficient flow of water into the boiler. Whilst doing that, boiler pressure goes down so planning beforehand is essential. This makes the game challenging but without it, it just becomes boring (like diesel and electric locomotives). This problem persists as DoveTail games contract or outright buy DLCs from other developers which leads to this inconsistency in detail. Another fact is the maps. I wish they looked better and I wish they got a refresh but apparently they won't. Old textures, very weird looking water, etc.
Honestly, the only reason I will recommend this is because it has detail in the real gems of steam locomotion and one of the only decent interpretation of that fact into a playable and fun game. If you do not want to spend that much money for some DLCs, look else where because you may be disappointed.

So, given I originally reviewed this game with around 600 hours playtime - I think it's time to update it.

Overall, as a railway enthusiast, the game is very good. There's a wide variety of available routes and stock from several countries for players to enjoy, with a range of focus points - Shunting, commuter, high speed and freight - there is something for everyone. I racked up over 1000 hours playtime just playing on a really poor laptop with absolute minimum graphics and framerates no higher than 15 - I now have a decent PC, managing high graphics settings and averaging between 30-60fps. It is much more enjoyable.

What are the negatives? 

Firstly, the game can crash quite often, which is frustrating - however I haven't experienced this for quite a while, but it is still a possibility.

Secondly, the price of the DLC compared to the quality of the product. Quite often products are not consistent - Some older add-ons include features which perhaps some newer add-ons don't include. Enhancement packs are available from third party developers for purchase which enhance the simulation and user experience - this further adds to the cost for content as some add-ons are simply of such poor quality that for some are considered unplayable without the enhancements.

That being said, all in all, it is a good simulator - having played since 2012 and watching how far things have moved onwards since then. 

Definitely recommend to any other railway enthusiasts, transport enthusiasts and simulation gamers.

This game is getting so outdated. I don't understand the praise for it anymore. The graphics are awful, controls are missing, safety systems are not realistic at all, and some of the trains accelerate unrealistic, Most TS fans will say I'm a hater just because I like Train Sim World more, which is equally as bad in some aspects sadly. Dovetail really should start delivering in 1 game though, not two. With Train Sim World 3 coming up I hope things will go better, but I doubt it, it's mostly a money grab for a simple addiction.

Of course the game has its plus points too, a lot of missions when purchasing a pack for example where you can have hours of driving, but even there you are met with spelling mistakes (And this review is probably full of them too but idc)

Would I recommend it to a casual gamer? Not at all, it's expensive, bad to run and takes a lot of time. To a die hard simmer? Maybe, but still I'll recommend TSW2/3 more.

Pros:
Free Version Update in September/October
Good Chunk of Content is in Steam Sales
Mod Friendly
Good Marketplace/Workshop Content
Good time Killer(for me)
Low amounts of storage
Cloud Backups of Game Progress
Somewhat Laggy but Ok 

Cons:
Visually Unappealing outside of the Tracks
DLC is expensive
Horn blast length on some engines (The AEM-7) are Not Controllable
Very Sensitive Alarms/ATC on Locomotives
Non-Accurate Horns(Example: The Metro North Shoreliners have what sounds like a Nathan K5LA Instead of a Leslie RS2M)
No Free Roam Sessions(where you can pick from a selection of trains on a route)
Difficult Route Creation Tools
Some Engines were Confusing/Difficult to learn the Operation of the Cab(The M2/M4 Was one of the hard ones to Learn. Even while reading the Manual).
Certain Lines are not Accurately Represented/Missing Elements
Routes are Glitched(for me at least)
Not fully Controller Friendly
Low Levels of Detail
Some engines are Missing/Take nearly 5-8 years to be made for a route
Slow acceleration on some engines

Basic Review/Tl:DR is: Good if you really only care about the trains and running them and not about any of the other details. I've had this sim since 2014, and while it hasn't changed much, it always provides a (mostly) realistic and accurate train simulation. There are locomotives available for purchase which have insanely detailed safety systems which place you in the heart of the simulation. Graphics are good, but they do fall short of modern day titles, even when compared to Dovetail's Train Sim World 2.

Although that is just a minor gripe, if you enjoy trains, it is definitely a worthy purchase :D

It pains me that I have spent so much money on a dud. I get the impression that the company knows this and sells a special deal at a special price, just to get rid of the stocks of a failure.

It started off so well with superb graphics and sound effects and slowly got worse with use over time. The first sign, was how it began to slow down the computer, then it took an age to load and now it won`t load properly and freezes itself and the computer when it tries. When this happens, the only way that I can restore use of the computer, is to turn it off and then on again.

Its silly overlaid messages drive me mad as well. I`ll give you an example. In the early days, I was about to leave the platform with a train when the doorbell rang. The visitor stayed for about half an hour and I then returned to the game. There was a message waiting for me saying that the train had left the station without closing the passenger doors. It hadn`t moved an inch in the previous half hour, so this message was ridiculous. There are others that are just as ridiculously false.

Knowing what I know now, would I recommend the purchase of it to anyone else ?  Most certainly not !

After playing over 700 hours of TS i feel like writing a review and give some advice.

First of all the variety is limited when buying the base game making the price a bit expensive. If you want to enjoy variety and realism you'll have to pay a lot more. I have spent a lot of money enhancing my game in many ways and at the end of the day it is defiantly worth it but requires a lot of commitment. As TS has been on steam for many years don't expect the graphics to be amazing. This depends on the route as newer DLC have slightly better graphics as stuff like newer textures have been used . If you are buying DLC that includes the trains i'm afraid to say this is where Dovetail games really lack. Dovetail games have been known for the poor sound quality when making stock. There are costly alternatives to this such as Armstrong Powerhouse who make high quality products. I also recommend RW Enhancer which is a software that enhances the sounds and visuals for TS. I best recommend this game during a sale as there are defiantly some generous deals. 
This game can be a bit buggy as well as FPS drops but overall not a hard game to run. I recommend you have reasonable memory for your pc and you should be fine.

To conclude this i will defiantly say TS is worth it as long as your willing to sacrifice some money if your wanting a better experience. If your just buying the game do not expect a wide variety of routes and trains.

I have a love/hate relationship with Train Sim. It's a game I've played for many years ever since I owned the original Rail Simulator on disc. As far as train sim games go, it's the best, no other series/games have really come close in matching the appearance, feel, and features of this game. But I still don't recommend for a few reasons, which are almost all the fault of Dovetail Games.

[list]
[*] The amount of DLC for this game is obscene, as is how much you'd have to spend to get it all (I believe it's somewhere in the thousands of £'s). When you consider that the stock game is fairly barebones, you're gonna want DLC to pad it out, and it can cost a shed-load. If you're strapped for cash, it just isn't worth getting it.
[*] DTG's inconsistency is ridiculous. Sometimes, a new route will be well-made, with great liveries, no bugs, and a wealth of scenarios. And then, the next one will be missing assets, buggy as hell, and with nothing to do. You can never guarantee that a new route will be any good, which is especially frustrating as there are some routes/locos I desperately want, but which I refuse to buy since numerous users have complained of game-breaking bugs and issues related to them.
[*] As mentioned before, a lot of trains and routes are just broken. Trains don't work, scenarios don't work, it's immensely frustrating. There is a loco you get in the vanilla game which is missing its AWS alert system, which means it'll simply jam on the emergency brakes randomly without warning, which makes it pretty much unplayable. It's ridiculous that stuff like this is still an issue and hasn't been fixed, with DTG instead just churning out more and more add-ons which get released in a buggy state and never get patched, because patching them doesn't make more money.
[/list]

Well, the dawn of a new era in TS Classic is here. Sadly I guess that means no more major updates to the core engine, which aside from tweaks to the UI is pretty much the best it can get.

Before the game can be somewhat playable, not gonna lie, money will need to spent on DLC. There are a few freeware routes out there but many use payware DLC. If there are 1 or 2 routes you would like, begin to build your route and loco collection. There were even a couple of humble bundles that included a tonne of DLC so keep your eyes out for deals on DTG website and steam also. Could save hundreds if you are patient and look around.

On the whole have had hours of fun on this, a few hours of not so fun, when things go wrong, but that isn't often. It "can" look incredible, with the right mods and routes and does what it says on the tin. Scenarios can add unlimited hours of challenge or just freeride around, choice is yours. If trains are your thing, invest in some DLC and off you go. If not, avoid.

I prefer this over TSW2, despite its age, it gives you more freedom and fairly easy to mod. TSW looks great but its quite linear, cant use all trains on all tracks, amongst other annoyances. It's very geared to the console player with its achievements and gameplay. Get TS classic if you like simulation and variety.

I have already spent quite a few hours on this sim, because i like it.
From the days of MS train sim i loved this kind of niche market.
Too bad that the Marias pass DLC was not available for the Netherlands, otherwise i would've bought this game a long time ago.

The immersion is quite good, i love the US tracks/trains. I also like the european variants, but not as much.
I have not tried everything in this game yet, i loved the audio and graphics so far.

I think it is absolutely nice (and educational) to have the possibility to see working signals and such. Having some "live" traffic from other trains make this much more realistic.

The menu feels a lot like MS train sim, so i felt at home quite quickly.

Few downsides:
I have not found a way to save multiple games.

As much as I like train sim, it's a complete pile of hot garbage. Constant crashing and bugs that've never been fixed or patched, a horribly outdated game engine from a decade ago, and with more and more advanced locomotives and route, unless you've got an amazing pc, it'll either crash or run at 15fps. The game only remains as popular as it is because people have sunk hundreds if not thousands of hours and dollars into the gaming hoping it'll get better, run smoother, but it won't, all it'll give you is more variety of locos to drive till the game crashes again. At this point Dovetail Games have completely ditched Train Simulator in favor or Train Sim World, so don't expect anything to change. Railroad online, TSW, or really any other train sim is worth more of your time and money that this dumpster fire. The only reason to buy the game is for the actual quality DLC from devs like VW, BMG, SSS, TF, and many others. If you do buy the game, give the third party devs you're money, not Dovetail.
The Game is realy good

The words "Train Simulator" and "fun" repel each other like magnets, and they don't exactly attract each other when you flip one of them around. The game often ends up as monotonous and boring after the initial "new factor" of getting DLC as most of the routes are so linear.

The game has a downright AWFUL model for DLC. No, seriously, it's one of the worst. The company shoves out DLC on a very frequent basis and the trains most of the time have unrealistic physics, sounds, consist formations and a lack of features. Routes are usually short, linear and offer the player to drive on...about 1 or 2 full services. This turns out to have very little play time on the DLC. Very disappointing for how much you have to spend.

Most of the features, such as Career Mode, serve no purpose. It is very punishing for no reason and many scenarios can be Career only. The XP points you receive do the nothing at the end of the day.

The game takes long to load. Like very long. I can boil the kettle and make a cuppa by the time it's finished to load. Sometimes the AI just randomly decides to have crashes and give you a game over screen if you don't test scenarios for hours and the points just decide to derail you when you go over if you SPAD. 

If you go on them in real life, the trains and sometimes routes are quite unbearable because of incorrect details, bad sounds and physics. Unfortunately, you have to spend even more money to make the sounds and physics good by buying Armstrong Powerhouse 3rd party DLC. They are damn expensive for what they are, but they sound quite nice.

It was fun 10 years ago, but not now.

TL:DR 
overpriced af

I can't say I recommend this game, neither do I claim this game isn't fun. (Maybe on the expensive side for just the base game, and then the DLC I'm eyeing seems to be as expensive again or worse than the base game) so, maybe if it goes on sale? My opinion is perfectly balanced, I'm afraid.

-- Using just a mouse, for the most part, you can drive the trains in the scenarios (I haven't yet done free play or quick drive yet.) However, just using the train, while I like it (and am tempted to see how this would handle in VR) there are several buttons that don't function (and are otherwise required to use via the minimal/maximum UI or keybinds that you have to learn) or are posted in the train's cab but do not operate at all. (The very second scenario driving the DB BRR442 Talent 2 or something has 3 icons that look like they operate the door controls on the train when you're at a station, but they don't do anything and thus I must rely on the T hotkey or click on a platform.)

--The game sometimes has a memory leak, this tends to be when I'm running it in 32 bit, so I have to run this through Steam's library (not the bottom right short cut) and change it to 64 bit or otherwise use another shortcut to specifically enter 64 bit, otherwise Steam automatically assumes 32-bit is the best. (Thanks, #Steam...) This, I don't blame on TS, but along the similar line, there [i]are[/i] many typos and mistaken instances, etc. in just the "train driver academy" that I feel like the game could have handled better. However, the most annoying I've encountered just now is that I recently finished a scenario and the game fails to recognise that I even completed the scenario at all. (And last I've [i]seen[/i] is that the game's dev team has last bothered any sort of patch since mid-summer 2020. Two-years later, these issues are still present? I doubt it'll ever be fixed.)

That being said, it comes down to weighing the pros/cons of this game. (Or I understand the team is working on a TS2? So [i]maybe[/i] go check that out instead.) However, the game is playable and I'm content, but I [i]REALLY[/i] wish the price was overall cheaper all around. (Base game, DLC, or at least fix some of the smaller and CRITICAL bugs..)

Well, time for me to update this review because just the entire first section needs re-writing. 

I did give it a 7.8/10 back in late 2016... I can't even give it that anymore. In fact, I can barely give it over a 4. 

The game is a timesink, that's the good part. The problem is, it's also a moneypit. So much DLC and more coming out monthly of varying quality (with the 700 being one of the single worst DLCs of all time, but that's another review for another time).

The game looks incredibly dated now. The Railworks 3 graphics just do not hold up nowadays and it's really noticeable now. Not to mention there's so many bugs that just don't get sorted, and the fact that even with 64-bit so much just doesn't work. 

At least they're not going to update in yearly with a number number (I hope), but man, I've owned this game for over 7 years now and it's actually quite embarrassing how little has actually changed. 

Dovetail need to do a lot of work on this game. Resting on your laurels isn't acceptable anymore, and I've watched it get worse for half a decade now. 

4/10 - Game works, does what it's supposed to do most of the time but it's so tired and bloated I can't recommend it.

Ok just opened this up and my first item to look at was the Tehachapi route. As I had previously purchased this particular route and found it disappointing I was interested to see if promised improvements and updates had been made. Well the answer is sort of. Scenery looks to have a bit more detail and the brakes are working better on the locos. My biggest disappointment with the original version was that the signals did not work correctly and this was supposed to be one of the things fixed. Well again sort of. Signal masts with only one head now appear to show all indications. Unfortunately any mast with more than one head is another matter. The best indication you can expect is a yellow, never a green, even if the track is clear for blocks ahead. Red does show when you pass.

The other problem is the locomotive headlights. They do turn on but when viewed from lineside they only show light when viewed from a distance. As the train gets close they appear to turn off. Whats with that. I guess this is just another route rushed out the door from developers who may know computers but their knowledge of trains appears limited and there Quality Control even more.

Even though I have visited this route in real life, on a number of occasions and was looking forward to it in this simulation I doubt it will get much use due to its frustrating failures.
