This review is now updated and applies only to Train Simulator 2022 and the DLC it contains. 

Train Simulator 2022 is going to look old. It's an ancient graphics engine that dates back to 2009 or some such and it's been updated year after year since then. It looks nothing like it did then, it's far better! But it's still exactly modern. The base game comes with a slew of training scenarios to get you going and several DLC to start with. Here's the thing about TS: The base game is basically a free upgrade every year, but if you buy it, you get a lot of new DLC at a very large discount - sometimes more than 75% depending on the package. 

This version of TS comes with 3 routes that I'll detail briefly here. If you want one of the "bigger" versions, check the reviews for those individual route DLC's. 

tl:dr - Two really REALLY nice routes with modern electric locomotives. Both are a pleasure to drive and everything works well. One route that's pretty and well detailed with nice locomotives, but at least one related broken achievement and one scenario that can't be completed with full points. 

Please don't get hung up on the plethora of DLC's. No one expects you to buy all or even most of them. Some are just plain bad, some are great. Check the reviews! The idea behind Train Simulator is to figure out what kind of train and/or routes you enjoy driving. Buy those DLC. If you want more recommendations, feel free to ask in the comments. 

Now the details!

- Frankfurt - Koblenz: This is a really fantastically designed route. It's unusually long and well detailed. The locomotive you get to drive is a modern electric and is relatively easy to drive. There are 7 scenarios that are roughly between 30 and 105 minutes in length. They all work fine. All the related achievements to this route trigger properly. 

- Birmingham Cross City Line: Lichfield – Bromsgrove & Redditch: Another really well designed route. It's a modern electric locomotive also. It's sounds are good and it drives well. There are 6 scenarios ranging from around 30 min to nearly an hour and a half. The timing is quite tight on a couple of the scenarios (If you're late you lose points, but it doesn't stop you from completing it) but they're doable. It just might take more than one try. One of the achievements relating to this route is currently broken. 

- Northeast Corridor: Washington DC - Baltimore: Sadly, this route is kind of a mess. It's recreated nicely with good detail but I feel it was rushed out the door for a couple of reasons. It is advertised as having 5 scenarios. This is less than routes normally come with. A clue is given away in that there are actually six, but the sixth has problems. You can finish it, but not with 1000 points. I expect they meant to remove it. Further, there is an achievement for completing scenario 7 which doesn't exist. Likely another broken one that WAS removed - but they forgot the achievement. Sad but true. The other 5 scenarios do work fine. While the problems with this route seem very sloppy, overall, you will get enjoyment from the 5 scenarios that do work. There are two modern Amtrak electric locomotives that you drive. Both are nice. One has a speed control which makes it more relaxing to drive. You don't have to turn it on however, if you want to be more interactive. 

One real downside is that there's no steam or diesel locomotives included in the base game. Usually every TS release has something of all three major locomotive types. Aside from that, there's not a lot to complain about. I'm usually a fan of diesel locomotives but enjoyed everything in the base game this year.

Overall it's a good game, it can be kind of boring if you're on a long route but there's plenty you have to do and look out for. It's a solid game, good scenery, the tutorials are good and the trains easy to operate.

What really disappoints me is the routes. There are few if any routes that come with the base game and the only way to drive someplace else is through downloadable content. It definitely is not a game built on micro-transactions model. Micro-transactions are a few bucks for content that will help you buy your way to success in a game. Having to shell out $20-40 for EACH new route and having it be no more than 50 miles long (why does the Amtrak Northeast Corridor sell in pieces and not the whole thing?), that is a MACRO-transaction! This is very disappointing. The main reason I chose this over Train Sim World is that there are freeware downloadable routes (if you can find them) that people make using the route editor. Even when I find DLC routes on the Steam store, I can't get any detailed information like a route map.

If they want TS2022 to be a top-notch game, they can start by being a lot more transparent about the routes, and their backgrounds, where they go, how long they are, and stop charging so much for them. There's no reason why someone should have to pay as much as the game itself just to add some 20 mile route and then we don't even know anything about it.

Thank goodness for freeware routes or else this could be a very expensive hobby!

I have been playing this game and it's precursor, Rail Simulator, for almost 15 years, and while it is a great game, I have to say that this game is not optimized to work on modern machines. My PC is way over-spec'd for this game yet I still lag on many maps, actually getting the *SAME* performance with my older PC which had a GTX1650 and my current rig has a RTX3070 with double the ram and double the Vram. Also, on the topic of Ram, the game will now randomly crash, citing "Ran out of Memory". It's gotten very frustrating. The graphics are very dated and many of the trains just don't sound good. Many of the DLC trains and routes are crapshoots since they're all made by different people with different techniques. The Graphics have not been updated since Rail Simulator, which came out in 2007... It looks like a 2007 game even though it's 2022. Dovetail NEEDS to do performance and graphical improvements, as well as lowering the price on DLC, I'm pretty sure I've spent over $1000 on this game in just DLC, which like I said earlier is a crapshoot, it's like a box of chocolates really. I do enjoy playing it but those gripes really destroy it for me. Bad graphics, Crashing, bad performance, too expensive

Lazy programming, poor performance, incomplete base game, and an absolutely deplorable amount of far too highly priced DLC.

Game takes me over a minute just to get to the main menu, then over three minutes to load into a level. This should not happen on an SSD. If I lived in a civilized part of the world, I could download this entire game in the time it takes me to go from desktop to playing. It takes so long to load I don't even want to try playing it anymore, and am getting a refund.

The framerate also regularly lapses into a slideshow, then transitions back to smooth, repeatedly. And there seems to be a general lack of polish re: menus and such. 

Not to mention the 498 items of DLC that cost, even at a steep discount, nearly four thousand You Ess buckeroos. I want to just buy a complete game and play it. 

This is extremely disappointing.


EDIT: Wow, they're up to 650 dlc items now. And keep in mind, most of these cost twenty to forty bucks EACH. For a half-finished game the devs don't care about. It's insane.

In 2022, this platform is absolutely [b]brimming[/b] with content - it now truly provides the vast scope of choice needed to span almost all diverse railroading tastes. You can buy what you like and leave what you don't - just check the reviews first and be sure to treat each product as a basis to potentially customise and make your own. As with the physical world of model railroading, some products you buy in your hobby store are hit and miss, but for all those misses in Train Simulator, there are usually fantastic upgrades made by passionate people such as Armstrong Powerhouse to breathe life into them and make those products more exciting and, above all, more personal to you.

Yes, there are still some issues with UI and a few crashes here and there being a system often struggling to accommodate as much legacy content as possible ([b]turning your wifi off before you start the game will immediately eliminate many of the memory related crashes[/b]), but even with these issues, it's still such a reasonable, wonderful way to thoroughly enjoy the railroading hobby alongside (or instead of) the more physical, space consuming model railroading side of things many of us also enjoy too.

If you love railways, Train Simulator in 2022 is a fantastic way to chill out and enjoy your passion. With such a giant selection of content that can be purchased both on the Steam store and through many excellent third party creators, it can be as personal and as bespoke as you want it to be. And, if like many, you want a break from creating structured scenarios, the free roaming functionality takes your content and turns it into possibly the largest digital model train set you could imagine, allowing you to place any purchased trains out on your desired route and jump between them dynamically providing almost limitless options - it really becomes a completely different game at that point and I encourage everyone to give it a go!

Happy driving and here's to a great 2022 with lots of exciting new releases :D

Here's another secret - there's actually even more content for sale here than what is available on Steam. Completism and trophy hunting have led people to believe they would have to acquire all of this to see the 'full' game, which is just not true.

The way to approach this is to view it as something of a model train set.
You buy the basic foundation and stick what you want on that.
If you're not a hardcore railfan or simmer just want to dip in and out of various routes, you'll be fine with one of the packs that come out each year.
Go back and find an old version on a reseller store if you don't want this year's version.
If you're more interested in train travel and sims, you'll probably already have a specific interest in one area, so you'll concentrate on acquiring routes like that.
US freight, British passenger transport, Austrian mountain routes - there's a rich amount of content in all these areas, and with third party improvements such as those from Armstrong Powerhouse it's quite clear why there's still life in this, 12 years after its first incarnation. So much, in fact, that as I write this simulator is above its supposed successor,
Train Sim World 2, in current players on Steam.

TS is an easy target for cheap jokes, and there is an infuriating habit among the modding community (though many do sterling work for free) of utilizing obscure and useless DLC packs in their mods (hello BR Blue pack, hello long-deleted 101 Pack), but for every official release of a train without working headlights or essential safety systems, there's impressive content made with care and attention. Bossman's Welsh Marches, Dovetail's own Semmeringbahn and GTrax's criminally underrated Suisun Bay route are 3 examples of the best of these, and then there are the devs making incredibly complex simulations that Dovetail would never have the freedom to attempt. That's one reason this game has lasted so long - to their credit Dovetail made modding and route-building accessible, meaning third parties work on everything from fun content like Story of Forest Rail to those full simulations, allowing DTG themselves to concentrate on the big crowd-pleasers.

In short, don't blame Dovetail for simply adding a number each year and rarely significantly improving the product itself. Blame those of us who have looked a bit deeper and found almost everything we could want from a train sim, and despite ancient graphics and out-of-memory errors, are quite happy where we are, thanks. It's a nice community too, one of the more helpful around - you're very welcome. - Kamandur_kAy

Dovetail train games are silly.  It's 2022 but there is no [real] controller support for either this game or their new on (Train Sim World).  Only options are Raildriver or a xbox controller (or a hack), otherwise you have to use your keyboard (can you say 1990's) or their HUD controls (that's really immersive). 

Then there is the constant fight with any software or utilities that has "head tracking" in it turn off the mouse view controls.  The software goes into the registry looking for head tracking software and forces head tracking if it finds it.  No option for you to turn it off.  Their answer since they provided head tracking capability.... uninstall your head tracking software...for the last 7+ years.  No checkbox in the options.  Nope.  You uninstall it.... that is... if you can find which one is causing it.

I do play the game, that is, when I can get it to work properly....  I just don't recommend it anymore.

They've been rebranding this game since it was called Railworks 3, for over 10 years, and they've also been re-releasing old DLC.

The last meaningful update was the TS2016 edition that overhauled several things but they forced existing owners to rebuy the game to have access to the exclusive GTEL, then later made it apart of the Sherman Hill DLC for Free completely alienating veteran players.

The last content update to the base game was a BNSF ES44. - First content update I've seen since I bought it. (DLC isn't a content update, it's DLC)

The game is good for what it is, but it's old and severely out dated - it badly needs a graphical and technical overhaul. It's a buggy mess.

As far as the price of DLC's go, they sell reskins for a premium and they're honestly overpriced, the only reason people in the Simulator Community are ok with it is because they're likely hobbyist who'd end up having to spent thousands on a Model Railroad anyway. 
TS is a cheaper alternative to doing that. TRS isn't much better in this regard.

As far as Trainz vs TS, it's very much a pick your poison, Trainz will offer you alot of variety, but suffers from similar problems, Trainz isn't exactly Plug and Play, but is incredibly modular with a massive community behind it. While TS is more Plug and Play and has a higher visual quality over Trainz, but almost no community additions outside Maps, Scenarios and a few Third-Party tools.

Both TRS and TS have multitudes of DLC, but TRS has a very passionate community - When I buy DLC for TRS Official or Third Party, I know I'm supporting a Community Member, not the Company.

If you're a train enthusiast/hobbyist, I personally would recommend N3V's TRS over DTG's TS, but, I don't see a real reason not to get TS on Sale, other than the questionable business practices from DTG, it's a solid game for what it is, but, it's not good either, honestly, this is a better "Simulator" than TRS, while TRS is a virtual Model Railroad with a simulator element.

I recommend this over Trainz for its simplicity and general quality over Trainz, but I certainly have my issues with it. - TS was outstanding in 2012, now it just feels like a chore just to do anything.

This game is a strong neutral "meh" from me, but, I honestly can't give it a positive score, I've recommended it and preferred it for years, but after recently returning to recreate a Scenario for my 10th Anniversary with TS - I've grown to detest this game.

Reading this review, it's made it clear there's nothing good to say about this game other than it has a decent visual and audio quality and even that's subpar at best, the only redeeming quality is the Simulator element but that's it.

Look, it's Dovetail, it's Train Simulator, you know the deal. Some bugginess, a hellish menu interface, some hit and miss over whether broken routes will ever be fixed to satisfaction. People with zero interest in playing it complaining that there's a lot of content. Allow me to let you in on a secret - that €10k of content? You aren't forced to buy it all to have a complete experience. In fact, I think it's physically impossible in one lifetime to fully explore the entire extent of routes and scenarios that have been created for TS. Here's another secret - there's actually even more content for sale here than what is available on Steam. Completism and trophy hunting have led people to believe they would have to acquire all of this to see the 'full' game, which is just not true.

The way to approach this is to view it as something of a model trainset. You buy the basic foundation and stick what you want on that. If you're not a hardcore railfan or simmer just want to dip in and out of various routes, you'll be fine with one of the packs that come out each year. Go back and find an old version on a reseller store if you don't want this year's version. If you're more interested in train travel and sims, you'll probably already have a specific interest in one area, so you'll concentrate on acquiring routes like that. US freight, British passenger transport, Austrian mountain routes - there's a rich amount of content in all these areas, and with third party improvements such as those from Armstrong Powerhouse it's quite clear why there's still life in this, 12 years after its first incarnation. So much, in fact, that as I write this simulator is above its supposed successor, Train Sim World 2, in current players on Steam. 

TS is an easy target for cheap jokes, and there is an infuriating habit among the modding community (though many do sterling work for free) of utilising obscure and useless DLC packs in their mods (hello BR Blue pack, hello long-deleted 101 Pack), but for every official release of a train without working headlights or essential safety systems, there's impressive content made with care and attention. Bossman's Welsh Marches, Dovetail's own Semmeringbahn and GTrax's criminally underrated Suisun Bay route are 3 examples of the best of these, and then there's the devs making incredibly complex simulations that Dovetail would never have the freedom to attempt. That's one reason this game has lasted so long - to their credit Dovetail made modding and route-building accessible, meaning third parties work on everything from fun content like Story of Forest Rail to those full simulations, allowing DTG themselves to concentrate on the big crowd pleasers. 

In short, don't blame Dovetail for simply adding a number each year and rarely significantly improving the product itself. Blame those of us who have looked a bit deeper and found almost everything we could want from a train sim, and in spite of ancient graphics and out of memory errors, are quite happy where we are, thanks. It's a nice community too, one of the more helpful around - you're very welcome.

With a 2080 you don't!). For everything else there is Train SIm World, beautiful graphically but overall (physics, sounds, complexity of the maps) less simulative.
I repeat: to have the best you need to buy third-party trains and locomotives (3DZug, vR, etc) because, always generally, the trains that come out by default with the routes are really basic and not at all simulative (no safety systems and sounds at all). equal to TSW, or almost).
Defects? Sure, different. But it still remains better than the competition.
Zusi 3 is even more simulation but it is really silly graphically.
So overall Train Simulator is still the best and most complete for those who want to drive (and not look around or be a passenger).

Oh did I mention DLC? Don't even get started on that.


2019 UPDATE:

Pretty much nothing has changed. Routes are short, equipment selection is limited, and god forbid you drop more money on better routes because they offer some of the most appalling value propositions I've ever seen. 7 scenarios for a $15 route, with "many more hours of exciting gameplay on the Workshop" which is disingenuous at best and a more accurately a big fat lie.

Why? Because just about every single "free" scenario out there calls for a laundry list of additional DLC worth at least $50, including $10 for a bloody hopper car whose job is to just sit on a siding while you whizz past at 50mph.

My original criticism and recommendation against buying into this kind of business model still stands. Support another company like N3V Games or SCS Software.


2021 update:

While there have been several QOL updates since, it is still the usual circus show since the early days when DTG was still called RSC. Add a couple of new routes, slap new fancy cover art on it and sell it as a new version. Most other DLC (oh look it's this again) released even today are wanting in either detail, performance, realism, quality control or some combination of all. I looked at reviews for over a dozen routes that piqued my interest in the latest Autumn Sale, and nearly all of them have negative reviews going back *years* about trackwork problems, session bugs and other gamebreaking issues with little indication that DTG of the developers in their ecosystem have any interest in rectifying.

Thus, the Dovetail ecosystem is still as slimy as ever:
1. Develop cheap and rushed DLC full of bugs and errors. Package it with ancient content.
2. Release said DLC for an unreasonably high price.
3. Wait for suckers to buy it at full price, and non-suckers to buy it on sale.
4. Ignore bug reports and feedback.
5. ...?
6. Profit. Rinse and repeat.

Absolute scum of a developer. The only money I can conscionably recommend spending on this trash heap of an ecosystem are the rare, legacy routes with good reviews and an established set of free content developed for it (such as the Alan Thompson or DPsimulation mega route merges) and even so, you're still likely to run into the age-old "freeware needs more payware to function" issue.

2/10 would recommend Trainz 2022 instead.


In response to Jay:

I wouldn't think twice when buying DLC from an honest developer who has a track record of quality, bug-free work that takes user feedback and ideas into account, and general behavior that accommodates or even cater to the third party modding community. Even when there are bugs, they are fixed quickly and properly. For these devs, I insist on nothing but buying their DLC at launch, at full price, sometimes even if I don't have time to play them right away.

Dovetail's DLCs are expensive, low quality, lack support, lack aftermarket content, lack replayability, and are generally one of the worst ways I can think of to spend money on the train sim genre. It doesn't matter how large of a catalog you have if all of them offer the same disgusting value proposition which is close to nil. You might argue: DTG doesn't create most of these. To which the response is: sure, but you're also taking a cut of their sales and hence have zero incentive to encourage anything other than gross dev practices that simply prioritize quantity over quality and just churning out more garbage DLCs.

The Train Simulator series is the Gold Standard in railroad simulation.

It is graphically impressive. I've often been late completing tasks in the scenarios because I am taking screenshots on the rain reflecting off the boiler of the steam locomotive I am driving. 

It has a huge fan base. Even if you complete every scenario you own, there is plenty of content to keep you going in the Steam Workshop and through third parties making content for Train Simulator. 

Don't be discouraged by the negative comments referring to this game as a "DLC Simulator".

Is there an abundance of DLC? 

Yes. That isn't negative though. It allows you to build your Train Simulator game the way you want it.

You can't expect to be given the whole Steam Store's worth of DLC for 30 dollars. 

Instead, you get a few routes, scenarios, and locomotives to start you off. If you like what you see you then have the option of buying DLC based on you interests.

The game has held my attention over the last eight years and 552 hours.

The question of recommending or not recommending the TS in year 2021 is somewhat complex. Eventually I'd say, I do recommend it. But not to everyone. By far not to everyone.

There are things you need to know about this game. Bad things. Basically: it's old. Every year there is some small update to the core game (which is, by the way, free for all owners), a package of new routes (which you may choose to purchase or not), but this won't change the fundamental fact that the engine is more than ten years old and it is already pushed beyond its limits. It's not pretty. If you look for pretty, go for the Train Sim World, a newer game of the same developer. It's not well optimised. It does not use the modern hardware efficiently. Contrary to what you might expect, it will not run smoothly even on a state-of-the-art gaming pc in detail-heavy routes. Did I mention it's not pretty? Yes? Then I also need to mention it may crash every now and then. So there it is. Technically speaking this game is TERRIBLY outdated. 

On top of this, it is definitely not very approachable. You have loads of DLCs of varying quality, from total rubbish to absolute gems of modelling (within the engine constraints). Manuals in many cases are poor to say the least. There is a lot of errors in many DLCs. Ah, and yes, DLCs. There are thousands. And if you want to really have some fun playing you will need at least some of them. Learning curve for this game can be steep. I personally had three attempts. One after I bought it originally in 2016 I think. Then somewhere later. And eventually around 2019, when it finally caught.

So why would you even want to consider this despite all of what I just said? Because what is hidden behind this not-so-beautiful surface is a very decent railway simulator. There are newer and prettier games, but none which offer so many opportunities. Opportunities in terms of creating and finding addons and scenarios. It's like the MS Flight Simulator on rails (well, except not all areas of the world are well represented). If you are a hard core railway fan and have time to learn how to use it, the TS is still an unmached (even if deeply flawed in many respects) environment.

Be aware, that to use its potential, you will need to invest into DLCs. Either time or money. Or both. There are wonderful freeware addons for this game. Some are outstandingly complex, comparable to the best pieces of payware (Skoda 109E locomotive is a wonderful exapmle of that). But finding them and making them work takes time. On the other hand there is quite a lot of good payware. Some of it also outstanding (like products of Railworks Austria or Virtual Railroads, mostly available outside Steam), but also quite expensive (30-40 € for a loco isn't unusual). Then there are also pretty decent cheaper and older addosn, many of them available on Steam.

There are ways to make up your collection at reduced cost. Sales are frequent, I hardly ever buy my stuff outside sales. Older content, which can be very good, may become available at a pittance. Outside steam you can find old packages of Train Simulator 2013, 2014, 2015 etc., which today act as inexpensive bundles of really decent older routes. So there are ways of making your bill lowER, but ultimately you can easily sink a lot of money in this game. 

Is it worth it? Well, if you are a real railway fan, and you want to give it a try, best wait for a sale (or buy some older low-cost package from other retailer) and check for yourself. There is just a chance you might love it. But be aware, this is definitely not a product for just any casual gamer.

If you look for a more casual and less rough product, just to do some easy and pretty railroading, I'ld recommend the Train Sim World instead. Game with more limitations of what you can do in it, but much more of a "plug and play" type. Also prettier and more modern. Which, however, will never fully replace this one.

This game has its ups and downs. It is probably currently the best train simulator on the market, but it's specific.

1) Graphics - It's pretty good, but the engine is old, and it's not as good as other recent train simulators (TSW, Railsim etc.)
2) Realism - Well, it's pretty simple. It really lacks a lot of features of real life driving, but it still keeps the medium level realism. A lot depends on creators. Some routes and some trains are really amazing, others are pretty bad and also bugged. Some Steam locos are masterpiece of scripting and some other trains are just plain basic. Unfortunately there are many limitations in the engine.
3) Accessibility - The game is aimed mostly at occasional players. There is simple controls mode. Still more advanced players can have a lot of fun especially with Pro Range add-ons and some steam locos can be very challenging to drive.
4) Routes - Reading points 1-3 one may think that the sim is pretty mediocre. Indeed, it is but why it wins on the market is because of how many routes and stock it has. There is no other sim that allows you to drive for 5-6h straight (London to Penzance, Linz to Lindau etc.), no other sim has so much diversity, starting with XIX century steam finnishing at TGV and even Maglev. Of course nobody can afford to buy all of them, but there is really a lot to pick from, especially in UK, USA, Germany and Austria.
5) Workshop - A lot of people are creating stuff for the game. There are plenty of freeware routes and scenarios which keeps the game alive. We can also create stuff pretty easily ourselves.
6) Third-party tools - There are tools like ThirdRails which track your journey on GPS and gives you real life shcedules. There are many possibilities to extend the fun of the game outside of what it was designed for.
7) Timetable mode - Unfortunately, the game lacks a timetable mode. We can only use premade scenarios, Quick Drive, which is pretty basic run from A to B and Free Roam mode. The latter allows us to explore the route, but without other moving traffic. Therefore, it's hard to drive realistically. We can use real life schedules in QD mode, but other trains will be random with very rarely any red light stopping us.
8) Hudless driving - The game comes with a HUD which displays incomming speed limits, stations etc. Still it is possible to drive without a HUD, like a real train driver would do. This of course requires some route learning or making notes. Some routes are very easy to drive HUDless, some require a lot of preparation, but I must admit that it works very well. Good for immersion.

To summarize. Any train fan should try the game. The basic package comes with only a few routes, but it's pretty good to start and see what the game has to offer. Later one can decide if he wants to invest in more routes or quit. This map shows all available payware and some freeware routes (there are however much more freeware routes to be found): http://umap.openstreetmap.fr/en/map/train-simulator-2021_252726

It's usually wise to explore one region for example extending what we already have, but some people may decide that they prefer more diversity and buying completely different regions.

Okay so, here's my review for Train Simulator

The Good section:
-Its very fun if you're really bored (mostly for railfanners)
-Its easy to play
-There's a wide variety of trains and routes
-You can create custom consists and have fun with them
-The trains are very detailed
-The community is welcoming

The okayish section:
-Not every train has a different sound, I would understand if 2 different trains had something like the same horn, for example, the M8 and the M7. But hearing the same horn on every cabcar is annoying.
-Not all the sounds come from the real trains.
-Suggestions aren't taken too often.
-The Graphics are okay, but its not too friendly to lower tier devices, as it will occasionally lag on a low tier laptop on starting
-Alerters are annoying and confusing, when you depart, the alerter will enable, slowing you down and making you late

The Bad Section.
-Derailments happen too easily
-Penalties have little to no context
-The game crashes by tabbing out of it onto another tab
-Most of the trains are gated by a paywall
-There's not enough free routes
-Every time you get a DLC, you have to update the game, which could take a while
 
Theres too many good and bad things to name but heres my solutions for the bad things and okay things.
1. Have more free routes, at least 10, 5 can be freight, all from around the world, and the rest of the 5 can be passenger service from around the world.
2. Reduce the DLC prices, everyone has to wait months for a sale just to get a DLC they want.
3. Give more context when a penalty is handed, like a timeliness penalty, it can either be good or bad.
4. Try and script derailments better.
5. Take more sample sounds from trains.
6. Fix the alerters, Make them have a cooldown.
7. Have Low Tier Versions.
8. Have a website where you can drop in suggestions, where they are all read every friday.

The rest, I have no idea to fix because I haven't developed a big game for a big game platform, but please take this feedback, many railfans enjoy the game but there are some things that need improvement.

But in all, I don't recommend it if you're looking for people looking for pure quality, but I recommend it if you're just looking for a game to have fun in when you're extremely bored.

This is an great game for train enthusiasts of all ages. I have had this game since TS 2012 and have loved every moment playing it.  With a huge selection of routes, locomotives, rolling stock, and scenarios, a built in editor, and access to the steam workshop, there is no time to be bored.

This game has not received very many updates over the years, so it certainly shows its age. DLC can be hit or miss. DLC is a bit expensive in my opinion, so I wait for sales before I buy anything for this game. There is also lots of great third party content (some you have to pay for but most is free) that helps make this game enjoyable.

I would give this game a 6.5/10, and I recommend this game to everyone, unless you are looking for mind blowing graphics and perfect game play.  Because you won't find those here

[b]It may be called Train Simulator 2022 now, but that's the only thing that has changed. Its a game from 2011 with a sticker over its title.[/b]

The few hours I've played it were mostly frustrating. The game runs between 20 - 40 FPS on medium settings with a GTX1060 and i7 (6k series).  This fps range varies between tracks, but it's never a clean 60. Controlling a passenger train feels pretty lifeless, static passengers waiting at a station to get in and that's about it.

[i]Who would I recommend this for?[/i]
For train sim fans out there that have a fat wallet and a beast of a PC, by all means try this game out. Or perhaps if you have a favorite route that's available in one of the many DLC's, it could be worth the experience. 

[i]And for the rest?[/i]
Try looking for alternative titles first, otherwise if you must... then wait for a big sale.

Train Simulator 2021 is by far the most realistic train simulation game I have ever played and is even superior to Train Sim World. I have to start doing reviews more often about my favorite games. First off, Train Simulator 2021 has the best train simulation sound effects one could possibly ask for. While it may not have that many rolling stock sound effects, they are the best sound effects you could ever hear. To make things even better, there are various dlcs to satisfy your locomotive operation cravings. Even the base routes are pretty expansive, but you will have to eventually forfeit/fork over around $20-$50 for a route. Even the bad routes are great routes. For example, one user claims that the Canadian routes aren't even elevated. The fact of the matter is that I highly disagree. Even though I do not yet own any of the Canadian routes, I can't just sit there and believe that one ungrateful steam user's claim is correct. Sure, Train Simulator 2021 isn't as graphically polished as Trainz Railroad Simulator 2019, but what it lacks in graphics, it makes up in content, realism, and fun. And additionally, the graphics aren't grim at all. They're actually very realistic, even if the sun's lens glare may not look all that colorful. The amount of rolling stock isn't as exactly as varied as N3V games' TRS 2019 with over hundreds of rolling stock and locomotives if you bought every single dlc route and dlc locomotive and rolling stock, and over thousands of rolling stock and locomotives and routes if you actually take the time to browse through the game's built in download station where over hundreds of newly created user content is being uploaded almost everyday. 

The good stuff:
-Realistic sound effects that usually vary by train car
-Realistic locomotive sounds and operation
-Over 600+ downloadable content items to purchase and play around with
-Very balanced colors that may make the game grim, but far more realistic in comparison to other train simulating games
-Millions to billions of hours to invest in content from the steam workshop and dlc items from the store
-Varying railroads to operate in routes available for the game
-Professionally revised DLC versions of base locomotives that can all be purchased on Steam
-Multiple opportunities for shunting, switching, sorting, passenger runs, freight runs, steam excursions, and more railroading
-AI train programming that is very easy to use
-Simple and realistic modes that are fun and challenging
-Tons of routes to play around with
-Tons of railfanning opportunities in almost any free drive, career, or user made scenario
-Tough and almost challenging grades that are fun to overcome
-Realistic railroad operations 
-Highly detailed routes, locomotives, rolling stock, and scenarios

Bad stuff:
-Not enough rolling stock sounds
-Rolling stock isn't really varied and is instead just repainted train cars
-Not all locomotives have operation manuals
-Some dlcs are faulty or malfunction
-Some locos have the same horn
-Some scenarios have bugs or are broken
-No scenic railroad or tourist railroad routes (e.g. Cass Scenic Railroad State Park) to play with
-Steam locomotive whistles don't always work the way they're supposed to (e.g. you can't really use the whistles like real steam locomotive engineers do) 
-AI trains don't honk their horns, blow their whistles or ring their bells when approaching railroad crossings, backing up, sitting, waiting for signal clearance, in distress, or other situations where horn sounding is required
-AI trains don't have minds of their own (don't really do anything unless they're given commands)
-You can only operate one train at a time in free roam scenarios making it impossible to make runaway train events
-No extinct American locomotives feature as downloadable content
-Railroad crossing sounds aren't varied and designs are not at all realistic
-Only a handful of American railroads feature in the game and dlcs
-Not all locomotives are fitted with their respective bells, horns, whistles, or engine sounds
-The Cumbres And Toltec Scenic railroad isn't featured

Edit: The railroad crossings are highly inaccurate in this game. Their designs are questionable, lazy, and less varied. Improve your railroad crossings Dovetail Games. Stop being lazy.

Got back into Train Sim after rediscovering my parents' n-scale collection and remembering the fun I had on the 2001 Microsoft Train Simulator. In all honesty, I don't really see that any progress has been made in the last 20 years, and if anything this game is worse. The graphics look like tech demos for the iPhone 4. Loading a game is likely to trigger an emergency stop because the train loads in at about 15 mph faster than it was actually going. Gamepad controls aren't customizable. Camera positions are glitchy and underwhelming. Tunnel objects and bridges have weird clipping issues. Missions are incredibly boring and tedious. 

This game holds your hand incessantly while simultaneously giving absolutely no feedback in a deadly combination that would be hard to engineer that way if you tried. 

I seriously could not believe that I'd seen all there was to see, so I kept at it. Turns out I just actually got scammed.

TS2021? It's Microsoft Train Simulator from the early 2000's with a lick of paint...

*Revisited after 40-ish hours. Sticking with "No" as there isn't a "maybe, but with caveats" option.

It still looks like an old game, but there's more going on here than meets the eye.  There's a huge back catalogue of routes for this thing, and absolutely loads of user created scenarios for them.  There's definitely a lot more to do here than the scant handful of activities that each route comes with by default, but it still lacks the full 24 hour service mode of it's successor. 

There's not much here for the more casual player, but there is definitely a lot to like if you're a train fan, and it does have steam traction which is a big plus over TSW/TSW2.  UK signalling seems to be more accurate as well - TSW has *still* not properly implemented turnout signals for instance. PZB seems to be pretty shoddy though, so if you're a fan of German traction bear that in mind.

Approach it as a digital train set rather than a conventional game, and keep an eye on the store tab as there is almost *always* stuff on sale.  

Difficult to recommend to anyone who isn't a massive railfan.  Recommended to railfans who simply want more trains than TSW currently delivers, especially if you tend to stick to one region/country.

I held off buying this for ages as it looked a bit niche and, although I appreciate all engineering and mechanics, I'm not really a train fan. (Even after 600 + hours, I couldn't tell you a single train model number or even manufacturer). However, it was on offer so I snapped it up and I'm glad I did. 

You don't need to be a "trainspotter" type to enjoy this game, although if you're interested in trains then this will be an added bonus of course. This game is great to relax and unwind to due to it's slow pace (although changing speed limits and station stops etc keep it interesting). The routes and scenery (the latter not being very realistic however) are varied and challenging, especially if you use the steam trains.

The game features a ton of (famously overpriced) dlc from Dovetail and add-ons from 3rd parties such as Just Trains. There are some really brilliant routes and trains available that blow the stock content out of the water so I would advise setting some extra money aside to purchase those! Everything from a fully functioning steam engine (see Smokebox) to the latest electric trains with functioning switches etc, through to London Underground/Overground routes, HSL, US routes through NY and routes around the Swiss Alps to name a few. In fact, I would say the stock content is pretty unplayable after you've played the add-ons (the trains more than the routes which are ok but short. Most of the controls/switches etc in the stock trains are non-functioning whereas they work in the add-ons usually).

There is also a route creator which enables you to make your own "scenario" on an existing route or even lay down your own track and make your own route. It takes some getting used to (especially making your own route) but allows you to theoretically create any route you like (assuming you have the skill/time/patience).

+ Pretty unique game (not many other train sims out there like this)
+ Easy to learn, difficult to master
+ Routes are realistic
+ Realistic controls/gameplay
+ Loads of DLC trains/routes/stock from Dovetail and other 3rd party vendors. Most prove a massive improvement of the stock content.
+ Massive longevity (I've got over 600 hours and I've not played every single route/scenario even)
+ Custom route and scenario editor

- DLC and add-ons are very expensive. There are also so many you would need thousands of £ to get everything. They are also far superior to the stock content which makes avoiding buying them difficult. 
- When you buy an add-on route, it comes with scenarios. These scenarios are usually tied in with another add-on model meaning you have to make another 2 or 3 purchases to get the trains required in order to play it. This makes it very expensive. (The key is to get the route and create a custom scenario using a train you do have by loading it into the editor. Or ignore scenarios altogether and do your own thing).
- Slow pace won't appeal to everyone (no speed up time either)
- Railfan scenarios seem ridiculously boring to me. You don't drive the train, you are a passenger and just go on the route. If that appeals to you then ignore this bit.
VERY long load up time (reminds me of loading a game from a Cassette tape recorder) and minimal help. Not user friendly at all.

Train Simulator is both a game I enjoy and a game I don't really recommend to my friends for a few reasons. The first reason is obvious, Train Simulator has a ridiculous amount of DLC. I mean just mountains and mountains of DLC. Some are made very well and are enjoyable, others... not so much. Some are so lazy that they have missions that are not even possible to complete and achievements that are impossible to get. There is one thing, however, that all the DLC has in common: It is all insanely overpriced, and many of them are overpriced even when on sale. The other thing I really dislike about the game is the graphics. They just really don't cut it, especially when the developers keep relabeling the game every year as if it is a new product. This is a 2009 game, you are a fool if you think there is actually such a thing as "Train Simulator 2021."
     The gameplay itself is also somewhat lacking. When you boil it down, there really isn't a whole lot to do in the game. Sometimes you just have to sit in front of the computer for two hours until you get to your destination. In other words, if you do not like trains, you will think this is one of the most boring games ever made. Even if you do like trains, this may still be boring to you. The game tries to make itself more interesting with the career scenarios where you get graded for your performances, but the scoring is often frustrating or in many cases even broken. 
    This last grievances with Train Simulator is more of personal preference than an actual problem with the game. There just isn't a whole lot of variety in the content. Most of the DLC is themed of modern day British and American trains, and I personally am not all that crazy about that kind of stuff. Why do they insist on churning out the same kind of stuff all the time when there is literally a whole other world of trains that they have ignored in the decade that this game has existed? China built and operated steam locomotives into the 90s, wouldn't that make interesting DLC? What about Mexican railroads? I mean they used a lot of American equipment that is already in the game so it wouldn't be that hard. They just aren't very creative when they choose what DLC they should make. 
   So, if you bothered reading this far, you are probably wondering why I do recommend this game. Well, it's simply because there isn't anything else quite like it. There is Train Sim World 2, but that doesn't have as much content as this and what little content it does have is pretty much DLC that this game also has. There is also Trainz, but I just don't think the driving aspect of that is as good as in this game. Trainz is better if you want to actually build routes yourself and is more mod friendly. Of course good old Microsoft Train Simulator is still around, but I don't really see that as being better than this game. Is this a good game? Well, not really. Is this the best game of its type? I would say so.

I'm changing my review of this game from a 'No' to a 'Yes' recommendation. Why? Well...

Some things from my original review have not changed. This includes the game looking pretty poorly but also running like a turd on a treadmill. On the one hand, the game engine [i]is[/i] like over a decade old, but on the other hand this is a game that is still getting new content and updates in 2021 and is, y'know, called TS2021 (name changes each year) so its very easy to leave the game with some terribly missed expectations if one doesn't do their research. 

BUT!

With lowered expectations in the graphics department, you can actually have a good time with this game[b]*[/b]

Asterisk? What asterisk? Oh, that one... Well, one's experience with this game is [i]highly[/i] dependent on the content they get to go with it. If you are not interested in buying DLC for this game, [b]do not bother with this game[/b]. If you want a train simulator with more content in the base game, go get TSW2; it looks WAY better and has a lot more to do in the base game, and Derail Valley is also highly recommended.  However, if you can reason with yourself and your wallet to occasionally get additional content for this game, then you can actually [i]really[/i] enjoy this game (wait for sales. No, seriously, [b]wait for sales[/b]. They happen fairly often and are often rather generous with discounts, and the bigger ones have a majority of the DLC on some sort of discount). But more importantly, DO YOUR RESEARCH when buying DLC. 

I did not do my own research, and when I bought the Sherman Hill route and the Big Boy locomotive (not Smokebox's, it wasnt even close to being out yet), I was let down harder than a girl who's prom date didn't show up. That Big Boy locomotive... even for 2013 it was pretty sad, but in 2019... theres a reason I think its been removed from the store. Add to this the game gives you very little information about which graphics settings are the most influential on FPS, and I had a game that looked like garbage, a locomotive that looked like garbage, and a route that is good on its own but can be hard to appreciate when you are driving a sad excuse for a steam train at 25 fps. There was a 6 month gap between me buying and being disappointed by that content and me writing my original review for this game, and even then it had been like 3 or 4 years since I had played the game before getting that content in 2019. 

"Okay, but what has changed since then that has made you change your review, you idiot??"

RIGHT! Well, a number of months ago I bought some more content. Instead of basing my [i]purchases[/i] solely off of what had a cool name and what had cool pictures, this time I looked at the reviews for the DLC that caught my attention before buying. I bought the Montana Hi-Line and Marias Pass routes (I'm not Montana born and raised, but Montana has stolen my heart) and the FEF-3 steam locomotive from Smokebox. The routes are fantastic to drive (though the Hi-Line route does take a certain kind of crazy to haul freight on with a steam train) and like all Smokebox locomotives, the FEF-3 is totally, entirely peerless among steam trains in Train Simulator... well, until he released his Big Boy this summer. If you are a steam fan and live in the USA or at least have a fascination with American Steam, Smokebox's locomotives (especially the FEF-3 and Big Boy) are [b]must-haves[/b]. The two routes I got are also very good, but you may not like mountains/Montana, and so long as you look at the reviews for any DLC you might get, you should be able to separate the high-quality routes from the low-quality crap and still be left with plenty of DLC to pick from. 

[b]To sum up[/b], my original review for this game was thumbs down, and rightfully so because DTG is not averse to releasing utter crap for this game as paid DLC, and I was one of the unfortunate people who bought the original Big Boy DLC loco. However, I have since gotten new locos and new routes and actually really enjoy this game now. For prospective buyers, don't be overwhelmed by the extreme amount of content available for this game, rather explore it all with excitement because its very likely you'll find plenty to enjoy, but you [b]must[/b] look at the reviews for each and every DLC you think about buying, because there are some [i]real[/i] turds out there, and there are also some real old DLC out there which might not live up to your 2020's expectations. Do you research and temper your expectations to be in-line with a game engine from the 00's, and you should be able to find some content for this game that you can really enjoy

When i received my offer of employment to be a trainee suburban train driver I brought this game in hope it would give me a head start on my training. It really is not like driving a real train. There is no ATP (Automatic train protection) and the signals have no bearing in the game. My last game i went full transaction and only received a speeding alarm. I ignored every Caution signal and SPAD every Stop signal. No ATP dropping my air and no emergency stop radio calls from a panicked OCC. Truth is the Stop signal is not even relevant because there is no conflict/danger points when you do SPAD. 

Train/track physics are not really realistic because i was going over set of points well over 100km. In the real world i am train not to exceed medium speed (35km) for any points. If i was to go over a set of points at 110km my train should be in the dirt. As i progress further with my real world training this game is becoming more and more a joke. This game is clearly design for the Gunzels and not people who wish to taste what a real train feel likes. I will keep to the $2 million simulator we have a work as that is an actual sim that will not ignore SPADs. Its sad because this game could be so much more and a great training tool if the Devs actually put some efforts in the fine details. Again i really think this game is target at the Gunzels/Want to be crowd so if that not you I would not bother

I loved the game before it was taken over by DTG. Now it seems lazy and thrown together messily. The biggest problem I'm having, is, when trying to edit the awful default sounds the dlc comes with, I noticed that now instead of all the audio and railvehicles folders, there just an adobe bluepring, and an AP file. Thats's it. Nothing else. I can't edit any DLC by DTG. Why. Am I the only one with this problem?

Edit: Now 2021 and the game brushed aside by the Devs, I can say this game is decent for what it is. I did finally figure out how to edit sound files (7zip and Winrar), but of course I'm not a code master so it doesn't work time to time. It has some decent replay-ability, and I find myself going back to it like a toxic ex. The game almost never changes with each "update" but at least everything stays the same with no changes to the UI or controls, and you don't have to buy the entire game again like TSW2. I still wouldn't recommend this game purely because I hate DTG with a passion and think they're money grabbing scam artists that push out trash as fast as possible. Yes I'm talking sh*t about the Devs I don't care. Over 700 hours played I think I gained the right to do so. I love the game still because I had it back when Railworks still owned it and it was an amazing simulator with a lot of potential. I recommend the game, but not the company. Do what you will with this information.

I've owned this game for about a year now and Steam says I've played it for just over 200 hours.

I own a few DLCs, probably 5 or 6, I usually buy when they are on sale.

Overall I enjoy the game and 200+ hours of entertainment is good value for money.

However, you'll see a lot of people slating Dovetail for releasing an old game with just a few tweaks every year and it does feel a little bit dated.  Graphics and sound are really OK, the engines do look good but scenery etc doesn't look like 2021 visuals and could use a little work, overall I'd rate it 6/10 for graphics and 7/10 for the sounds.

It does feel fairly realistic, driving a train isn't simple but it is also not too hard so you can enjoy the game pretty much as soon as you start playing.  It is tricky to get a 100% score for the career scenarios so there is a challenge if you want that.

I think value for money is quite good, people complain that it would costs thousands of pounds for all the content, but you probably wouldn't live long enough to try every mission if you bought all the DLCs.

I have probably spent less than £100 in total and had over 200 hours of entertainment, that is pretty good in my book.

I will continue to play the game as I have only played 2/3 of the scenarios so far, but I would love a proper 2021 version with fully up to date visuals.

I find it kind of therapeutic playing this and it is good for escapism, when I am driving a train my problems go away for a while!

I had spent tons of hours playing Microsoft Train Simulator (MSTS) years ago before Microsoft changed the core of its OS level no support for MSTS. I tried other train sim games, but none were ever as great as that. Train Simulator 2021 isn't perfect, but I am really enjoying it. This is nice in that you can download items from the workshop, and you can even create scenarios that you can upload them to the workshop for others to play. Be sure to start in the Academy to learn how drive different types of trains and other things. 
 This was money well spent for what I desire in a train simulator.

After being caught in Everquest (Evercrack) for 2 years around the turn of the century, I spent some years with Roller Coaster Tycoon (see Youtube rct3dave.). When RCT decided to quit, I came across Sid Meyers Railroads and got some experience in Route building.

Then MSTS, which I played but didn't Build, that morphed into Train Simulator and the rest is history. 

Driving is fun but Route Creation is the reason for Train Simulator. TS2012 I think was the first one with yearly updates to TS2021.

I have had 10 years of building with no results as a result of poor Backup procedures.

Poor backup procedures are the cause of thousands of hours (I have nearly 10,000 hours of playtime) of effort being lost but the enjoyment value pays handsomely for the losses.

If you enjoyed Meccano and such, Train Simulator is for you.

Start at TS12 or the earliest available and thoroughly exhaust all you can from it and move up year by year. The Simulator does improve with time.

Have thousands of hours of fun !!!!

To start off with I love trains, so that is an automatic win for this game. Driving trains and seeing trains, this is just great. I would recommend just off those factors right there. I recommend this game for anyone that likes trains.
In my own option this is good game, I like how it plays and the range of routes and train that you can play, and for the most part I can happily play this for hours or in short sessions. Sometimes playing the same routes that I enjoy. I feel like this game has lots of replay value for me and I will probably play this for years to come.
However, I think the that the main issues for this game, is the price of routes and trains, I have only brought stuff on sale and even then it feels a bit much, even buying a few keys from other places to try keep the cost down, I feel like the prices are bit too much for me personally and I will wait for a sale to add different DLCs when they are a good price. 
Then I think the games takes itself a bit too seriously sometimes, don’t get me wrong I love a good level of challenge and have often got top scores in a few routes or just lost a few points, but there are a few levels that just are a bit too challenging and difficult for me. Which isn’t a bad thing, but there has been moments where I have quit the game because of difficulty or silly mistake, but I always keep coming back to it.
Then lastly, the bugs. Dear lord there is a few in the game, depending what routes and levels you play. Some are minor and I can look the other way. But then some are bit more noticeable, like the stations or parts of the map not loading or appearing, creating holes in the map. Then random and sudden speed changes that aren’t shown on the map at the bottom, which is going to cost you an unbelievable amount of points because you didn’t know that there has a speed change, in fact one DLC is unplayable because of that reason. It somewhat takes away from the simulation part and that real world feel.
But overall, I just love this game and with recent world events, so to say. It has been a fun way of seeing the world whilst not leaving the house. I think it is solid game overall, but you are going to have to put up with a few little things here and there, plus the game is quite old now so the older DLCs look a bit worse then then new ones, but they cost a lot less and they are still pretty enjoyable and playable.

After playing this for eight years, I can't recommend it.


So, upon my first runs on the sim, I was instantly hooked. Hell, I didn't even care at the time how much it was for a route. I remember being hyped for the TS2014 Update (at the time I had no idea what would become of TS). So around December 2013 (from what I can remember), RSC rebranded as DTG, and around that point, The sim began it's ever so slowly fall. At first, I didn't notice, I was too busy having fun while reading over the other players problems via the forums (i'm no longer subscribed to them as they got annoying). Around mid May 2014, I finally started to note some issues, and finally decided to give in to a negative review. The review, did NOT last very long, as when TS2015 came out, I was instantly happy to see a Class 801 (which nowadays serves no purpose, YET) and the upgraded Acela. This was the point I had met some friends who knew and had to deal with the current issues with the sim, until I started to do so as well around December 2014.

When TS2016 was announced, I was nevertheless, expecting just a update, untill I found out you had to pay for it......... I ended up dropping $38 bucks to get it to work (as my TS kept crashing when the free TS2016 update came). Other than that, it was just a rehash of TS2015. The same goes for the TS2017 update, and again in the TS2018.  Now here we are with TS2020 and this game lives on for now, although with DTG losing licenses and having to remove content one may wonder how much longer we have......

Now, enough of this nonsense, let me just cut to the chase.

One problem that REALLY annoys me is the constant dump files (when the game has crashed). The 64bit update back in TS2019 also didn't fix that.  Another problem is the amount of money for DLC, some of which are just bad. I think I've spent over $3000 on this game for bad DLC. DTG keep messing stuff up, like reusing Class 455 sounds on newer trains. Even with the newer DLC my friends have lag issues, one of mine can't even get his game working anymore, and had to go back to Run8.

If you think that's not bad, wait till you meet the TS Community. Back in the day it was just 3rd party devs, but now we have the reskinners and the freeware devs. I'm not going into detail here on how much of an issue this is becoming.

To sum it all up, make sure you have a super computer, and try to have around $100-200 during the steam sales, which is the best time to purchase DLC.

Overall, it's a 0/17. I still enjoy driving trains, but I can't recommend it due to all the flaws, which may never be fixed.

Bought this game as Swiss Edition in the summer Sale for 20 bucks.

I knew that the developers just rename ist every year after making just small improvements and therefore, that the "Train Simulator 2021" technically is a game from 2009. Therefore I didn't expect much - just a chill train game with at least realistic controls in the train cockpit. What I got was much less than this, as I saw after just somer minutes of trying it.

Controls:
You don't actually use the controls of the Dashoboard of the train but some arcade-like Hub that is layed over those controls - mainly one slider vor the level of the engine power and one for the choice between back- and forward. Don't know exactly if you could turn of this stuipid immersion-killing hub, but it didn't seem like I could.

Camera:
You can choose between various camera modes. The free roaming mode just sets the camera completely free, regardless of any collision control whatsoever. As I switched to that, I got inside the head of train driver.

Maps:
I wanted some beautiful Swiss maps. The first I tested was the Gotthard Line. The draw distance of trees was really short and there were no options to change that in a graphics menu or something. And now the biggest disappointment: the trees were just 2D-sprites. I felt like I was in a game from the early 2000s or something. I knwer expected top notch graphics from this, as the core of this game is from 2009. But I didn't expect to get reminded of early 3D graphics in computer games either. I checked other train simulators on youtube after testing this and found that the Microsoft Train Simulator from 2001 (!!) had comparable graphics to the things, I saw in this particular map. 
There may be other maps, which are better, but then I would expect the developers to hold the maps at least remotely up to date in terms of graphics considering how high the prices for those maps as DLCs are.

Al in all: I would consider this okay for 5€ or something. But not for 20€, which is already the price in sale.
This feels more like a scam for thatprice.
Therefore I asked Steam for refund now.

Wouldn't recommend TS 2021-- this is specifically the three routes that come with this "edition", the game engine is still the old Railworks it's always been with its limitations (framerate drops when loading new tiles, poor hardware utilization, bugs on bugs, etc.). 

-Clinchfield
The SD40 on the Clinchfield route is completely broken, the brakes don't work at all, let alone like they should. The sounds are very basic and rather nasty, the model is very basic (the radiator fans are there but they don't spin), the cab has nice textures but very few controls that actually work. TS has published better than this, I don't know why they chose to use this model for their "big yearly release". And being a DTG thing, there's no useful documentation at all in the readme, just the absolute basics.

The route has very little in the way of track or car sounds, you can improve this a bit with mods if you're willing to wrangle with third-party tools and text files but DTG doesn't want you messing around, they make things just difficult enough that most people will give up before they get to something simple like replacing the horn sound. It's totally possible to mod this game (and that's where the real good stuff is, lot of it for free, made by railfans who, y'know, actually care about this stuff) but you have to get through the needless obfuscation first.

It's also not a good look when DTG can't change the description of the GP7 from "GP7 Pennsy" before publishing the route. Makes it hard to say it's not shovelware. Which it totally is. I haven't run the Geep or the F7 although they're also very old, basic models. If they had expanded on these since they came out in 2012, they could deliver a much more immersive experience... seriously, just make a few more of the buttons work and redo some textures and these could be really nice to drive.

More issues-- the brake gauges in the caboose don't work (this model is recycled as well and I've seen them work properly on other routes). Some of the wheels on the freight cars aren't quite round or not centered right, which is really obvious if you're using the free cam near the ground to get a perspective like you would in real life. 

The route itself is scenic but quiet (as in there's very little in the way of sounds) and the 2D trees start very close to the track. Runs OK framerate-wise, which isn't surprising as it's, again, pretty basic. Bridges and tunnels and trees. Looks alright and makes for some nice screenshots. But you never get the sensation that you're driving a heavy freight train through the Appalachians, just that you're playing a half-finished simulation of driving a train through a forest. I bought this (on sale, mind, don't buy anything TS at full price) for this route and I was sorely disappointed. Could have been way, way better even with just a little more polish.

-Fife Circle Line

... so you put the Class 68 on the splash screen and then you only use it in two scenarios.

The bridge is well-done, but just like the Hell Gate on NYNH, I feel like they spent more time on the bridge than the rest of the route altogether. It's not a terrible route and the Class 158 is pretty good, but that's it. The Class 170 doesn't even have a passenger view. The cab textures on the 170 look awful, very few of the controls work. The Class 68 has power/dynamic on one handle and the "increase/decrease" type brakes like the Class 66, so it's a bit different and fun to learn. But you only use it in two scenarios.

-Norddeutsche Bahn

German routes, you have to know the signal system or don't run with PZB on, you'll just keep getting emergency brakes and not knowing why. You can turn this off (and it's off by default) but interacting with signals is one of the key parts of driving a real train.  Penalties for late stops are usually severe (~30s late and you lose points) and you can't make up time since 61kph in a 60 is treated like 61mph in a 60, even though 1mph is a bigger speed difference. In some cases, it seems like the timetable doesn't understand the restrictions placed on you by the signal system (where on most routes it does).

For this route, the framerate tanks frequently, frequently enough that it ruins the experience. The scenery is probably the best out of the three routes but if the route isn't playable on settings that make it look good, there's not much point. The other kicker here is if the framerate tanks while you're accelerating, you can easily end up overspeeding and losing points once the game recovers. The DMU controls are like the Hamburg S1, power/dynamic brake on one handle and air brakes on the other. The air brakes won't stop the train in the distance you think they should, so you have to learn how to use both to make the kind of stops you'll need to to keep up with the timetable. This is neat and starts to get towards the "driving a real train" feeling until the framerate tanks and ruins it, and then the game penalizes you for trying to drive too close to the timetable it wants you to drive exactly.

--

Overall this was disappointing. There have been better "Train Simulator 20XX" releases in the past, this is mostly just warmed-over content from many years ago to try and get you to buy it. Maybe worth it on sale if it's less than $20. I bought it for $20 and I felt ripped off.

As a game, TS is kind of OK if you go outside the "official" releases. Lots of 3rd party DLC to be had which is generally quite good (although usually paid), and you can make the junk DTG pushes out better if you're willing to work at it. It's the same game it's been for over a decade and the "TS2019" "TS2020" "TS2021" stuff is just a ploy to confuse people into buying it. That should tell you something about the publisher. The community is pretty good, although not as extensive as MSTS used to be. For the US, you'll want to check out Railworks America for freeware mods.

To sum it up: A few years ago, DTG's big thing was "WE ARE RAILFANS". They're not. They're cash fans. You have to search out the actual railfans (3rd party devs and the fan community) to get this game to be what it claims to. Driving the train is OK for a while but if you know anything about how railroads or trains actually work, you'll quickly be seeing the issues and wishing for better. It's even more maddening if, like me, you work on or with the real thing and know what it's supposed to do and why. DTG will not fix, patch, improve, etc., so you have to do it yourself. That being said, they're pretty much the only game going, so you don't have much choice except to buy their product at some point if you'd like to drive a train on your computer. And they know it.

Well where do I start? So I have booked well over 1,200 hrs driving, creating and sometimes pulling my hair out in Train Simulator. Without 3rd party add-ons such as Armstrong Powerhouse, then I probably would have uninstalled TS2021 a long time a go (when it was TS2018). WIth 64-bit and other key core updates, TS2021 is actually quite stable these days. 

Dovetail games seem to make their DLC's half-hearted and we (the customer) have to spend another £11.99 or so, to make their half-hearted DLC to work correctly or sound and feel more realistic. This is bonkers, no other simulator or content creators' business model would ever allow this, but what choice do we have?

If you have time and money to spend on this Simulator, then your end experience will be far better than the 'vanilla' base game. 

There are a lot of people in the community that create videos, how-to's, etc. So worth researching and looking about for any tips or hints. Join a Facebook group, too. There are a few to choose from and members are usually very helpful with any issues you may have.

As most people have noticed, the engine has been used for 11 years now, so all they do is they change the number to the year and select already made routes to uniquely combine the three routes for the game.

Pros: 
Loads of DLC's (You probably wouldn't even get through half of them)
Detail to the scenery, (It's not one of those games where the scenery looks good up close but bad when you go outside of the game bounds)
Cons: 
Same engine used for 11 YEARS now, it wasn't even called Train simulator then,
Terrible train engines on most routes (Although there is some decent or even good ones if you lucky)
Lack of realism: As expected for a early 2000's engine. The movement for the trains is unrealistic and virtually terrible. 
Passengers just disappear into the train other than walking INTO the train and sitting down in their desired seat. 

If you like buying DLC's and loco's to make the game more free and selectable, then this game is for you.
If you like Realistic and highly detailed games that can be compared to in real life, then this game is NOT for you.
Overall, the game is okay, but they need to stop advertising it making new people thinking it's new.

I'm going to recommend this title (with caution) for a few different reasons and I will go over them in detail listed below. I picked this up on Mid-Week madness for $14.00CDN, as well as the Canadian Mountain Passes  route on sale for $17.00CDN. 4 routes - one of them being insanely long for about the price of one new route. It was a good deal for me.

I came over to PC from console not long ago, with my only rail sim experience prior to this being in TSW and TSW2. I've been a lifelong fan of North American freight, having grown up in the heart on CNs steel industry in Southern Ontario. I also lived in Lake Louise, AB for multiple years and got to witness the Canadian Mountain Pass route in real life almost daily. Needless to say, I like freight and that's why I own these titles. 

Regarding a quick comparison to TSW(2), and how freight is presented - I feel much more at home here. I appreciate the complexity, the route length, the short message from dispatch at the beginning of a scenario. All of those small things that TSW lacks. I like to know whats happening and why its happening, and what I might be able to expect out on the line in terms of traffic and other important information an engineer would know. TSW is supposed to be a highly realistic recreation of locos and routes, however it always felt very empty to me. It's usually just A to B with no real information on anything you're doing. 

I'm happy to say that with TS2021, the majority of those voids are filled. Now please keep in mind this is from a strictly freight perspective with only a few hours on this title. I know its still not 100% accurate in every sense, but to me this is a huge difference. 

In terms of performance, I'm on the higher end of the medium range spec running the 64-bit version. My PC runs this title way smoother than a lot of other games despite the occasional frame drop or lag from busy areas. For me it's not as bad as the reviews but thats with a modern rig. I personally don't mind the old graphics here, simply because there is just so much more. Building and vegetation textures actually look better to me here than they did in TSW. And I do have TSW running in full ultra as well. 

TSW looks great but there just isn't as much more to it than that. Obviously TS2021 being a PC exclusive with access to the workshop, mods, third party content etc is a somewhat unfair comparison but that still does not change my view that TSW is very much confined to the limitations of Xbox and Playstation. 

I'm sure if you're reading this you're well aware of how Dovetail games operates. Everything here is locked behind DLC and transactions. I guess it just comes down to what you see as most valuable, and how you plan to use the title. In my case, I'll probably be happy with what I've purchased for some time to come. But I know for a fact how repetitive and boring it can get driving the same route/loco over and over again. At some point you're going to want to switch it up and get something new. It's just how it goes with these things unfortunately. I don't like it any more than others but at least we have somewhat frequent sales like the one that is going on at the time I'm writing this review. 

There's a lot of reasons not to pursue these titles and that's totally understandable but at the end of the day if you like trains, and you want to drive said trains, this is the place to do it.
