I have had every version of this simulator since it was first released, so I have already amassed a fair bit of DLC, and although I am a Steam era fan (and also run MSTS!), I am very biased! I like this sim, and if the asking price looks a bit steep, compare it against the cost of other forms of entertainment and the value for money factor always compares favourably.  I can't wait for the workshop and 3rd party sites (UKTS) uploads to embellish the  hours of new play I have with this version. For newcomers, I would say 'get it and prepare to be entertained', and don't worry about the apparent cost of DLC, because it takes a while to get through what you already have, and there are some pleasant surprises during the Thanksgiving, Xmas, Easter and Summer Steam sales. This version comes with  'really good' iconic routes which also feature more locos than before, with new effects in the game engine, and is arguably the best yet. The Steam workshop is busy with route mods and new scenarios, and along with 3rd party freeware and payware, the choice is now amazing. The only criticism I have of this version is the actual organisation of the front screen. I would like to be able to segregate the routes and stock into regions, so that I can easily get to particular models and routes of say the UK as opposed to have everything jumbled together.  
                               In terms of  development, which is probably a completely different aspect of the game, the tools are sometimes difficult to access. Route building using the world interface as it stands is generally made complicated, and was easier in MSTS. Track laying is over complicated and would benefit from, perhaps, a scripting tool so that some of the bad things the tool does in the world view can be edited textually. I would like to be able to lay simple track pieces the way MSTS accomplished the task. The scenery population would be helped by availability of text based macros. For track laying, a tool which could convert track plans (text or visual tools) into world view layouts would be extremely useful. I would really love to do more route building, but without some less time consuming methods, the chances of this happening are quite low. I have not got a few spare years to accomplish new routes. In addition, the modelling tools are now quite complex, so new buildings and general infrastructure take much longer to do, and the modelling tools themselves are very expensive, unless employing Blender.
                               The views leave me wondering where the sim will be in a few years time, and what I may be writing about it then.

Oh dear! I have had this game for a few years now and played it quite a bit and did enjoy it a few years ago.  I came back this week to see whether it had been updated............ My goodness, it is so badly maintained/updated and rehashed every year as a "new game" when it is not. If you want a game that is based on code from about 1990 then buy this game but do not fall for the fact it is renamed Train Simulator [insert year here] and it has anything like what you would expect in 2021. It is so laggy with mind numbingly bad graphics that will suck your CPU/graphics card out of all of its juice. I have a high end pc that easily plays todays latest games on full high graphics/resolution but cannot cope with this to any good degree.

Onto the simulator itself. Do not expect any sort of realism folks. The stations may be named but do not think that they will look like anything they should. Also, all of the scenarios are based out of peak, rush hour time so hardly any trains and so no enjoyment or challenge. The timings are all out and you will be lucky to complete them in the time they state without a penalty because they are unrealistic. The trains are the same no matter what DLC you buy they just look different on the outside. Trying to use the editor to make your own scenarios requires a degree in tediousness and about three years of your life only for it to fail. Most mods and other DLCs require you to buy a lot of other trains you do not want or need to play them and then sometimes they still crash. Loading times can be anywhere from a minute to half an hour so have a book handy!

Buy the game if you want to pretend to be a train driver [from the 1990s with little control due to the stuttering graphics] and do not mind any realism whatsoever.

I have tried a lot to get this game to work, and I have failed. There are so many bugs with this game, it ruins the experience. 
So far, the issues I have experienced are:
- Not being able to move the camera when sat in the cab. I am supposed to be able to move the camera so I can look around and interact with the controls in the cab. I have been unable to do this, and the view is fixed facing forward through the window. No matter what I do, what buttons I push on the keyboard or mouse, what game controllers I plug in, nothing works and I can not move the camera. I then have issues controlling the train, and therefore playing the game is affected. 
- Some times, the controls of the train just don't work. The accelerator, or the brake, or something else just does nothing (sometimes the accelerator wont go up, it keeps resetting to the bottom position). There is nothing to indicate why this is happening. Again, this means I can not control or move the train, and need to leave the route. This only happens with some of the routes, while other routes the controls work normally. I believe this is a bug. 
- Un-optimised. I don't have a top of the range gmaing computer, but it is a fairly good computer which runs most of mu games at high/very high graphic levels with good frame rates. TS2021 is not optimised, and runs very poorly. this is odd, considering how poor the graphics are. I've seen mobile phone games with better graphics running more smoothly than this game. 

I would get a refund on this game if I could, but I have spent so long trying to get it to work, that I can not get a refund and am stuck with it. 

Avoid this game.

TS 2021 is a mess.  Its the same game as TS 2009, just 12 years older with a new name that they add every year.  This is a good example of a good game gone bad.  The game engine and coding is really dated now.  Lots of VERY long load times (you sit forever while it loads, even for a "replay").  I have played 2021 for only 6 hours now but have had 3 game crashes in that time due to what the game called "out of memory".  If it was out of memory its due to the messed up game code...my computer has enough memory to run a small city!  I'm sure the reason they don't fix it is that they can't find anyone willing to spend a lifetime unraveling the decade of mix and match coding in this game.  It really needs to be totally re-done and actually made into a 2021 game with new engine and new graphics.  Calling it TS 2021 is probably actually pretty close to criminal.  Adding a new tree or plant to the game each year is not "updating" the game in my opinion.  So, if you don't mind super long load times and a game with bugs and crashes then by all means go ahead and buy it.  The actual game has the potential of being fun.  I won't bring up the over priced and endless downloads (oops..I guess I just did).  When you buy the game your just getting a very basic game with basic trains and routes...to get the "good stuff" you have to pay a lot more.  I really don't like what Dovetail is doing here, but I'm sure they don't care...they got me to buy it!

The engine is outdated, so if you start playing this game, you have been warned. To be honest, not recommending this game is connected to my view of DTG as a money grabbing group of train enthousiasts. I don't know another game that has DLC all over it like this game. And with Train Sim World (and Train Sim World 2), that only became worse. Gameplay is very linear, the world is dead, although the scenery isn't too bad. The mechanics are nice though and I will probably fire up the game now and then to drive around in a steam engine. The immersion is at a reasonable level for a game of this age.

If you want to start in the train simulator world, don't buy this game. It's outdated and DTG probably turned its attention to Train Sim World 2. TSW2 does not have steam engines though, and it looks like it will take a long time before they have that implemented. So if you want steam engines, go ahead, be very picky in your choices and try to wait for sales.

So, very mixed feelings, but in the end DTG should be more sensitive to criticism and less money grabbing.

I'm not what you would call a trainspotter but have ridden on quite a few for work and liked the idea of gentle driving scenarios as an alternative to FPS games. I didn't understand why there were 2 main games out there both coming from the same studio, and watching videos on comparisons didn't exactly give me answers. I have taught game development using Unreal Studio which TSW2 uses but an attractive game has no bearing on playability. I enjoyed TSW2 but noticed that some of the routes I wanted to drive on were only on TS so I waited for discounts and ended up buying TS2021 and a few lines. 

Having now played both I can say that TS2021 has a huge amount of content available. It may not be as attractively rendered as TSW2 and the gameplay seems to be a bit more in-depth on TSW2 but I've thoroughly enjoyed the routes TS2021 has to offer including the workshop add-ons which I'm just discovering. 

I'd like to hope that Dovetail do some sort of deal where updated content for lines that you may have purchased for TS2021 are available at a lower price for TSW2 as this can get very expensive with all the DLC available.

In summary TS2021 is still very relevant and enjoyable to play, just add the DLCs to your wishlist and wait for the discounts!

I remember, as a small kid in the early 60s, My great uncle was an engineer for Union Pacific. There were times he worked on the switcher in the Denver, CO yard setting the consits for runs to various destinations. We lived about 2 blocks from the yard. There were many times he allowed me to join him in the cab of the engine. I remember the excitement I felt, that even today I remember the excitement I felt. I'm hooked and love trains because of it.. I always wanted to be an engineer, but as life always throws its curves, I never followed my dream. But with Train Simulator 2001 I actually feel like I am living that dream. I love this simulator. I have tried so many others over the years, but this is the best. I just wish that the DLCs weren't so expensive...  I love the freight DLCs but wished they covered more destinations, actions and routes. Thank you for letting me live my dream even though it's on my computer. lol  Highly recommended for all! I give this simulator 5/5 stars.

Every fault  I had found earlier with Train Simulator turned out to be due to my ignorance or incompetence, such as being fooled by the sound of another train's doors closing, having the camera pointing at the wrong train, being in the rear cab waiting for the red to turn green when it already had at the front end. It really is an amazing bit of programming with so much detail. I play it on a Win 10 Desktop mainly using the mouse and a couple of keys, <Q> to quell driver alert and <space> for whistle. Just crossed the 200h mark. I thought I would give my honest opinion on this game.

You might at first be turned off by :

- Bad optimization, some routes can run better than others though. 
- 10+ years old graphics in some older routes
- The vast amount of DLC's to buy
- The lack of a '' Carreer Mode '' to get your though the game
- Bugs that can be scenario breaking in some rare occasions

You might be tempted to leave the game and never touch it again... but you might also, just like me, slowly realise everything this game does right and better than any other train sim. I mean, there is a reason why this game is still running after 10+ years on the market with the same engine.

You will never find another train sim that :

- Offers you so many possible hours of gameplay without never doing the same scenario twice. 
- Offers you over 10 000 hours of gameplay with the additions of DLC's and Workshop Mods.
- Has a modding community really active after 10+ years. Thousands of free scenarios are available and some are still comming out to this day and every day. 
- Lets you create new scenarios yourself and upload them to the Workshop for others to enjoy.
- Has a vast 3rd party Payware modding community. With some luck you might find your hometown train mapped out and ready to be added to your Train Simulator.

I really love this game for being able to play for hours and hours and never do the same scenario twice. I also enjoy Special Hunting for DLC's, the steam sales are always the best time, and may I encourage you to also do some google searching to find your favorite DLC, I have found some for under 1$. There is no reason to think this game will cost you thousands of dollars. No one buys the whole DLC list. Pick what you want to run and explore every modded scenario people have made for it. You will absolutely feel like you will be getting your money's worth of every DLC you choose to get. 

I thought this game was a scam when I saw the price of all the DLC's, but I can assure you it's a great Train Sim, even in 2021. Buy the base game, it will give you enough scenarios to get started and you can go hunting for more for free on the Workshop. 

Did I tell you I was addicted to Scenario Hunting on the Workshop? Gotta go find some more to run.. :)

Train Simulator is simply the best simulator for trains that you'll find anywhere. Yes there is lots of DLC. Do you need it all? No. Would you want it all? No. Think of the is game as a virtual train set. 

You can get routes and trains from all over the world from every imaginable era. So you'll probably have your favourite trains, eras and routes and wont be interested in anything else.

 I bought the game in a sale a few years ago just for a laugh. I had no interest in trains at all at the time and now many hours of play later im addicted to a train themed crack cocaine. 

The game play for me at least is very calming and completing routes and challenges issues a certain sense of accomplishment. Sometimes I sit for hours watching videos of trains going by on YouTube and I probably have a problem and perhaps need therapy. But the game is fun and I enjoy it. 

Over the years you'll add bits to your train set every time there's a sale, and there are lots. Also there's an editor and lots of free scenarios in the workshop. Overall... a really good sim! Room for improvements, certainly! I enjoy these types of sims, and would encourage everyone (but especially kids) to get a taste for what these jobs involve, I am a fan of the trades. I would like to see more realistic weather effects, maybe tie in with real world conditions (like Flight Sim does), or at least be able to control the types and frequencies of weather events. I would also like to see more AI while driving, like livestock in fields, or herds of wildlife. There are some small issues that I've see with scenarios not showing a change in the speed limit, which ultimately costs points as you'll be penalized for speeding in a hurry.

After giving my initial opinion in 2019, the time has come for me to give an updated opinion on Train Simulator.

For a former player of Microsoft Train Simulator (2000) and Trainz (2009), this game sure was an improvement, but as of 2021 it looks (and feels) awfuly outdated.

Graphics-wise, the game uses a completely outdated engine. It's absurd that they still slap the 29,99€ price tag on new content because, even if it's brand new content, the fact that it's built around an outdated engine makes that price tag a complete rip-off.

The DLC policy used to be a funny meme. Now it's just a sad and never-ending truth. Some routes need two items: US Loco & Assets Pack; and the European Loco & Assets Pack - which up until 2014 came with the core game. Now, if you need those DLC's, or you're lucky enough that the route comes with the needed content, or you'll need to spend an extra 13,99€ to purchase only ONE of those items.

On the content variety it's starting to get better, now that some Swiss and Australian routes are being released. But the fact that this game centers around mostly the UK, Germany and the US, when the game has a worldwide playerbase is somewhat disappointing, when you're expecting something new and DTG releases the 9999th route in the UK/Germany. There's more to Europe (and the world) than just those two countries.

The only thing that gets me hooked on this game from time to time is the fact that I'm a massive railfan. What this game should be is what Train Sim World is - but DTG decided to milk every penny out of their fans and make 2 different tittles. In doubt, just wait to see what SimRail 2021 is going to be. Right now, it's the simulator that is getting me the most hyped for some fresh air in this scene.

TLDR: 3/10

This is based on a 2007 game engine, and it really shows. It comes with all of the bugs, crashes and horrific performance you would expect when you slap 14 years of expansions on top of it. The game engine is the limitation - no matter how solid your computer's specs are, this will freeze, stutter and crash to desktop time and time again because it simply can't cope with modern hardware and it's full of rotten coding. Even when it's working properly there are severe FPS (frames per second) drops every few minutes. And the DLC is far, far too expensive, even for a hobbyist simulator like this. The graphics don't look bad for a 2007 game, but are pretty awful for 2021, particularly the lighting. There's fun to be had for railway enthusiasts, but only buy if you're happy to feel ripped off, prepared to pay >£100 for a decent amount of content and willing to spend hours sitting around while the game crashes.

Only played this game for four hours, and already don't like it. Free roam does not work, and am told by community members that DTG doesn't use it, (then why is it still in the game?) I finished a scenario in the SD40 in which I derailed the train because the speed limit went from 30 mph to 15 mph and I never saw the 15 mph signal. Being thrown 200 feet into the air while spinning was interesting. When I came back to the ranked screen, there were no global stats, or friend stats, or anything to compare my score of "0" to, just a spinning blue light chasing it's tail.

I have enjoyed playing this game for a number of years. For someone interested in railways who wants a feel of what it is like to drive trains, it is good fun. The physics isn't entirely accurate for those types of traction of which I have personal experience but it isn't bad by and large.

Some comments have focused on the cost of DLC, complaining that it costs thousands of pounds to buy it all. That complaint is laughable. Yes, there is a lot of DLC but you don't need to buy it all. The game as purchased comes with a decent amount of content. Thereafter, you should buy routes and rolling stock that appeal to you. Buying it all would be a waste of money - it is unlikely you would ever find enough time to play all of it.

Having said that, there are some negatives with this game.

I wouldn't recommend attempting to run it with a computer matching the official minimum specification. Mine was above that spec when I bought this title but it didn't perform adequately until I upgraded the graphics card. Even then, simulations still juddered regularly (with time in the simulation going much slower than real time for a few seconds) and had other strange effects on some routes until I massively increased the amount of memory and switched to SSD storage.

The biggest problem with this game in my view is Dovetail's poor quality control on the DLC they produce. If you visit the forums you will see lots of complaints about this. Far too many of the career scenarios are broken. This includes:

- scenarios where the timetable is not achievable even if there are no delays (i.e. the time allowed between timing points is insufficient to allow you to cover the distance even running at maximum line speed throughout)
- scenarios where signalling delays and the like make the timetable unachievable (e.g. a London-Oxford scenario where a signalling delay near Didcot means it is impossible to reach the next station on time)
- scenarios where the points available don't add up to the maximum the game thinks you can achieve (e.g. a scenario which thinks you can achieve 1000 points but there are only actually 996 points available)
- scenarios that don't save your score, showing that you've scored 250+250+250+250 points but making that a total of 0
- weirdly, on at least some scenarios the clock used to judge your timekeeping is different to the clock displayed, so you arrive on time (or even early) and get penalised for being late, with the log showing a substantially later arrival time than you actually achieved
- scenarios where the physics for the traction is badly wrong, leaving you woefully under-powered

A few years ago, Dovetail posted a request to the forum, asking people to tell them about broken scenarios so they could fix them. As far as I can tell, no scenarios were actually fixed.

There is a new version of this game every year. However, on the whole the new version includes little or nothing in the way of updates to the underlying product. When a new version comes out I would recommend checking out the bundled content. If it includes content you want and is cheaper than buying the individual items, go for it. If it doesn't, you might as well skip this update and wait for the next one.

So, whilst I am, on the whole, positive about this game and would recommend it to railway enthusiasts, there are some shortcomings. I wish Dovetail would fix the broken scenarios. It shouldn't be difficult.

The premise of the game is good, but the blatant relabelling of the game to be Train Sim 2021 is appalling. The game is only 32-bit and run like a slideshow on most PCs.

For being 12 years old, this game's pretty good. There are some caveats, however.

I won't pretend it doesn't have issues. Loading times are dreadful, especially if you're using newer routes with lots of trains. Third Party scenarios are worst for this as they try to base of off real life timetables.

Many of the trains also don't sound great. The BR Class 303 has no track run sounds IIRC, so it's almost completely silent everytime you take off the power.
Fortunately, many of the British trains have third party sound packs (Armstrong Powerhouse, SamT, Steam Sounds Supreme etc.) that greatly improve not just how they sound, but also how they work as a whole (at least as far as AP is concerned), so it's good to be a British railfan when playing this game.

However, there are few, if any, similar sound packs for the trains of the other main nations included in TS, so you'll be stuck with naff sounds on most of the German and American locos.

The game's vast library of DLC is often mocked, but it's not expected of you to buy literally everything on offer. Only buy what you want. Prefer the British routes and locos? Only buy the British DLC then. American railfan? There's plenty of American stuff to choose from.
The main complaint about the DLC is that it's typically quite expensive, usually £11.99 for a loco, and £24.99 for a route. The very old stuff is cheap now, but looks terrible and generally isn't worth buying anymore.

If you are a British railfan, I absolutely recommend this game, but be warned the cost of the DLC and the relevant third party sound packs can add up quickly.

well, where do i start? this game is horrendously outdated (dates back to around 2007, im pretty sure). it has glaring flaws (unoptimised and eats up ram among other things, though at least they finally made a 64-bit version), and you'll also have to fork out tons of cash on first and third party (cough cough AP) DLC if you really want to make the most out of this game

that being said if you are a huge train nerd (like me) and want a good rail-based experience on your pc then this is a pretty great game for that. in particular, the british railway network has a HUGE amount of representation in this game and it's very much catered towards enthusiasts. yes, the game can be a broken mess. yes, the quality of the content can vary wildly but theres so much support for this game, even outside of steam, and there are many third party developers who produce high quality content for this game. even DTG gets it right sometimes. and honestly, i have to say this is definitely one of the better train sims out there.

I bought this game way back in 2018, and got free "upgrades" through the years, to whatever version is current. As of the writing of this comment, it's TS2021. But to be brutally honest, nothing has changed aside from the name and some UI cleanup. Routes are still the same, content is still the same, gameplay is still the same. If you get the base game, it's very limited out of the box. Three routes are all you get and a tiny selection of locomotives and rolling stock. It's a DLC cash cow. Even one DLC pack costs as much as the game. 

I've played another train sim (Trainz) that has a much larger out-of-box experience, better content creation tools, and an enormous community with a plethora of both free and paid content. 

But if you have to have a Dovetail game, check out Train Sim World 2. It's the same price, but a better game.

This game glues me to the PC every time!😀 I had to turn down the graphical settings to make it run on this PC, but it doesn't look any different!😀 It has certain advantages over TSW2 (which I bought to drive the Bakerloo line). I will list them here in a war, and shall see who will win!😀
Q1: Is there a route builder function?
TS: Yes
TSW2: No

Q2: Is your scenario creator capable of making something that looks like a payware one?
TS: Yes
TSW2: No

Q3: Can you access workshop without ever leaving the game?
TS: Yes
TSW2: No

Q4A: Is selecting the route you want to drive quick and easy?
TS: Yes
TSW2: No

Q4B; Why?
TS: Because you can choose which route you want to drive by scrolling down the scenario list until you reach the route you want to drive.
TSW2: Because when you select a route, it takes you straight to the tutorial, even when you've already completed it.

Q5: Can you select a train to drive in some scenarios?
TS: Yes
TSW2: No

Q6: Can you explore the route as a passenger without having to be the driver and pressing 5 on the keyboard?
TS: No
TSW2: Yes

Let's count up the score: 😀😀
TS: 5 points
TSW2: 1 point

Whilst the graphics engine and memory management are clearly ancient by today's standard, overall, TS is a fantastic simulator and as an 'open' platform, there is a huge range of content and mods available to enhance the experience. It has the potential to become a hobby rather than just a game, as sites like ATS have proven; packed full of 3rd party content.  Almost all 3rd party DLC content is superior to DTG's efforts which tend to be lazy and lacklustre.  For a massive boost in immersion, check out Armstrong Powerhouse's train fleet and enhancement packs.  TS, although much older than TSW provides TrackIR support which is a must for me, whereas the newer TSW franchise does not.  I also use TS with hardware controls for things like the power and brake levers (albeit via a freeware interface that makes TS believe I own the 'Raildriver' hardware! ... rather than natively).  Again, TS's newer cousin TSW has no capability whatsoever to use hardware - it's keyboard and mouse only.

So, if you want an infinitely expandable train simulator platform, despite it's flaws, TS is an absolute must.  I have 1,117 hours on it at the time of writing!

You will often get a lot of people rating down because this can be a rather expensive game to get into. (Anymore expensive than the physical hobby)?  I can't make that decision for anyone.  All I know is how I feel about it.

You get what you pay for.  Good content.  I have no regerts on my purchases and plan more.  What is a little more tricky is the workshop.  Typical routes have DLC Route dependencies.  This can be discouraging is you don't want or have a lot to spend.  But with all due respect to DVG, they should be able to wet their beaks a little.  And it would cause them a bit of financial distress if mods became the entire game.  Just like everyone else; they are a business after all.

With all that said, it's a great sim with lots of content and more coming.  I can't wait to dig into the NE Corridor Add-on.

I didn't realize that I have never reviewed this simulator. Considering the fact that I have played this simulator for almost 4000 hours of my life at the time I am writing this, I obviously enjoy this game.

Most other simulators to me, look in a way "toyish" as in the graphics, to me, just look too fake. Either that or they fall in the spectrum of over realism, making the game too real to be fun. This simulator falls perfectly in the middle. things look real and operations are simplified, but not too much.

The downsides to this game are becoming more and more known as i have played this simulator more and more.

the main downside is the hastily made, and WAY overpriced DLC. Most, if not all DLC has a deal-breaker qwerk. most of the time is is either locomotives not having set notches of power or the most prevalent. inconsistent breaks quality. the breaks either take ages to come on or ages to release this making operations almost impossible. while i am not in the railroad industry personally to know how they work in prototype i am sure it doesn't take as much as 2 minutes for breaks to come on or off. there are many MANY other little things a veteran player will come across that make you wonder why you just spent so much on something that doesn't behave properly, or behaves so poorly it becomes unplayable, good thing is we have 3rd party developers working with steam that can create consistent DLC. 

other than DLC issues this game is great to play and is very relaxing. it is a Great platform to learn the basics of the basics of railroad operation and i would definitely recommend this simulator in the future.

The DLC can be quite expensive, but the overall game engine and system is good, and Steam Workshop adds so much more content. If you are contemplating buying an American route, I would definitely recommend the Washington DC to Baltimore route as it is the most detailed and comes with a lot of good Amtrak trains. Overall, this is a good game and if the prices were lower, it would definitely be my favorite.

I think that TS2021 is definitely got some problems, and I see why people call it a game from 2009. But honestly? The graphics are fine and they are better for low end computers (my 1050ti can run it no problem), the DLC is expensive to attract  people to them when they go on sale when the cost a few dollars (pro and con), and its like a model railway. It requires a commitment to expand, but you can still use the base game. It is accessible to most people due to the light GPU and CPU requirements, but if you like simulators you should have more than enough RAM. The other complaints about the engine and such just seems like dovetail going "it aint broke YET so we wont fix it" for too long. This is a great base game, but it is in desperate need of an engine overhaul for some parts, but I dont think TSW2 is the "better game" either. They are 2 different game appealing to 2 different groups. This is for dedicated people who look past the engine for the HUGE amount of DLC, TSW2 is the more accessible version. the DLC from TS2021 mixed with the engine from TSW2 would make a great simulator, but I would still recommend TS2021 for the dedicated.

I had to rewrite the review for this game after a 24 Hour total play time. I absolutely love trains; I have loved them since I received my first Amtrak H.O. scale train set at 7; I was hooked for life. This game is a giant train set on your PC and almost infinite in scale, do you remember that very first locomotive be it steam or diesel that you were just in love with??? This new train sim can bring you into the engineers seat of that train for a ride that you could never have imagined, even better you find new locals that you'll fall in love with like the Swiss DLC (Talk later about those lovelies) that bring you through the Swiss Alps offering spectacular views and very unique locomotives and coaches; the Swiss are not the only ones with great views many other places are absolutely outstanding, I was left in awe by some of the sights seen in the short travels I've made. 

Enough with me gushing about the great pros of this game because ALL games have CONS. This game as far as I can see is the DLC pricing. You can spend 1,000's of dollars on these things getting content and forbid you don't like what you have purchased. The only way to squeeze the most of this game is to wait for the all forgiving sales that come along here and there; you will still spend quite a bit of your hard earned dough but you will get many more DLC packages for the price of just one. 

To conclude I love this game because I love trains to the end of my days, but this one can be expensive; so be tactical in your buying of this one and you will be fine. Pick all that you like put them in your wish-list and wait for a sale. Good luck and HAPPY RAILS to YOU!!!!

What to say about Train Sim, I wish there was a maybe button. I'll start with a bit of background. I've had this game for a very very long time, it was the reason I got steam in the first place. I bought a disc for Railworks 3, Train Sim 2011, due to my own interest in the route construction and my own overall interest anyway. At the time, the game looked good, it ran on my old desktop at the time fairly well and I enjoyed just roaming and having fun. Over time, the game updated and got a fresh lick of paint every year from Dovetail. This game hasn't changed since 2009, small engine tweaks don't count.

Pros

If you do enjoy route variety, then TS as a series will probably be a good choice for you.
3rd party software from companies like Armstrong Powerhouse is top notch and getting to the peak of this poor old engine's capabilities, but they have brilliant functionality.
The community around this 12 year old game is still great and supportive, really great people.

Cons

Updates do little more than add to the every growing DLC list to fill Dovetail's pockets and change the number on the title screen.
This engine is far too old now to get anything worthwhile for any new players, it had its run back in the early 2010's where I played it most.
There are alternatives with far more features, Dovetail's own TrainSimWorld for detail, Run8 for multiplayer while holding graphics similar to this, or if you are like me and enjoy building, Garry's Mod has some amazing communities like FC&N.


I love this game I really do, I probably have more hours than stated, offline play etc. If you really want to experience a classic train sim, then go for it, but I think it's finally time for this game to really rest, there are others, do your research.

Remember, this is no negative, but a mixed.

To understand why I dislike this game, we must talk about why I like this game. This game was my childhood for the most part and for quite a while it was one of the only good-quality train games with a plethora of routes out there. If your computer/device can not handle Train Sim World/2 and you're willing to give out an arm and a leg for more content, then be my guest. 
     Now on to my dislikes about this game, D L C. The very fact that some DLC is considered worth more than the base game itself should serve as a red flag. Idk about you, but $60 for a loco and route seems quite pricey when you can get AAA games for that price. I am aware that simulators and in particular, train simulators are quite a niche market, but in my honest opinion I don't find that the routes I buy, have $40 worth of enjoyment. Even though I have near 700 hrs on this game, this is very much a relic of the past. Unless this is your only option for a train experience, knowing what I know now, I would consider other options first. Not to say you can't buy and thoroughly enjoy this game, but I would be more economically conscious before you buy anything.

EMU's example, high voltage's switch: VCB is not funtional.

2. TGIS: Train General Information System, displaying is not functioning.

3. EMU starting sequence is not available. other locomotives are the same problem.
Depends on train's manual, I know one of the EMU's initiating sequence. This is why I said this game is very casual.

Master key is set position > Checking voltage of batteries(maybe DC 100V) > Checking displaying TGIS: Train General Information System > pushing ACM(Auxiliary Air Compressor) and checking pressures of ACM > Checking all kinds of relays > Input VCB: Vaccum Circuit Breaker > Checking breaking system > Checking notch(driving throttle) > Checking security systems(Security Break, Emergency Break)......

4. Developers should consider making various scenarios.
There are many situations to be happen - external and internal matters. Too moderate.

I honestly wanted to like this one. Sadly I'm a casual gamer who just wants to drive a train and watch the world go by. Therefore I rely on the ribbon to let me know what speed my train should be going at. But once again the ribbon hasn't been play tested for this. Its really annoying to be 40 - 50 minutes into a route only to find that you're over the speed limit when the limit is posted 500m down the track and you are already decelerating. Its plagued this game for years. The Fife circle line seems OK but the others are all over the place with the limits. In the real world its easy to see a speed sign up ahead, on a pc monitor it flashes by in a split second. It isn't difficult to get the ribbon running right and I can't understand why Dovetail haven't managed to do it for years on so many lines.

If this was just tested a bit before release this would be a much more accessible game for many people.

Oh and the long wait on the Fife circle line at Haymarket is real. That was my train into work for 17 years. It was always late.

Having used TSW2020 and TSW2 for dozens of hours without problems (running on a decent gaming machine that is now turning 2 years old) I thought I'd try TS2021 alongside, for the greater flexibility and to try more routes and train types. 

The game does not run at a playable quality on this machine. I was forewarned about "lack of optimisation" and this is certainly evident. Even the flagship routes sold with TS2021 are rendered in quality more befitting a game from ten years ago, and the framerate is well below what I'd expect from a "2021" release of a game. The graphical detail is very poor compared to TSW; there's no value for me in calling up a familiar route if the route looks nothing like reality.

I appreciate that TS is an older product and that's the tradeoff you take in order to get access to a larger range of DLC, but compared with the realism and quality of TSW I don't feel that my purchase was good value for money. But this is a personal feeling that I'm sure will be different for other people, especially if they have a particular interest in one type of rolling stock.

So 74.8 hours of game play, Got to say last time I played a Train sim game was Trainz Sim 2010 engineers edition. So first off, coming from that game to this, I had to reprogram my brain for hotkeys, no problem. The physic are not the best, I know I've been in more locomotives in the USA then most railfans, but the way the engines "load" are beyond bad, you move the power handle and power right off the bat, no way of the engine loading up into the train, and the engine takes off whether you have a passenger train or a mile long coal drag. The Build tools which I got this for are alright, but buggy buggy buggy. I have a I7 10700K with a 2070 super GPU, more memory you know what to do with and every ten minutes or so the game crashes with a out of memory error even in the 64 bit version. But from the cons to the pros, I had this game for just over a month now and already 75 hours of game play, trust me you won't get bored. I really enjoy slugging it out on the mountain passes then racing along the valleys with mile or so long trains, stacks, coal, passenger, then switching it up and rushing commuters into and out of major cities on very tight timetables. So overall, if you can work around the bugs that come with this game which I am getting use to; go for it.

Its finally time to make a review of this game, and why I think its one of the worst games on Steam, and in general. Bare in mind this is coming from a player who has been playing since 2015 and has had experience in many other train simulators railway based games.

The Base Game

The base game costs £20 - £50 (on Steam), and generally includes 3 - 5 routes depending on which package you opt for. The routes on the game are extremely terrible and a waste of money, being under 50 miles, linear, and only including a few trains, For example the GWML is 50 miles and includes 2 trains (with there being 8 trains that operate on the route) and doesnt include the Heathrow express, Greenford Branch or Windsor Branch. With most others being boring and thus results in only being used a few or no times. The game engine is also terrible and leads to those with even Extremely powerful computers having random lag spikes, lower than 30FPS, and having random crashes during route building.

Route Building

With most routebuilders on this game being from the United Kingdom, this leads to many routes being based in the UK. With the United Kingdom being very densely populated this means that route builder have to spend hours and hours to make just one or two miles. With the terrible business model of this game being that of double EA this means that things like Station furniture, buildings, construction models and other assets being locked away behind unneeded paywalls. With a quote from Mr Maverick Hunter Daniel, "With these unneeded paywalls a routebuilder is being denied to have their freedom to build a semi-realistic route.".

The DLC & Third Party Content

So, the biggest problem with this game is the DLC (Be ready for a big paragraph). With this being a train simulator, there will be many different lines and trains that people will be biased to and want to drive. But, if you actually want these trains and route, you will have to fork out more than 26% of the average salary in the UK. The cost of all DLC is as near as makes no difference £7800. So for example, if you wanted to drive on my route, you would need to own: Kent High Speed (£25), South London Network (£15), London to Brighton (£15), Class 68 (£15), Town asset pack (£7), and Class 375 Blue (£5). So that is £83 for a single scenario / route. It is absolutely appalling the way that DTG treat their fans and consumers with these prices and the way they deal with criticism. But its not just DTG producing content for this game, there are other devs like AP, JT and ATS. AP are probably the worst TPCC as they pump up prices for literally zero reasoning, silence all criticism, and lie to everyone. Just Trains are somewhat decent as most of their old routes are average with Chiltern Mainline and Western Mainline being absolute trash, but their new routes and trains are pretty ok, Like Plymouth - Penzance and Sheffield - Derby (kinda). And ATS is meh, most of the content is free, but there are some paid packs and addons. Most of these are terrible and have absolutely no reason to be payware, Not to mention the ripoff Subscription thing.

The Worst Community in History

The fanboys and the regular community dont get along very well, with death threats, police warnings and alot more.
Thats all you need to know, dont get involved.

Piracy

After hearing all this (I hope) you probably dont want to buy this game, and you will probably start looking for another train simulator, here is the problem: there isnt one. As they are in a competition of one it is impossible for them to loose, they will keep keeping their prices up until people stop frantically throw their money at them like the worker at KFC when I held them at gunpoint. I would recommend pirating this game, as you end up being better off when you do. if people stop giving them money, they will listen

But aside from that. I do recommend this route. Because although it is short. It is well made, due to the involvement of CactusJuice. We owe him a huge thanks for his contribution. And hope that he will help continue an extension far beyond what we’ve been given today.

I've already sunked a good amount of hours into this and there's many great pros and one or two major flaws.

Pros: Easy to get into and understand the mechanics in a short space of time, overall graphics look pretty good and look exceptional with high res settings, super in depth game play and controls, and really fun plus addicting.

Cons. My major gripe with this sim is the add on's and lack of content within the base game. Fair enough you do get enough to sink your teeth into at the beginning. But the fact the base game is £25 with only like 6 locomotives, a few select routes and yet add on's range from £5 to over £30 is pretty criminal if you ask me. And there's like over 600 add on's. And I though EA and Rockstar was bad enough lol. I don't mind buying a few add on's every once in a while, in fact I have already which has been fun. But there's no way in hell am I paying for an add on that's priced more then the base game, and it won't be often that I will buy one either as I can't justify it.

All in all it's a great sim. But like I said the major let down is the pricing on add on's, by all means give it a try but try not to feel disappointed if you need deeper pockets then you first anticipated.

I had an older review of Train Simulator. I could've left that up if I wanted to, but I think after 300 hours of this game, a console-friendly sequel and a slightly fancier threequel, it's time to go over it again. 

[h1]Why buy this instead of Train Sim World or TSW 2?[/h1]
One look at Train Simulator will probably make you think "wow, these graphics have aged like old milk", and that's a pretty fair judgement to make, but the original Train Simulator's allure comes not from its graphics, but from its content library. While Train Sim World has stricter limits on route size (although TSW2 seems set to fix that), Train Simulator wasn't subject to quite the same restrictions - although routes still rarely exceed 90 to 100 miles in length, which is fine for most anyway. 

Train Sim World's more limited content library makes it much more gameplay-focused than Train Simulator seems at times, and that's due to the fact that the sheer amount of content on offer makes this both a game to play and a game to cultivate a collection with. Amassing a huge library of content over time is pretty easy when there's loads of official content on offer, more constantly being released, and an equally immense library of non-official stuff. Train Simulator is, then, a worse game with a better content library.

[h1]What's the content like?[/h1]
Your mileage may vary. Steam addons for Train Simulator come in 3 ranges, those being Classic (old stuff that hasn't aged well), the standard range (generally alright) and Pro (expensive and harder to use, but much more immersive). Steam content isn't just Dovetail's either - there are a few other popular developers, like Rivet (I personally haven't tried any Rivet stuff yet), Just Trains (mediocre in the sound department, great at everything else), Thompson Interactive (good routes but poor trains), and the legendary Armstrong Powerhouse (specialising in sound packs and trains, although they've made routes before). 
Most of your content will be Standard, which is fine - hell, Train Sim World's older stuff isn't much better than Standard, although more recent TSW DLC does match the TS Pro catalogue's levels of immersion. Safety systems are generally well-implemented - AWS and TPWS work well on British routes, PZB and LZB generally work well on German routes, TVM works perfectly on London - Faversham's CTRL section, and also on Marseille - Avignon, that kind of thing. Vigilance systems are often left out - although most German trains have working Sifa systems, the DSD/DVD that many real British trains have seems strangely absent unless you get something from the Pro catalogue.
Train physics are also varied in quality. Some trains accelerate absurdly fast - the DB Class 423 and BR Class 220 are examples of this (please don't torture yourself with the Dovetail 220, get the Just Trains 220 and 221 pack, pick up the AP sound pack and never put your wallet anywhere near [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/258679/Train_Simulator_CrossCountry_Class_220_Voyager_DEMU_AddOn/]this abomination of a DLC.[/url] like I did.)
Others, however, are much better. Armstrong Powerhouse's physics are top notch, and you can give them a try with their Class 90 (either in GEML livery only on Steam or in multiple liveries on their own site), or any of the enhancement packs or sound packs with physics patches on their own website. Generally, the newer a train is and the higher its range, the better its physics will be.

[h1] Okay, okay, we get it. The game is varied in quality, we know. What about the gameplay?[/h1]
Uh... bad news, this varies too. 
Pro products are basically flawless in their gameplay experience. Nearly everything is simulated, and if you're really lucky you'll get stuff like announcements (e.g on the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/896715/Train_Simulator_Frankfurt_UBahn_Route_AddOn/]Frankfurt U-Bahn[/url]) or random train faults (e.g on the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/222597/Train_Simulator_GEML_Class_90_Loco_AddOn/]GEML Class 90[/url]).
Most people won't mind standard content either - it's not bad enough to annoy you, and a lot of UK stuff can be improved with a little Armstrong Powerhouse magic. Classic content has its charm, but it's not great in terms of quality, so it's generally a bit naff if you're playing for immersion above all else. That said, there are a lot of freeware enhancement packs for classic routes if you know where to find them.
Physics are pretty good - wheel-slip, sanding, etc. Again, train acceleration and deceleration are subject to the number one rule of TS - that being YMMV - but newer content and the Pro range as a whole are both generally good in that regard. 

Also, external controller support for stuff like the Raildriver! Yes, really! You can stop foaming at the mouth about TSW not having it now!

...no? you're still mad?

...okay then. Hey, TSW 2 is due to get Raildriver support soon enough, but Train Simulator is a great companion to the Raildriver right now.

[h1]The endnote[/h1]
To summarise, Train Simulator is a worse game in most regards than Train Sim World, and that's fine. TSW was made to be both a big change for the better and a more console-friendly experience. Train Simulator is not that, and that's where its appeal lies. If you're [i]really[/i] into train simulation, you'll put up with the poor graphics and optimisation here, because when Train Simulator's capabilities are truly harnessed, it is a [i]much[/i] more immersive title than Train Sim World will likely be for a long time.

[b]DISCLAIMER[/b]: Train Simulator 2021 is [b]NOT a new product[/b], it's just a somewhat updated version of a much older train simulator. If you want something new you should look elsewhere. 

TL;DR Don't get this train simulator unless you are really desperate. 

Pros: 

As it is an older title there is a lot of content developed for it, most of it are overpriced DLCs however and not worth your money. I recommend that if you really want to play this particular simulator that you wait for sale and [u]read the reviews[/u] because a lot of the add-ons aren't even that great.

Cons:
- Graphics are pretty lackluster, it certainly does not look like a game from 2021 and that's because it isn't. This game is old and it shows.  

- Performance: Now I could potentially forgive the outdated graphics if the simulator had awesome performance. However, this simulator runs like garbage. The framerate is all over the place, going from 10-15 to sometimes 60fps on all the routes and trains I have tested so far. It's kinda ridiculous how little optimisation has been implemented in a simulator that gets a new shiny badge every single year to advertise it as a new product.  
- Bugs/Crashes: You would think that they had managed to get rid of these by now but sadly there are still bugs and crashes around to this day. 

Overall I would not recommend this outdated game to anyone.

After 5 years since my review I decided to be fairer and give it a thumbs up. It's not that I ever disliked it, just the way DTG do their business (i.e rushed and incomplete content is something that's not changed, though credit for the WCMLS route and the clear fact the dev team are very passionate about it all).

I've played this sim since it was Railworks and damn has it grown. Grown but still remains to be at times a very frustrating experience. When it all comes together though, it might be a gaming niche but as a bit of a geek it's near perfect even with it's flaws. To get to that point isn't as simple as buying TS2020 though. Or as cheap.

If you really want the true experience from the sim then be prepared to spend. A lot. It might be worthwhile in the end if you can afford it but let's just say that DTG content is often no good for anything other than a platform for other developers to create DLC to compensate for how the game should be.

Sounds, scenarios, trains, so much of what is released even now will come with generic old sound effects that to anyone serious about the sim (I doubt many who play are not rail fans IRL) will always notice. For me, the brake squeal is the one that has always stood out for me, as you come to a halt the stock audio of a train stopping is (was) immersion killing. I've heard the sound in TV and film before so no doubt just pulled from a royalty free library in the early days. Forgivable back then but now in 2020 they could have at least chucked money to one of the 3rd party devs they work with to give up a new generic sound to replace it. Why haven't they?

The eco-system surrounding TS is what keeps it going, they cut corners because in reality, they can't justify to their paymasters that it's worth spending hours at a train depot with high-end recording equipment as Armstrong Powerhouse do in their amazing packs. Between them, Just Trains and a sub to Alan Thomson Sim they all come together to create a masterpiece that still stands above TSW2 and Trainz offerings. Not bad for it's age, shame the engine doesn't handle it that well though. Even high end systems struggle still, it can only be assumed when they created the game engine they didn't expect it to ever still be in use over a decade on.

So to sum it up, if you want a simple quick and cheap experience of train driving and don't care about hours of playing it or the detail and choice of the routes close to where you live offered by spending more on top then great, I encourage anyone to give it a go as it's surprisingly enjoyable to some who wouldn't expect it.

To those like me, it most likely requires no introduction anyway, if you haven't tried this yet for whatever reason and don't mind spending many hundreds on it to make it near perfect it will be worth it. Pick up contend in sales and it's not so bad. I've spent hundreds, more likely thousands over the years and I don't regret it at all. I want a train sim with all the sights and sounds that replicate the real thing, nothing else offers that chance so i'll pay for it!

Great fun when it's working and for me, the steam routes are by far the most interesting. But it seems too easy to crash it, sometimes with out of memory errors (with 32Gb available) or 'Failed to create vertex..'. It then takes ages to restart when it does fail even with SSD drives. You have to remember to save often.
The UK semaphore signalling system is pretty unrealistic. It takes no account of a train's intended route or its direction of travel, whether actual or intended. On a bidirectional track, signals for the opposite direction to the train's travel will clear as it passes them which is horribly wrong, or signals at the exit of a siding can clear even when there is no train in the siding. If a train's orders have it terminating somewhere or changing direction there, the signals ahead will still clear even though it's not going intended to pass them. Much of the signal behaviour is inherent in the signalling system - it's basically just based on how the pointwork is set and whether the line ahead is clear. That much is reasonable but is not nearly enough to allow prototypical signalling to be simulated. All but the most basic scenarios require the tab key to be used at least once to get round problems with the signalling system. To be fair, many faults are down to the signal models and scripts supplied with a route,  Weardale and Teasdale, for example, which is a graphically excellent route, has several faults - distant arms clear even when the home (stop signal) on the same post is at danger and even two conflicting home signals on adjacent converging lines can be seen to clear at the same time. Some route creators have done some amazing work on signal scripts to try to make them realistic (e.g. Glorious Devon) but success is limited.
Overall, it's an excellent game but it needs a lot more work if it wants to be called a simulation rather than just a game.

Boring and frustrating.  I spent 10 hours on this game sitting in a cab of a train watching trees go by. Not sure why I continued to play. Career scenario is basically trying to keep the train under the speed limit which is  nearly impossible since sometimes the HUD shows a speed limit change and sometimes it doesn't. Going over the speed limit causes the train to autmatically brake while obnoxious messages showing a deduction of career points go flying by. Two different career scenarios I ended the run facing another train on the same track even though the directions did not state that I should expect a track switch. The tutorial tab in the main game menu contains nothing, not sure why it's there. Graphics are OK but not 2020 level. I''ve seen better scenery in a Half Life 2 game. I'm glad I only purchased the base game on sale that incuded addons rather than going crazy buying routes and train packages before playing the game. I'm out roughly $20+ and feel lucky.

OK, I now have over 4000  hours playing this game and my mood towards it has cooled somewhat.

The routes that made the game fun originally are still fun, but a large number of the DLC that I have bought since acquiring the game has been sub par at best.
In fact my last purchase "North London Network" almost finished me with the game, broken scenarios, missing consists and appalling physics of the locos featured.
Verifying files, re-installing the game from scratch, neither made the slightest difference to issues experienced in the game or other routes.
My computer is capable of playing any route at maximum settings, yet the broken bits still remain, and that's the bottom line, the game has atrocious quality control, routes and locos etc are rushed out without seemingly the slightest care as to whether they are fit for purpose, and when one does complain, no solution or fix is forthcoming, it's all very much a case from DTG of, oh dear, how sad, never mind.
Some notable examples of shoddy build are as follows.
Northeast Corridor, bought in good faith, never worked and is full of missing speed signs, broken consists and scenarios that can't be finished due to AI issues.
Then there are the Chinese routes, they are to sum it up, dross and unplayable.
Again with many of the German routes, missing locos, speed signs, broken scenarios and random derailments.
At present there is no real competition to the DTG game and this has allowed DTG to release the most egregious dreck and ignore the moaning customers.

The game still has its virtues and if one is careful when buying routes and reads the reviews, you can be assured of some real fun; sadly the misery and disappointment of the purchase of a poorly made route can really knock the joy out of it.

In conclusion an 8/10 for play value and 3/10 for build quality.
I'm dubious about buying further routes just in case they're cack like the ones mentioned above, or as truly abysmal as Return To Maerdy or the Chinese high speed route.

Caveat emptor as they say.

Wow I have been bamboozled. I saw some really awesome videos of ts, especially with steam locos. It seemed so realistic and the sound design was great. People seemed to be enjoying it. So I said to myself, "Fuck it." and bought the game with several of the american steam loco dlc. I get into the game and find out the models are not very well designed, the sound design is terrible (A horn/whistle continues to play like 3-5 seconds after you release it, wtf?) Not to mention the lack of content in it. I bought the game about 9 years ago with ts12 and it came with more! I looked at the videos again to see what I am missing. It turns out they are playing with modded upgraded trains, I said, oh well and tried to install them to find out that they were for 2020. 2021 changed how audio files worked and thus these mods were unusable. 

Short story, I am getting my money back. What a rip-off for such an expensive game. Honestly is there really nobody who makes a quality train sim? TS here has went to shit, Trainz is way outdated, a lot of the smaller sims are not fleshed out. Derail Valley seems to be the one beacon of hope, but it still is in the early stages of work. Honestly, I might consider making my own at this point.

I absolutely adore this game.  Good graphics, good variety (as long as you're willing to pay for it.) and lots of things to do.  You can play with more arcade style simple controls for someone who just wants to have fun, or you can play with the real cab controls for the enthusiast.  Not as realistic as Train Sim World, but still very fun.  And unlike Train Sim World, this game can have Steam Locomotives!

Only real downside, is that the game can be a huge money pit, like Train Sim World.  Standalone, the game only comes with a few routes, you have to pay for more routes and engines and DLC, which there is easily more than $1,000 of.  Choose what you want wisely, read descriptions as some DLC requires other DLC, and wait for sales.

I sometimes play this game obsessively, neglecting my friends and family, postponing or completely ignoring personal responsibilities like answering the phone, paying bills and going to work.  Train Simulator 2021 provides gamers, like myself, with a fantastic, time-consuming activity to fill your schedule once you finally stop resisting the game's persistent demands to stop playing in increments of hours, instead using the more realistic units of time, namely, weeks. Dovetail Games provides a vast catalog of highly detailed DLC, which is all moderately priced and affordable to pretty much any gamer who's name can also be found on the "Forbes 400" list of the world's wealthiest billionaires. TS:2021 has an added bonus of helping anyone interested in maximizing their efficiency and improving time-management skills, in that it will quickly and completely eliminate your previous, ineffectual behaviors that consisted of unending redundancy, and pointless, boring, repetitive, and most of all, 100% futile, daily routine spent making pointless efforts to maintain even a vague semblance of personal hygiene. When you finally eliminate these time-wasting, unproductive behaviors, you'll enjoy this game as much as I do.

Having owned this game for many, many years I have noticed one thing; you never, ever get any new content unless you're willing to pay for it.  It's shocking to see the developers have the audacity to use false advertising techniques in their "TS 2018 OUT NOW!", "TS 2019 OUT NOW!", "TS 2020 OUT NOW!", "TS 2021 OUT NOW!" then using DLC content in their promotional videos, screenshots and cover images.  I'm sure it's a kick in the teeth to anybody buying the game in 2020 to discover that the routes/locos are very limited and which have been with the game since 2013 or earlier. 
Considering I and many others purchased TS way back in the early days, one would hope that the developers would at least give something back.  But they seem like a money-grabbing, greedy bunch who care only but profit.  I'd happily see a boycott in purchases of the game for new players and DLCs for existing if that would send the message to these developers that they need to change their attitude.

I would have recommended this game back in 2012, when I first bought it. But it's now a seriously dated game, no longer worth the insane amount of money you can sink into it.

There are some things this game does very well. To this date, TS is the only game I ever played in which the bogies and wheels move and turn independently and the trains answer to the laws of physics in a realistic fashion. No damage models, but still, disregarding the signals and speed limitations does have consequences. The trains themselves are lovingly sculpted. Plus it's quite fun to drive a train, when it works like you intended.

Some things the makers/distributors could do better:
- Making sure all the needed assets are packed & tested for a release. My playthrough was plagued by missing assets disfiguring the landscapes I travelled through. This ranged anywhere from some missing overhead wire supports all the way to the entire New York station missing, leaving me to look at the underside of skyscrapers clipping through a lo-poly landscape. 
- When setting up a custom drive scenario, it would be helpful to have a map with the location names -- those location names only make sense for people who often travel there irl, anyone else has no idea what kind of journey they're planning. I often found myself sitting through those awful loading times for a trip of just a few km.
- The train selector, once filled with dlc, is extremely cluttered with different versions of the same loco or wagon scattered all over the place, thanks to the several naming conventions in use. It would be helpful if we could choose an engine or car type and [i]in a separate sub-menu[/i] select its proper version and skin.
- Some trains have special systems on board, but there's no way to learn about these in-game. You're supposed to memorize the controls for those from a pdf file buried amond the dlc files. Not my strong point, I'd rather they mapped those to the default TS functions as much as possible.
- Most importantly, this game is too outdated, especially its graphics, to still be costing this much. I already sank ~€168 in this game, so I'll only buy further addons if they become dirt cheap. And I mean that in the literal sense: cheap as dirt. For DLC to still cost €20 (or €8 at a generous discount) in 2020 is completely bonkers.

This is a fun and relistic train sim, with a lot of DLCs to keep players busy.
Edit: At this time, I have alot more with this game. I really like it, though their is some bugs, there are lots of dlcs and a large community. Check out Calediona Works and Blast Pipe Productions for some more content and reskins.

This train simulator isn't bad, but it's starting to show its age. It's not the graphics or the amount of content or anything like that. It just seems to be overall from the game play to the physics and such. This game has been out for a very long time, giving small updates each year and letting you stay up to date with the current version (unlike another train simulator series).

I feel really weird saying this, but I honestly have more fun playing the train games on Roblox than I do with this. It's very hard to pinpoint why exactly, but I do know a couple of factors are in the UI and controls. The controls are starting to feel aged and sometimes the trains feel unresponsive. Simple controls don't work for every locomotive, which is a bit weird to be honest. I prefer playing with simple controls because I kind of just want to drive a train like it's a model train, but the simple controls feel restricted in some way and just don't feel like they're letting you drive the train the way you want. Passenger services tend to be difficult even on easy challenges because sometimes your train will just decide it doesn't want to go faster on this hill. Then using the brakes to stop at a station is all over the place as when you apply the brakes the train takes a moment to even respond and then it starts slowly applying the pressure of the brakes. I know for those that like realism this is perfectly fine, but for people like myself it seems we need even simpler controls.

The UI takes up way too much room on the screen. It could very easily be reorganized so you can see your train better, especially on wider screens. I can't get close to my locomotive without the bottom half of it being cut off by the UI, but I also can't be zoomed out too far or else my camera gets pushed around by objects and terrain, forcing me to constantly adjust the camera distance, which is *very* annoying with the camera controls being on the arrow keys. The camera distance is only affected there and not by the mouse wheel, which controls the FOV. 

It's just getting strange at this point that the AAA train simulation games have these things that just ruin the game for me, yet I can keep going back to indie and roblox train games even when they lack a lot of the features of the AAA games.

This is a hard game to review. It is by far the most well supported of rail simulators. With third party support, it provides for me, the best simulation experience currently available. There are other programs out there with better graphics but as simulators go this is number 1.
Pros:
Workshop support with a vast array of free software
Third party support that often provide superb products to support this game
Extensive routes that range from the steam era to modern day.
Graphics quality varies but can be made to come up to an adequate level, especially with the latest product releases and third part enhancement software.
An extensive route and scenario building tool. External programs make this even easier.
Very good simulator that receives annual updates so far.

Cons
There are simulators with better graphics out there but this game has to support products that cover a decade or so and so will always have limitations compared to a new game.
The list of products is extensive and but there is no real support as to what products are best for you, which means a lot of searching. Also be careful as products on steam may be available via a third party and there may well be differences between them.
The products available on Steam run from the good to the bad in quality.
Bugs - this game still has its fair share.
Slow load times
Frame rates cam drop very badly in places. This can be due to poor route/scenario design or simply a transition from one tile to another.
This game is a power hog and requires some knowledge of computers to set the program parameters up correctly. There is a lot of help on line though.
Expensive - Unless you are happy with the base program and free software, expect to sink additional funds into additional routes, scenarios, locos and enhancement programs.

The limit shown under the speed will read, say, 100, I'll be going 85 and getting docked for speeding. Custom consists don't work at all without breaking the game upon load. Once had the train literally fly off the track out of nowhere (going under the speed limit on a straight section), losing about an hour of progress since I wasn't saving regularly (because why should I need to?). I have been playing Train Sim since I was 10 years old on and off, and although when I first started I had trouble running the game due to the poor specs of our family desktop and my old notebook. Times have changed though and in modern times I'm now able to play this game at high settings on a relatively standard laptop; 8th generation i5 and integrated Intel graphics. Technology has advanced quite a bit since this game came out and now most standard desktops and some more expensive standard laptops can play this game at comfortable graphics settings. Of course, a dedicated GPU would give you the best experience, but the price of such computers has recently increased quite a bit, and weren't affordable to begin with.

In terms of content, the 2013 version of the game happened to come with some of my local routes as standard (HS1), so I was happy for a while, but I quickly wanted to drive on more lines. Unfortunately, DLC for this game is quite expensive, although more recent DLC seems to be better value for money, and some older ones are going for less now. I've recently come back to this game because of the release of WCML South, which is one of my real-life favourite routes, not to mention the Pendolino is probably my favourite train of all time. For £25 it seems like a good deal considering you get 5 modern trains and over 100 miles of track; some DLC with less content goes for £30. TS is one of those games that has become much better to play later in it's lifespan than one that was at it's best in it's first few years.

Overall, in the modern day I'd recommend this game to any train nerd like me: It's easy to play yet has realistic challenges that mean you don't get bored, and a large library of DLC to choose from (although you need to be careful about spending all your life savings by accident). If playing with mouse and keyboard gets too disorganised for you, this game fully supports Xbox controllers (I use an older 360 one although I'm sure it supports Xbone too) which I find are a far better way to play the game than keyboard and mouse.

I give the modern version of this game 7/10 overall.

I feel that if you want to get Train Simulators full potential you would have to acquire DLC at some point. With that said, the DLC for this game is very hit or miss. I have played DLC that is phenomenal, but I've played DLC that is very lackluster (to say it nicely). I have enjoyed playing this game and I most likely will continue to do so, which is why I recommend this game. It has trains from all sorts of different eras and countries, allowing you to drive really all sorts of different trains. Overall I find Train Simulator to be a good game that can be enjoyable to pass time, but I do warn that Train Simulator does have its fair share of bugs.

I have spent over 30 hours trying to build basic routes, the controls/menus are extremely confusing and inefficient, each time there's a different problem that you cant find an answer to online, the game crashes losing all your progress, sometimes locomotives you place will turn invisible and become un-deletable, making your entire route useless because every time you try to use it theres an error that says "invalid consist" and forces you back into the editor, even though you cant interact with the "invalid consist". Connecting two different pieces of track is incredibly harder than it should be, sometimes turntables you place will become invisible and you have to restart the entire game. When most trains derail a message pops up instantly preventing you from seeing what happens or whats going to happen, if you want to turn that off you need to go into  every engine file and turn it off, it'll take hours to do. And i'll add that the DLC is pretty expensive so if you want to get good routes and engines you'll have to spend a lot of money, hell even on some routes if you wanna do a quick drive, you'll be unable to finish because an unchanable switch track is activated, or an AI train is blocking your path. Overall it's an 2/5 from me

These can occur at any time and make many routes or trains unplayable. Finally, in a recent post, they have accepted that this is a problem but have given no date or promises to fix it. This is a pity because when it works well it is really good and the huge variety of content (incl 3rd party content), otherwise make it, (finally) a great game. I just went from an 8 year old laptop with an Intel HD4000 graphics card and an Intel i7 processor to a brand new desktop with Nvidia RTX 2070 Super and an Intel I9-10900k processor.  I've been wanting a gaming desktop for quite sometime and I finally decided to get one that I thought was an amazing deal.  It has made a world of difference.  The graphics on this game have improved 100%.  The game play is also a lot smoother. 
 Before I couldn't see anything at night without turning on the bright lights while using the minimal settings and now I can see everything using the highest settings and low beam lights.  I can even see stars in the sky. The detail that is put into ATS is amazing.  This is by far one of my favorite driving games.  The only issue I see right now graphically with the game is the lighting on the speed limit signs will blur at night and cause some coloring issues when the lights from the truck hit the sign.  It's still legible and everything still look great.

Train simulator is a nice game for people who look for the experience of driving trains and such. 

However, about the game updates, Dovetail is a total hypocritical. Why? Because if a person buys the game in the year of 2018, for example, they only will get the game content (trains, routes, scenarios) relative to that year. Knowing this game "updates" every year, for example: TS2018 - TS2019 - TS2020 - TS2021, the only thing that changes in the game is the name and banner, nothing else. If you think every year you will get an new update of routes, trains or scenarios, im sorry but you will not. 

Dovetail games uses a unusual tatic of marketing that I consider being hypocritical: they only change your game's banner and name. If you buy the game this year you will only get the content of this year. Next year, they will add new content that you will not be able to use without paying and worse, the name and banner of your game will still change to TS2022 and you will be using the same content as TS2021.

I don't agree at all about this marketing strategie. If I buy something with a specific content I wouldn't like if someone updates my game's name and banner to TS2021 with me still using TS2020 stuff.
