Talk about a "confusopoly" DTG are just clearly trying to confuse the hell out of their customers with all this nonsense.

First of all you can't just slap a new number on your old games and claim that they are "Newly released" when they look and feel like something made a decade ago.  I understand business needs to release new products, but please try to do so in a non confusing way and make sure that if you release something as new that it is actually new - looks new, feels new, has new tech that wasn't possible before etc.  I.e. an improvement in ALL WAYS over the previous one.  Leave the old titles and DLCs as they are to be less confusing.

This game is not "New" nor is any of the over 600(!) addon packs which are all ludricrously expensive.  I would warn to stay away from any DTG products as they are all like this now, IDK who took over as their head of sales or product director but something changed a while back and they are just trying to money grab and be very confusing with their marketing strategies now.

I still have no idea what this game is, how I ended up with supposedly a "newly released" "2021" game in my library, how half the DLC says it was added in 2008 or 2013 etc.  I obviously played something in the past but now am so confused, it's even worse than when they updated Train Sim World to 2020 and messed around with all the DLCs that people had paid for, giving some for free and others not.

DTG are not getting any more of my money on any of their products until they pull the plug on this ridiculous business practice and release proper NEW titles, with proper game-engine updates and improvements worth paying for.  Why would I want to play a train sim game called "2021" with graphics and crap looking assets from 10 years ago that in total costs more than my rent for the month?  No thanks.
nice game

When this game is up and running - it's brilliant. I spend far too much time on it!!  However, there are glitches in the game that DTG will not address - such as 'memory dumps. I'm running an Intel i7, 32 gig memory, Asus P9x79 Pro mobo, nvidia gtx 1060, running Train Sim in 64bit mode - and still this problem persists. There is nothing more infuriating than starting a game - especially a scenario that has took hours to build - only to find, time and time again, the memory dumps and the whole programme has to be restarted. Microsoft say it is a DTG fault, DTG say it is a Windows fault. Either way, the two should be getting their heads together to get this sorted. Other than that, as mentioned, it is a great game-well recommended.

UPDATE: TS2021... As long as Train Simulator is supported.. I will keep supporting them with every Bundle that comes in the next years series...  Still relaxing.. You will get the new update if you buy the bundle or not.. but there is a value in buying the bundle anyway.. for the routes included.. which you will not get free..

UPDATE: Oh sweet... TS2020 has finally added some Graphic Enhancements... 

Seriously, It took me about 10 YEARS to get into this game as it collected dust mostly.... it's all falling into place now.. During the Summer sales it was well worth grabbing another bundle for the routes alone and some extra DLC... I would never suggest buying any of it at full price.. it can be relaxing and frustrating at the same time... With a good system it runs just fine in 32bit ... with some luck, the 64bit version works even better.. although my favorite DLC route does not work in 64bit without a 3rd party fix..sigh.. Dovetail, fix all your DLC to work properly with 64bit already..  I can run either or from launch.. But I prefer to stay in one or the other.. preferably the 64bit... Choo Choo...

Look, it's a good sim. The graphics are pretty good and it's quite optimised for most PCs. But I have realised this big problem:
YOU HAVE TO BUY EVERYTHING!
If you thought you can just get the game and feel like that's enough, then think again. After you have completed the scenarios that you get with the base game, it's really boring and you have no CHOICE but to buy the DLCs. Once you've finished playing THOSE DLCs, you feel like you have spent waay to much on a £25 game, so you turn to freeware 3rd party content. I was kinda surprised to find that there is a complete lack of freeware trains, so you have to find the routes that include the trains you already have. You find a route that looks quite promising, but after reading the readme file, you see that you require something like 5 EXTRA DLCs just for the AI, and there's no easy way of deleting that DLC content that you don't own in that route.
In conclusion, this had the potential of being a very moddable sim but Dovetail had to make the game not pay 2 win but PAY TO PLAY, and that's just a bit selfish of devs.

Alright. August of 2020, let's update this on my new PC. The game is pretty fun. I've finally gotten the official raildriver software to work with the game which gives the controls such as the brakes, throttle and reverser to have way better calibrations so that's fun.

The routes can very on how good they are just depending on what you buy. Personally, I've bought mainly classic scenarios (classic being old TS20XX/Railworks, not classic as in 1966) and they're pretty fun and detailed so I can only assume some of the newer routes are the same if not better.

Optimization is pretty good, I'm playing with a MSI GeForce GTX 1660 Super, an AMD Ryzen 7 3700X with D.O.C.P enabled along with 16 GB of RAM, with the settings on a mix of High/Ultra, I get 80 FPS on average with dips to 50-60 depending on the location, route, and rail vehicles which is perfectly fine for probably everyone because you're not gonna really need 144 FPS at 1440p for a simulator.

I also have to say, they've continued this game for almost 2 decades probably and are still releasing content for it unlike some other games... so, if you want a train simulator, I'd say go for this one. It has literally THOUSANDS of dollars worth of content with possibly hundreds of routes, locomotives etc. If you got the money, the patience, and optionally a RailDriver (which I do recommend) then go for this. One of the best if not THE best train sim out there.

Also, if you want to know what a RailDriver is, either go to PI Engineering's website or look up videos. It's essentially a controller, for trains. It has a Reverser, Throttle, Train Brake, Independent Brake. A horn, Sander, Bell, Alerter buttons, headlight and wiper switched along with 28 assignable buttons, a D-Pad, a half D-Pad (don't know what it's called) and a LED thing for a speedometer. It's also got speakers! Perfect for any person who likes train sims and has support for multiple different sims including Train Simulator.

After a hiatus of about 4 years following the demise of my best friend, I recently downloaded the current version of Train Sim: 2020. what a difference in the program. The foliage looks very realistic now; the whole game looks sharp and clear, and there are really a nice assortment of add on rail lines to buy. Also, all the lines now have operable scenarios since engines have been added  to  run them. The whole rail world seems to have been reworked and I find driving these scenarios to be better than earlier versions of the game. Yes, there are "errors" here and there but the experience is more realistic and the game flow is smoother. I really would recommend this game to other. Look at train cab videos on You Tube and you'll see close resemblance to the many engines and stations mirrored in real life.

I don't actually have too much to complain about this game, so much stuff in here is great compared to previous train simulator games I have played. Hell I even like the amount of DLC there is, so much content in a game is great, where you could potentially play for possibly thousands of hours and still have new content to experience. But the DLC is just so overpriced, and it's $60AU for stuff that looks like it should be more like $10. And on top of that, there seems to be very little difference between the 2014 version and this new 2020 version. I came into this game this year for the first time since 2014 expecting a bunch of new content, but the only new content seemed to be just more tutorial. And the game feels like it needs way more content in base game, like, 3 routes to play on doesn't seem like much. The old Trainz Simulator games from Auran I used to play felt like they came with more than what this does, but those games were generally worse than this in basically everything so not much competition there for me. Although I think what you get in 'base game' depends on what version you buy and when you brought it, since all of the base game content appears as DLC for me.

Don't even think about getting all of the DLC for this game. As much as it would be awesome to have all of it, the price for all of it is insane. I can make my own recording studio and record bands with professional level recordings and make money from it for less than all the DLC in this game. And to me that is just insane, that you can pursue a career such as that for less than it would to have all the content in this game. But perhaps it is better to think of the DLC here as like mods for Skyrim; it would be absurd to have every mod for that game even though most mods there are free. So of course, just get the stuff that you want. But even when getting the stuff you want, it's really overpriced, and there are things in there which cost lots of money which kinda look like they're free mods much more than paid DLC. Even with these DLC being overpriced and with me leaving a negative review, I am thinking of getting some anyway though, because I do want to get more out of this game. And that's the exact reason why having this DLC so expensive works isn't it (as well as this being a good simulator), people like me want to buy some anyway.

And also; the tutorial shows off that the game feels really realistic and has good sound design and has good quality, but then you drive outside of the tutorial and the quality of everything feels much lower. But that could just be because I'm playing content from 2014 and a tutorial which is possibly really up to date.

Other then that though, I do love this game. It's fun to play for me, in a way that I can't even explain. Driving virtual trains just feels cool. It's a type of game I loved when a kid, and I still seem to like now. I don't even mind too much that the game isn't as realistic as it could be.

I love model trains and am an avid modeler in O and N scale primarily. I am new to train simulations on computers. I just had never done that but I decided to try it out when I got a new computer this past year. I really love TS 2020. The scenarios are quite enjoyable. The controls are fairly easy to master, especially if you already know something about locomotives. The scenery is very nice too. I wish that the creative tools were a little better, but they do suffice. Being a huge Narrow Gauge fan, I do wish that there was more content in that area. Overall, TS 2020 is very well done and I am enjoying it immensely.
Its a very good game!

EDIT: As I play more, I'm beginning to realize I need to add in that if you are a perfectionist and/or simply can't tolerate some glitchy/buggy things from time to time, this game may not be for you. I'll add an explanation at the bottom of my review.

Well... This is actually an extremely fun game for someone who's a true nerd. If you're looking for jam-packed action, derailing box cars, explosions, and hijackings... Well, this ain't for you. If you're a fan of realistic sim games (especially public and commercial transportation), then this will be right up your alley. Beautiful scenery, detailed trains, incredible cab visuals (you can reach down and flip the switches, etc), great sound... Yeah, I really like this game.

It does irritate me a little that if I wanted the DLC, I'd basically have to spend 13 billion dollars. Just take a look at the list - there are countless routes and locomotives you can buy... for TONS of money. Yeah, I might buy some new routes and locos from time to time.. But I'd probably have to sell my house, cash in my 401k, empty my savings and investment accounts, and begin begging for change on the street to buy them all. It's a little absurd.

Also, the menus aren't that highly polished. It's weird. For a game with absolutely stunning visuals once you're driving, the menus look like some kind of Windows 95 reboot. That's not really a complaint... It's just weird.

The scoring system keeps things very challenging - you have to make sure you drive just right to get to your destinations on time, do everything right, etc - but don't go TOO fast, or you'll get fined for speeding! Oh, you've got to be pretty invested to get this done right... I've had it happen plenty of times where I was building up a very nice score, only to accidentally miss a lower speed zone, and boom - I've lost 100 points. And that's after like... 45 minutes of driving. (Yeah, these little runs can last a while - maybe 30 mins for a short one, over an hour for the longer ones.)

I also really enjoy the screen shots. In many of the sim games I play (like American Truck Simulator) I absolutely love taking pics of the stuff I'm driving against the background.. this one makes it pretty easy.

So yeah... If you're looking for tons of action, move along. If you really like a nice, relaxing, realistic sim... It might be worth cashing in on this one. (Although I'll be honest - I waited for it to go on sale. Having played it, though... I'd probably buy it full price.)

EDIT: Ok, so while I do really enjoy this game, as I buy content I'm realizing that what others are saying is a little bit true. I still GREATLY enjoy this game, don't get me wrong - very relaxing, very beautiful. However, there are some things that aren't 100% polished... For example, on some locos, when I honk the horn, I feel like I'm double-clicking TRAINHORN.WAV, if you know what I mean, lol.. Not entirely polished and smooth. Not a big deal to me. The one thing that DOES bug me, though, is the slightly buggy gameplay... So far, it's nothing I can't deal with, but there are certain scenarios where things happen in a slightly unfair manner, and I find myself having to "remember" these things in order to score well.

Example: Scoring is done based on how well you handle your driving. (For example, following signals/speed limits, smooth acceleration/deceleration, being on time, etc) In one scenario, I just have to 'remember' that certain things happen along the track that will dock me massive amounts of points if I don't remember those things. An example: I'm cruising along at a high speed, and see a 90MPH speed zone coming up. I begin to brake. However, if this was your first play-through, you wouldn't know that due to an upcoming track switch, you're actually going to switch to another track which has a 75MPH speed limit (rather than 90). So you're down to 90MPH when you need to be... switch tracks... and all of a sudden it's informing you that you're "speeding," since you're now well above the 75MPH speed limit. The HUD should be able to see this upcoming track switch and 'know' that you'll need to be down to 75, not 90.

It gets frustrating when you don't just 'know' these things - you'll have been carefully driving for like 45 minutes, making sure to keep everything well in line, and all of a sudden you just lose 500 points for pretty much no reason, with 10 minutes left in your drive. You go ahead and finish out the scenario, just for the fun of it, but you're telling yourself, "Ok, next time, even though it tells me to slow down to X speed, I know I'll actually have to slow down to Y speed instead."

Bugs aside, I will still play this game, and I have purchased several routes and locos while they're on sale.

Terrible graphics for a "2020" simulator. Check out Derail Valley instead; even though it has a long way to go, it already provides a much more engaging and COST-EFFECTIVE experience compared to this piece of recycled shit.

Do I recommend TS2020? Yes. 
What score would I give it? I'd personally say an 85 to an 87 out of 100. 

It works well within the constraints of its older engine and software limitations of its time while giving more sophisticated graphics and features you'd rather have in a modern simulator, all while giving you more creative freedom than many newer sims. 

If you're looking for a cheap train simulator that has the same amount of flexibility...I'd suggest OpenRails. It does most of the same things, except with a different coding language and some idiosyncracies carried over from MSTS. That being said, the price is my only major gripe about this game. However with what payware in general--or for that matter, model railroading costs these days (a half-decent HO setup costs as much as an Accucraft Ruby or a Plum Cove Boxcab these days! What is the world come to? I miss the days of Athearn Blue Boxes lining the hobby-shop shelves!) TS20xx is par for the course, only beat out by purchasing limited amounts of payware in MSTS / OR, going the all-freeware route with OpenBVE, and matched somewhat by Trainz's freeware / payware blend. 

Overall, the graphics are what you'd expect from an engine developed in the 2010s - pretty, but not Unreal. I've seen uglier (anyone else remember when cruciform trees were a thing?) so maybe I have more of an appreciation for the newer graphics. Support for normal mapping and advanced shaders also sets it apart as the most advanced of classic "big four" of simulators as well. 

The physics is close to the real thing, although steam and freight weren't exactly considerations in the model initially. This is where OpenRails runs circles around TS20xx with its meticulous steam physics and calculating slack and resistance over a long freight consist. Even then, some third-party developers like Smokebox have found ways to work around the quirks and there are freeware patches for many of the stock models. 

The vast majority of my hours are in the editor. It compares very well to actual CADD software, with the only exception being a lack a tool to create of spiral-equipped fillets without some kludging in the editor. This aside it's possible to make very detailed scenes and it has all the positives of both MSTS and Trainz, and improves on both some as well. The biggest plus is the precision of the editor, along with its WYSIWYG approach to configuring complex signal links. It also leverages its relatively modern game engine to provide more procedural functions from track to vegetation, which again is fairly advanced for the main four simulators. 

On a typical system these days, it doesn't break the memory bank. If you're running a basic laptop with an integrated GPU, this game could work at lower settings and by accepting a hit in framerate. For what it's worth, on both a typical PC and a middle-of-the-market laptop with an integrated GPU, the game still performs as well as OpenRails at the same overall settings. 

I haven't delved into the back end of the game, but at some point I'll have to because of my route-building endeavors. I can't speak as well to how to script or set up assets, but like MSTS, it seems daunting at first. Pretty much the only train simulator without a significant barrier to content creation these days is TRZ. I'll provide a follow-up to this review once I can speak to the complexity of it.

I said yes i recommend this game but, there are some things that would put people off from carrying on playing this game.

lets kick this review off with the most common complaint that i've noticed and that this game is very crashable and i can say for sure yeah it is very crashable but, I did able to decrease the amount of crashes with doing a lot of things to fix it or just driving the train a bit more carefully as i can (yes i am counting moving with doors open error that seems to happen randomly if your not careful to fix it).

1. with the game being very crashable you do have to use the steam verify a lot more then another games i've ever seen on steam as there is always 1 - 3 files that need fixing a lot but, I can play the game about 4-12 days before i have to do the steam verify to fix the game or to just keep it stable.

2. minimum memory i would say is wrong am using 4 GB but even tho i decressed the other crashes i used to get so much offen, I always still end up getting the out of memory crashs from time to time, I've tested over and over am not having any memory leaks or anything you should really play this game on 8 GB or higher, I sadly haven't been able to buy some more memory for my pc yet but, It's got to be better then what i've been playing the game on as I most likely get this out of memory crash once i've played an hour, so i only get an hour with this game before it may or may not crash on me what does get me angry when am near the end of a mission and it shuts down on me.

3. with so many DLCs for this game and very pricey, I mostly recommend you either use the in built store page in the game, even if its slow to go though like over 500 DLCs or still use the steam DLC page but, do not go to any filtters on the steam DLC page like the USA locos or other world routes why? cause if you filtter it on the steam DLC page about 35% of all the dlcs that should show, will not show for some reason idk why, but yeah when i stop going to the flitter i noticed some UK route DLCs that were not shown on the uk route filtter so yeah its best to go to the browes tab and just browers away at all the DLCs or like i said before the in game store page. I also really don't like the prices to these DLCs and with over 500 i feel the dev team are very greedy with they prices (estermated about £5000.00 to buy all the DLCs to this game if you was that mad) It should be way cheeper and i recommend you only get DLCs on sales rather then the full price if you can cause these prices are outrageous there are some that are pretty acceptable but, most are way over priced in my opinion.

4. building in this game hasn't changed much from the 2014 erea of this games history, what i feel really needs a upgrade in places and so its still hard to get the hang of building in this game, If you want to build you're own maps, Its best to watch SpacialKatana vidoes on it of the best tutorial videos on the game that i've found even if its 2014 footage like i said it hasn't changed much even the youtuber has made a playlist packed with his 2014 tutorials but, they is a thing that really puts me off from building my own lines in this game, Is there are some restrictions with building you're own station, I wanted to make a roof like the brighton station i got the walls up around the platform but, when i was trying to find roofs i found out i had no station roofs out of the DLCs i have as of right now, I still don't have any station roofs to use at all for builds you can't even use the brighton roof from the DLC  >:(  and i don't know what DLC that has some station roofs to use if there is any but yeah, you most likely be building open to the outside stations unless you're making underground stations or even tho i don't like to, you could use the pre built stations but they would have the station name on the signs and that most pre built stations you can't customise (pre built stations do not come with track they should do cause its pretty hard to get the track lined up on curved pre built stations) so yeah have that in mind if you plan to build you're own maps.

5. (the last point to make) you really got to like trains/driving them cause most of the missions are 50 mins - around hour and 15 mins just to finish one mission these are the 45-60 duration mission any above 70 duration i haven't played yet but, It will for sure take more then 50 mins - hour and 15 mins to finish them i've been very much put off by the 100-130 duration missions but, yeah there are low duration mission but not many, so you could play a short mission a bit but yeah, not much of many of them have a fast mission to do, in all the dlc i have, just don't have many low duration missions either so don't think when buying a dlc that they be many fast missions to do what i guess you could see that as a good thing when buying it. The duration rating isn't accurate for every mission so it may say it would take you a hour but it would really be around hour and 15 more minutes what feels like it just drags on and on sure not a high number but, when doing one mission for an hour and then have to go longer really does feel it drags on and on and to me gets a bit boring.

Thats it, If all of the points i pointed out seem alright to you then go ahead and buy the game if you wish cause it may have some flops but is still a pretty good train sim. :3

I actually quite enjoy the relaxing feel of driving a train sim, and the universal control option panel makes operating the different types of trains very simple.  Driving down from New Jersey to the Newark was very cool the first few times in the game.

However, the game would seem to run very poorly; I have a mid-range gaming PC, a GTX1060 6GB with 32GB Ram on an SSD, and the load times and FPS drops are really bad, sometimes going as low as 10FPS on medium settings, which it really shouldn't be considering I can run most games at around 40-50FPS on High, such as Dishonoured or even Doom. 

Dont just take my word for it, you can google "TSW2020 Low FPS" and you'll find dozens on dozens of threads about the issue dating back from 2017, youll find people with GTX 1080s getting 30FPS which is absurd.

The game itself has some content which is pretty engaging, however much of the content is locked behind a massive wall of DLC. You get about 9 trains and 4 routes, so if you're looking for a bit of fun on the side from another game or juts to start and see how you feel, its alright for that, but If you want more intensive hours, you're going to have to start to pay up for it.

Don't get me wrong, this is one of the best train simulators on the market. The game is well done, and I enjoy it. However, many things need to be fixed. Overall, the game is reasonably priced and has good graphics.  But they, as I said earlier, need to fix somethings. Here is a list of things that, in my opinion, need to be fixed, should be added:

-Check old and future routes for floating/missing objects.
-Fix the numerous amount of bugs that many people have already alerted you to.
-Don't price your locomotives and routes too high.
-Don't sell routes or locomotives that aren't finished.
-Fix the career and standard scenarios that are broken.
-Add more standard scenarios. 
-Try to bring your future locomotives to life by allowing players to interact with most of the controls in a locomotive cab.
-Add more unique sound effects to locomotives that don't have any.
-Fix some of the scenery clipping into things/objects.
-Add a voting system that will allow players to vote, or suggest, the content they want to see in the future (Or just simply put in a polling place on your website).
-Fix lighting issues.
-Fix some of the audio issues related to locomotives.
- Expand upon your route varieties. We don't have enough good South African routes. We don't have a lot of Chinese and Japanese routes. We have no Australian, New Zealand, Russian, Italian, Brazilian, Chilean, or Egyptian routes. Allowing your players to purchase a wider variety of routes and locomotives, that are well made and for a reasonable price, will draw in more people. To me, it's a win-win for both DTG and the players.
- Add more LRV (light rail vehicles) routes.
- Add a cold start option to all locomotives.
- Improve train AI.
- Please don't add the same route twice but with a different locomotive, a few miles of extra track for $40, and expect players to buy it.

As a community, we want your game to achieve greatness. If the game is doing well, then chances are, the community will be thriving. It is incredibly important to listen to us, too. We are here for a reason, and, ignoring us won't help your game. Please, listen to our suggestions, fix the bugs, add more routes from around the world. Catering to a more diverse audience will grow and expand your game. After all, we've always wanted to see more diversity in your routes.

Dated game engine, dated graphics, dated game thats release date was July 2009, game overall performs poorly on my modern PC, low fps on most routes unless on older 2012 or further back released routes (even still when having messed around a bunch with the in-game settings) you won`t get very much content when buying the base game of any edition and while an extensive collection of content is on offer through DLC for the game it comes at a hefty price especially when having an interest in multiple countries railways. Some trains have unrealistic and poor quality sounds, braking and acceleration can sometimes feel too drastic and don`t expect to be able to interact with every button, switch and lever in the trains as most are there but are not simulated.

On the positive side, there is some nice third party and community created content (freeware and payware options) which can help improve/expand on the game developers content, with additional route scenarios, route improvements, train reskins and even some more advanced stuff like RW Enhancer, sky and weather improvement packs and all kinds of stuff. Even though this game has been around for a while it still has a decently active community and playerbase. Trains are visually overall realistic to their real life counterparts. I do enjoy playing some of the older released routes that I manage to run smoothly.

(If possible) it just would be great to see this game get some major tech upgrades and improvements and some more of the bugs fixed that do exist. Even though I will continue to play this game, I can`t recommend it to you for my experience  with it and instead would recommend at least checking out the newer DTG release Train Sim World. It`s not perfect but I personally prefer it to this product.

EDIT : After the recent news that Train Sim World 2 is coming out and effectively Train Sim World 2020 will be left astray, DTG screwing the community and chasing more money, I can`t recommend TSW to anyone anymore either. In fact I won`t be recommending any DTG product and rather recommend you stay clear of their cashcow business modelling and put your money to better use. I certainly will be ...

It is a lovely game. But for the price we pay, I expeced more. I expected graphics that with a modern 2020-computer would generate more than 20 fps, blurry vision and almost impossible to see signals. I expected fully fuctional cab, and I don't mean that everything needs to be working. But the things that does work, for example cab light can be turned on - but not off. This might be a bug in the BR185, but really, tens of euro for a loco model that isn't play tested, c'mon! I also expected a tutorial, that actually tought you things that you would use when you started playing. You show us signals, but no driving examples with signals. For some signal combinations you need to know that you can pass, eventhough the "briefing" say you should call the controller to get permission - the game doesn't give you permission, nor does it punish running the red light when you waited for 5 min and didn't get clearence... Driving the 185 suddenly I get wheel slip, from nowhere. It is uphill, sure, but no rain or snow. I'm a huge fan of Train simulators. Was there for that first simulator published by Microsoft; I was there when the original Trainz rolled up. A couple of really good starts, but it doesn't seem like things advanced much from those days. For a game with 2020 in the title, it feels ten years old. 

It’s just an ugly, outdated, clunky experience. Most of the content is locked behind expensive DLC. Nothing in the base game makes me feel any of the DLC would be worth the price, because if it is graphically on par with what’s in the base game, then it’s at least a few generations old. I’m talking the xbox 360 had better quality graphics than this thing. It’s almost insulting with how bad it is, considering they’re slapping a 2020 tag on this. 

I spent a little time in the editor, trying to build a layout. It’s really bad. The whole UI design and the experience of trying to use it, is not enjoyable. Navigating around feels clunky and awkward. You don’t really get a preview of the assets to be placed, just the names, so you don’t even really know what you’re looking at. I couldn’t get any sort of main menu to come up, and I’m not sure what was up with that. I had to alt-tab to windows and force quit it, to get out of the editor. I’m sure that’s not normal, but it does help illustrator the issues with the UI and usability. A number of the items I looked at in the editor looked like they did when those original games were released. 

The game as a whole feels like the developers were trying to Weekend at Bernie’s it with the corpse of those original game sims. This game isn’t alive. It’s not 2020. It’s a dead corpse that they’re trying to paint up as if it’s still something. 

I’ve been playing a little VR train sim called Derail Valley. Graphically, it isn’t that great, but where it lacks in the pretty pixels, it makes up for it with a solid and simple gaming experience. It really highlights to me how bad this simulator is, because this game attempts to pack in so much more, but at the end of the day it’s just not fun. It’s not an easy game to engage and get into. I can recognize the depth it might give to some hardcore train fans, but it shouldn’t be a chore to get there. I feel that the people that give a game like this a positive review, are just starved for something better. I guess when all you’ve got is a dirty glass of water, and a glass of human excrement, that dirty glass of water starts to look pretty nice.  

Train simulators are a bit of a niche product, but they don’t have to be this bad and clunky. There’s plenty of fun niche games that work exceptionally well, and as Derail Valley shows, even a train simulator can be enjoyable, as niche as it might be. 

The legacy of where this game came from was a great one, but nothing about it has advanced into the modern age.

At this point, Train Simulator is only being kept alive by third party content. Most first party content, so much of what is on Steam, is pretty bad. Physics messed up, sounds crap, textures horrid, and I could go on and on and on. If you want good content, you need it from third-parties. And boy-oh-boy is it an investment. So buy this only if you are okay with spending a lot, since this is quite an expensive hobby.

I think this game is amazing. I have wanted a decent simulator for a while and I think this is great value for money. I waited for a sale (which are quite frequent) and then suddently prices went down. For example I got the game plus a few other packs (featuring routes and trains) which add on to the main game for around £45 (originally it was about £100) so for anyone moaning about price just wait for a sale and buy it then.
The controls and sounds are realistic, the routes are pretty nice and as said realistic with lots of little and minor details added as you drive along. The steam engine controls are amazing, featuring various controls such as: injectors, sanders, blower and the coal shovelling to make it truly authentic, the diesels / electric locomotives are also a pleasure to drive.
The only thing that I would say is that it can take up a large chunk of storage space and it makes your battery life a bit poor, but nethertheless providing you keep the battery charger plugged in that isnt a problem.

I hope that this review has helped you, all I can say is buy the game because to me its pretty good.

Foreword I have no choice. TSW is even worse so if i want any train game, this is it. 

This is an 11 year old game. The engine is about as efficient as an emaciated gerbil trying to pull the titanic into drydock. It runs like absolute garbage, choking any system you throw at it. You have various options for AA; FXAA FXAA MSAA FXAA SSXA to round the list about 10 deep. problem is, none of it really works worth a damn. The highest setting somewhat tames the game artifacts down, but at the cost of burning up a supercomputer in the process. So you have to scale it down and just live with it.

Graphics artifacts are galore. Flickering textures, fuzzies, shimmering, pulsating objects are the norm. They typically change with the position of the sun so it goes from epilepsy inducing madness to just annoying madness. 

The bloom is completely broken, requiring another program to buy to tame it down. whatever, just another 25$ into the pot!

The scenery rendering is what really murders this graphically. Anything further than say 300 meters becomes 1 huge single poly blob. Mountains are just blurs with color swirl. Awesome! 

Map errors are constant. Random vegetation on the tracks is normal, confused switches, wrong singnals, indusi/aws systems that do their own....  and that's with the good DLCs mind you. 

Train systems are basically non existent. Few 3rd party locos have some working screen buttons that show some info but most of it is just a blank textures starring you in the face screaming YOU WISH YOU COULD PRESS ME DONT YOU!!! Between engine limitations to code and laziness of developers, you get no systems at all! And what you get, acts as realistic as carmageddon's physics.

Onto the actual physics.. oof. Bad. Very bad. No track joins, no  track vibration except for the random slamming into some select curves (i consider it a bug as you have to overspeed to trigger it), there is nothing. The tracks are lazer etched and the rolling stock follows it with equal precision. There is no suspension at all. 0. 

Sounds are bad. Worse inside than outside.. Complete lack of immersion. Most is just random terrible loops that stutter or have unwanted noise in them. Again terrible from the inside, a little less so from the outside. 

The routes are short. Somebody said the absolute maximum hard limit is 400km, but that doesn't factor in complexity. In reality, you are looking at 120km sections AT MOST. Annoying because all the content is just little snipplets from here to there. Nothing is actually complete... Thats due to the editor being absolute horror to work with and the game engine just not liking complexity and size in general. 

Nothing is done to this game.. nothing is fixed. Each year it is rebranded as a new date and up it goes again. After all, if the name suddenly changed to train simulator 2009, would you buy it in 2020? Doubt it.

Challenging, but yet fun as you start your adventure. Go through the academy first to learn some basics, and then switch to career goals and more challenging lessons, which is even more worth while making you a better engineer.  Radio messages from the dispatcher's are entertaining as you begin to also learn the lingo. I chose my extra's package for the Alaskan Railroad which has beautiful scenery.

It's sort of a 50/50 kind of thing. You see there are a lot of pros and cons about this game. If you want a more realistic approach to a train sim, go and buy run8 Train simulator, you will get more realism out of it then you will get on this game, on the other hand, you get more beautiful scenery in this game then you get in Run8. Dont expect to buy this game and think "Oh im going to play the most realistic train simulator in the world" no, you get something pretty lack luster in my opinion. On a good note though there are some good mods for this game Ex: Searchlight simulations content. They make some pretty good locos and rolling stock that fill that realism gap. If you decide to get their (IMO) Best product the AC4400CW (Which I Believe is coming to steam soon at the time of writing this) you get some pretty good damn simulations with that loco, if you get that loco expect some pretty awesome detailed runs with the loco. Though is not made by DTG(the creators of TS2020) Which shows that they need to up their game. Apart from that you can get some pretty damn good looking routes Ex: Canadian mountain passes, Steven's pass (I dont have it because its US only which is pretty sad(On bnsf's end of course its not DTG's Fault)) And a lot more. So i suppose its all up to you whether you want to buy this game. Do note that this game has a few big bugs like unnecessary memory crashes (What do i know haha). Some derailment problems with the older trains tipping on curves, etc.
Ugly as hell and somehow buggier. Recommended.

I liked the detail, the sounds of the locomotives and the rolling stock mostly American trains and my favorite route is the Surfliner Route from Los Angeles Union Station to the Santa Fe San Diego Depot, and you can also install and download mods into the game and have different looks and different sounds to the game.

I do find most of the tracks I've purchased are somewhat short, which makes them a bit expensive in my opinion. Personally I'd like to see longer running times and longer stretches of track to make it more value for money. I don't know of any other game where you're paying virtually the price of another game for what is on average a couple of hours game play with each purchase. 
That said, if trains are your thing, it's very enjoyable if a little clunky at times. I have a pretty decent setup and it still flickers and judders at times. but not too much to ruin it.

My biggest issue by far is if something does go wrong, you're very reliant on the forum to sort it out (they're a very helpful bunch) as the company is very slow to respond to issues and not greatly helpful especially as you're likely to spending quite a bit of money on this in the long term. That and finding instructions is quite difficult and they're not very in depth when you do.

[h1]DLC cash grab. Steer clear.[/h1]

Don't mistake my 100-odd hours in this game as a positive tale. Most of them were put on in 2011 and 2012.

This game is based off an outdated physics engine, using textures that are years old, by a company with a business model that puts that of PAYDAY 2 to shame. [url=http://store.steampowered.com/dlc/24010/]Just look at all the DLC.[/url] If I foolishly press "ADD ALL TO CART"... I am left with 232 items totalling upwards of $3000. [url=http://i.imgur.com/gfm78Yo.png]I'm not joking, and here's a screen capture to prove it.[/url] [i](For the record, if you foolishly add all DLC to cart, you can clear your cart by going into Steam's settings, to 'web browser' then hitting 'delete all browser cookies.)[/i]

[b][i](Edit for clarification 2016-02-21: That screen-capture was taken during a sale and is actually a thou or so under the current price for DLC. /edit)[/i][/b]

Each new iteration, all we get are UI changes and more DLC. In order for us who bought Train Simulator 2012/2013/2014 to "upgrade" to what DTG advertises each year, you have to essentially buy it again. Guess how?

And don't get too used to the DLC you buy functioning (especially DLC routes). If a change they make breaks it... it won't be fixed unless you go in there and fuck around in the editor long enough to figure out what you need to do to fix it.

Edit 2020-05-21: 4 years later, and the price has gone up to over $10'526,17 for 585 pieces of DLC. Yeesh.

edit: after another 2 years of development the game is still full of gamebreaking bugs. The game crashes randomly when i try to minimize it. Locos stop working when i try to detach them. Switching to nearby engines function was removed for no reason. Consists can derail at 0,1 mph if left on the stock of a hill. Random FPS dropdown with no reason on my RTX 2080 ti. Listen, I love this game. I've had for as long as I've been playing video games and it has a special place in my heart. But don't but it. This game has been nickel and diming its way for about 5 years now. I know the DLC price has become a meme around video game circles but it is  a blight to anyone who plays this game. Oh whats that, you want to play on this route, well you better be willing to pay $40 BLOODY DOLLARS to play a map, that at best, has one or two issues in its route layout or scenarios. At worst, you will get a terrible route that is rivaled by the spin-offs of roblox or the old routes of TRAINZ 2006. That isnt even getting into all of the other knick knacks that you need to buy to get the full experience of a map. You will get stuck in an endless loop of buying a route, not having everything you need, paying up to $100 for everything only for the whole experience to be a buggy mess. This game desperately needs a new engine. If it isnt crashing the second I close the tab or try to get onto another bloody mission, the game chugs like the steam locomotives they sell for $20 a pop. Thats not even getting into the missions that dont work. I imagine the same people who play test these routes and give it the go ahead are the same people who kept shooting eachother in TF2's MVM play testing. If you have the money and willingness to pay hundreds of dollars in this game, go right ahead. I wont stop you. But if your strapped for cash, DONT BUY THIS GAME. I recommend the Trainz series. Specifically the older games. At least with those games they dont try to sell you something every five minutes.

Have had this game since it was released as Railworks many years ago. 

Since then it has been tweaked and upgraded to what it is today. It is a simulator and if shoot-em-ups or racing games are your thing you will tire of it very quickly.
For those of us that love railways it is a superb simulator and with such a vast range of DLC available, whatever period, country or traction types you are interested in, there will be content that appeals to you.

Those who complain that it would cost far too much to buy all the add ons are missing the point. You only buy the stuff that interests you and in terms of pounds spent per hours of play, the game offers fantastic value. 

There is also a vast range of freeware out there and since the game comes bundled with a full set of developement tools you should never run out of stuff to do.

Although it requires a reasonably high specification PC to run at its best, the age of the core game means that even those with a less than state of the art games machine will still be able to run it.

If you like trains and simulators, then I cannot recommend this game enough.

I have driven most train simulations, comparing this to others I would give it a score of 8 on a scale of 1-10. The graphics are very good although it occasionaly stutters on my machine. (Which does not really have a lot of horsepower.) The big hangup I see with this is they went a little to much into the pay for everything model of sales where many other games have a free mods / add-ons provided by the community.

Where to start. Its a very good game and worth 24.99. However the game itself, considering its 11 years old, hasnt progressed much. The biggest update within the last few years has been 64bit running of the game. Now I play, this, Euro Truck and American Truck. All 3 of these games are played at Max settings and the latter two run with next to no lags or frame rate issues. TS on the other hand constantly lags and struggles. Its very disappointing that no real progress forward has been made with TS. On top of this, it crashes often and your really limited to what locos you can put into a scenario. The bigger the route, the more assets used the less locos your able to put into a scenario before it crashes. The DLC is hit and miss, with the sounds and physics been awful 9 times out of 10. Routes are decent as well, again hit and miss. For example, DLC from third party is in a different league for both sounds and physics and they price them according whereas DTG just have a set price. 
Its disappointing, as TSW has come out, and yet DTG still haven't been able to iron out faults with this game in 11 years.

I pretty much only like freight with grades that are challenging.1 year ago I purchased from...Searchlight Simulations.........com......the UP S 40-2 pack with the "snoots". So I've played this for 113 hours so far, which I think is a testament to how much I like trains, and how much I really, really wanted this game to work.

It does. Kind of. Enough to keep suckering me in, and enough that I bought a few scenario packs in addition to the base game.

But here's the bottom line: to quote, "It is buggier than a big bug, bugging out in a dune buggy." There are scenarios that straight up crash to desktop. There are steam locomotives that randomly game over the scenario because they "ran out of water" (no it didn't. It had 1000 gallons in the tender and 76% water in the boiler). The GP38-2 brakes like it's connected to 20,000 cars. There are scenarios you can't complete because one of the instructions is the opposite of what you're supposed to do (load cars at an unloading station). There are scenarios you complete perfectly fine but then the game doesn't check off that you did it because of an error box that appears for 2 milliseconds and then disappears. The workshop module spams errors if you don't have all the necessary DLC installed, and the only way to get error boxes to stop popping up is to quit and restart. 
There are oodles of complaints in the forums. Every complaint I've listed has been noted before, years ago, and have still not been fixed. In particular, the Norfolk Southern GP38 having terrible brakes has been an issue since TS2018, and that specific scenario pack was included in TS2020 as a showcase. Why was that a good idea? Dovetail has acknowledged a few of them, but nothing seems to be done about the bugs; people seem more occupied on making more content for it instead of refining what it has.

Oh, and the graphics chug like a cottage cheese margarita. I've got a GTX1080, and it drops frames constantly, as bad as 4 FPS. 

In brief: This game has potential. It could be fun. But it needs to work. And I really really recommend spending your money somewhere else, because it doesn't look like the developer is interested in repairing their experience.

I love this game, I really do, but frankly this game for being 12 years old and still being updated is in a sorry state and has been for many years. Dovetail continually put out new content which sounds pretty alright. But over $8000 in first and second-party dlc for a game that feels like it is held together by a metaphorical shoelace is really sad to see. 

The game runs like garbage on anything less that a supercomputer and crashes more than a drunk child driving a car. 12 YEARS! and the most beneficial update to the games stability came out in 2018 in the form of the 64 bit update, which quite frankly seems to be just a placebo and a terrible one at that since the game crashes the same amount as the 32 bit version if not more. I constantly get errors related to not having enough memory despite having 16Gbs of RAM and 6Gbs of VRAM, and heaven forbid you alt+tab in fullscreen without saving your progress. The optimisation is just terrible and this game gets ONE update a year, too change the name of it (this has been the same game since 2009). The problem is only going to get worse from here unfortunately, with devs like Bossman Games putting out ultra high detail models becoming more common. 

If you asked me, i say that dovetail should drop everything and just work on making the base game experience itself better, because at this point they are riding the coattails of third-party content creators that actually make the game bearable to play. I hate to rip on something that has brought me endless joy but someone at dovetail needs to get their priorities straight before this game goes to far under.

Bottom line, do i like this game: yes, yes i do.

Would i recommend it to other railfans: yes, but only because there is no other alternative.

Should you even get it: only if you have cash to spare. everything is crazy expensive but thats understandable for reasons i wont go into here. i get the most joy out of third-party content where i know my money is going to help make their next release even better.

I've come back to the game after about a year. I'm sure glad I did. The visuals are terrific. The engine sounds are so realistic,  and the scenarios are absorbing and fun to play.
Unfortunately I get too many frustrating bugs. For DLC that has been around for years and has had lots of time for the designers to kill the bugs, they're still there. Like cockroaches running around when you don't fumigate your apartment.
Examples are derailments out of the blue and for no known reason. Another is the emergency brakes coming on suddenly, as if lightning has struck (although I've figured out finally how to start the train again). This is probably the most annoying glitch.
I would definitely recommend the game but I wish they would get rid of the bugs.
By the way, the add-ons are ridiculously expensive. I know the company has to make a profit, but wow! On the other hand, gamers are  obviously willing to pay these prices so who am i to complain?

I'm coming from Train Sim World. 
But I like TS2020 better. 

+ The weather system is much better
+ The seasons are much better
+ The lightning system on different times of the day is much better
+ The routes are longer and have more unique assets
+ The AI traffic is better and more varied and immersive
+ There are no frequent sound bugs like in TSW
+ The more expensive 3rd party locos are better than the locos in TSW
+ Big stations cause less lag in TS despite having a similar level of detail.
+ The anti-aliasing is better in TS
+ There is a passenger cam with an assigned hotkey in TS

- The normal TSW locos are much, MUCH better than the normal locos in TS
- There is no frequent scenery loading lag in TSW
- Even the best loco/wagon interiors are significantly worse than the ones in TSW

Unfortunately I cannot recommend this game. Not because of the DLC policy, as i think everyone who buys this knows the pricing - you would have to be an idiot to not see that. My thoughts are, if you are really into trains, then sure, why not by as much DLC as you like. If you don't like the DLC policy or its pricing, don't buy it. Seriously, it's not hard.

However, what is not absolutely clear when you buy this is that for a game which is marketed "2020" version, the engine is unbelievably dated and poorly optimised. The graphics (dx9) are pretty crappy, and, frankly, embarassing to look at in the year 2020. Not to mention the UI that has sections/tabs that simply don't show or do anything? If you click on those tabs it crashes the game. What is that?!

The loading stutter and wildly fluctuating framerates are very annoying and immersion breaking (e.g. I go from 120FPS down to 30FPS, and back again in the space of 5-10 sec). The anti-aliasing is utter garbage and grinds even my i7 7700k/RTX2080 down to sub 40 fps. NPC's just float around or disappear off the platforms. It's just so half-arsed.

The tutorials (the "academy") is pretty basic and lame, and it even has obvious spelling errors. It's like the developers seriously don't give a rat's knob as to what they re-label and churn out every year.

Going back to Euro Truck Sim 2/American Truck Sim - just think people, imagine how awesome a train simulator would be from SCS (the developers of ETS2/ATS) and then compare it to this cranked out trash?

Could you imagine what SCS could achieve compared to Dovetail's lame excuse for a simualator?

I am caught between the devil and the deep blue sea on Train Simulator 2020 having pondered over whether I should recommend this game or not! If there was the option to remain neutral, I would opt for that rating but as there isn't I will choose a 52% recommendation. Here is my reasoning:

Positive aspects:

1. It's fun and there are enough trains/routes on the basic game to keep you going for a few hours (or more).

2. Scenarios are often enjoyable and you'll quickly see that driving a train is more involved than just going forward.

3. The academy guides you through the train operartion, signalling, coupling and other basics you'll need to understand before completing a scenario with full points and no penalties.

4. Passenger trains and cargo trains are included yet each requires a different appoach when driving. 

5. You can drive, steam, diesel and electric trains covering different periods of time, routes and within many countries.

6. There is also the option to simply do 'Rail Fan' mode where you can observe trains passing and take pictures/screen shots, for those that enjoy that part more. Not my cup of tea though.


Negative aspects:

1. Some of the official scenarios that come with the game are bugged where you'll be penalised for speeding when even though the current line shows a higher speed. ie: on one scenario it showed a 50 speed limit but going over 30 got you penalised.

2. Occasionally you'll get an annoying siren in your cab that can't be disabled unless you save the scenario, close it down then select resume to clear it.

3. There is an insane amout of DLC's for this game which will set you back over £6500 if you wanted them all. Many simply are overpriced for what they offer imo.

4. The steam workshop offers a lot of extra content but be aware most will require certain purchased DLC which adds to your costs too.

It's you choice, like it or leave it. It would be good if the developers sorted out some of the issues and stopped focussing on releasing more expensive DLC just to line their pockets. As for better train simulators, I can't say as this is the only one I have played so far.

I would advise to only buy it on sale and wait for deals on any DLC to expand the game.

[h1]Incredibly disappointing sim.[/h1]

[2020 notes...]
So i'm editing this because Dovetail like to slap a new label on this every few years, but trust me, it is not worth a new label.
All the existing issues with no changes (again) that i can perceive.
Snow inside tunnels..???  Models with holes in them.
People walk off the platform across the tracks seemingly hovering mid air.
People spawning and de-spawning on platforms.
Signals that are missing theirs posts or supports that just float mid air.
Holes in scenery.
Nothing has really changed, same garbage from a lazy garbage developer.
[end of 2020 notes]


You’d think in 2019 and after the failure of Flight Sim World that dovetail might have learned a few lessons.
I’ll cut to the chase, here are the issues.

[*]Long loading times on fast storage & hardware.
[*]Slow and clunky menu
[*]No direct input joystick support (this is insane!)
[*]Uses TrackIR (head tracking) with no option to disable it.
[*]Incredibly clunky controls for keyboard & mouse.
[*]Graphics and visuals look > 10 years old.
[*]Boring and repetitive scenery.
[*]Extremely poorly animated people.
[*]Cars go through train crossings regardless of train crossing.
[*]Essentially looks like the previous version with a new title.
[*]Massive DLC fest, one of the worst in the industry.

From launch to jumping into the cab the load time is far to long for a mid-high spec PC with NVME SSD storage.

The big 'Fisher-Price' menus are poorly laid out and you end up clicking in all different places of the screen to get around.

I have a perfectly fine Throttle quadrant here (Thrustmaster Warthog) with 2 nice big levers and a smaller one that I’d love to map as throttle, bake and reverser, alas as with several previous versions there is not even the most rudimentary generic support for Direct Input devices.
I suspect this is to sell more of the proprietary controllers.
Problem is, as many flight sim enthusiasts custom build panels and sim pits, without direct input rail enthusiasts cannot do the same.
I’m aware there is or was some obscure, unsupported 3rd party mod that was just about impossible for me to track down and get working, to don’t comment on that.

A moment of delight when without configuration Track IR worked was ruined by not finding a way to disable it. It’s all good and well to be able to look around, but when you want to just sit in the cab and do your job without having to hold your head in a rigid position it’s annoying.

The keyboard and mouse controls are disgusting, really, they are.
No ability to fine set throttle and brakes, levers snap at certain almost random percentages.
The ability to use a scroll wheel on the levers would be greatly appreciated.
Playing this sim with a keyboard and mouse is so exhausting and cumbersome it’s insane.

The models of the engines are acceptable, but the repeated cars with the same textures over and over looks bland, would be good to see mild variation in the wear and paintwork on them, after all there isn’t a massive variety of things to simulate in a train, and the train might as well look as good as it can.
As for the surrounding environment there is a great deal of room for improvement.
Automobiles should probably stop at a train crossing… Just saying…
Animations and variety of models are extremely limited and basic in all things.
These badly need work.

Looks, feels and plays like previous versions with no changes that i can perceive.

The breadth and width of payware DLC for this is astonishing, and disgusting.
Take a moment to remember Dovetail acquired some kind of rights to develop Microsoft Flight Simulator X code into what they were going to call Flight Sim World, and essentially limiting the 3rd party addons to have to be bough/sold through their own store. Flight sim enthusiests won't put up with this and voted with their feet, and FSW died a death that could have been avoided with a different attitude.

There isn’t really any anything good to say.
I really mean no offence, but anyone who gives a positive review must have incredibly low standards.
Train enthusiasts deserve much better than this regurgitated garbage.

There are a lot of issues with Train Simulator. The developers clearly don't have a passion. This is echoed in the poor sounds of most of the rolling stock and there are silly things like the doors closing too fast or the noises not in sync. 

Graphic quality on most rolling stock (especially the Class 377) is horrific. I have had to buy sound packs for most of the rolling stock when available. 

However TS has the most routes and rolling stock out of any other Train Simulator and that is why I recommend it.

The evolution to this game is Train Sim World which has stunning graphic quality, is much more comprehensive with more driver duties and you are in first person and in ultimate control. However, there is a huge lack of routes and rolling stock and that will all take time. So for now, this the simulator to get, but get ready for Train Sim World to be the next big thing.

If you can overcome the overpricing of the DLC (which is not value for money) then this is ok. However I'd be reluctant to recommend given the amount of bugs and glitches I've encountered in the short space of time. Checking forums suggest these are common place, making some of the career scenarios unplayable or when they do work, no score or XP are given after successful completion. It's the sort of game that should be relaxing but is all too often frustrating.

The fancy looking "screenshots" of the game that roll in Steam's storefront page for this garbage mask a game with an engine and design flaws that would have been outdated a decade ago. With so many hours played, I can't give a bad review, can I.

Main advice: as a new player, browse DLC a bit, then jump to the forums, introduce yourself and ask for suggestions.

The positives:
- Fantastic variety of route types and trains. Flatlands and mountains, deserts and grasslands to lush forests, mainline rush and branchline servicing, fast to slow, steam to electric. Overwhelming focus on countries with a fair market potential. Don't buy it all, you need eternal life to play it first.
- Ranging from casual content to Pro-labeled content where you have to learn startup sequences, manage many handles, particularly steam locos.
- Ranging from simple graphics adequate for weaker computers to rather nice, but demanding ones. (If you want nigh-realism, move over to Train Sim World or very recent Trainz.)
- Since the 64 bit upgrade the game is fairly stable, hence the recent positive review trend.

Workshop is a mixed bag, it can extend your game with further scenarios and routes, but often at the expense of a purchase spiral (due to lack of filters). In which case you have enough content and don't need workshop.

There are issues with the game:
- Maintenance is minimal, even for game breaking issues. Sad when it breaks things that did work.
- Almost all DLC has some kind of issue: some are visual, but a set of US rail cars tends to disconnect and fail scenarios all too frequently. Timetables are often often impossible to meet so don't stress about it.
- Workshop tends to break the game, and the menus get slow as you add DLC (TS 2019 was good).

I've been sitting on this game since July of 2019. In the short amount of time that I've played it, it's become an interesting game. There are a wide variety of locomotives and routes (Steam, Diesel, Electric, UK, Germany, Japan, US, etc.) to choose from, ranging from all periods of locomotive history (late 19th Century to 20th Century Steam, early to modern diesel, and electric). However, these are NOT FREE. You have to buy every locomotive and route save for the very few that you get with the base game. There are over 500-some DLCs in the game currently, and the total amount for that is over $5000, with each DLC costing anywhere from $15-50 (essentially the price of a game on Steam), so let that sink in before you go dipping into your wallet. 

You can kill some time and get screenshots in the "Quick Drive" menu, and carry out objective-based runs down the line in the "Career" menu. You can also build your own railroads too, which is neat. 

If there's one issue I have with the game though, it is the lack of training that the tutorial gives you, and how the game hands out penalties. The tutorials are too short, and somewhat vague in certain scenarios, such as the stopping at stations and unloading/loading passengers tutorials. I was doing a run on the Chatham line where I had to take the Class 375 at night to pick up passengers, and each time I stopped and opened the doors and then departed not long after, I'd get an error message saying that I didn't give passengers time to align and load up, and that I should refer to said tutorials, which had me do THE EXACT SAME THING THAT I ALREADY DID. I have also been penalized a number of times for not acting on the conductor's alarm fast enough, triggering emergency brakes and making me late. 

TL;DR It's a decent game if you ignore the massive price tags, semi-poor graphics, lack of helpful info in tutorials and multiple penalties. I wouldn't make it a game that someone could play for 4-6 hours though, I'd get bored after a while.

You know, I'll forgive quite a lot in order to get good gameplay.  I'm used to buggy games from small dev teams.  I don't expect something like this to run like a Triple-A title.  But Train Simulator has opened up vast new uncharted horizons of mediocrity.

By rights this game should operate something like Digital Combat Simulator - an old free-to-play platform that's continually updated by a small team and populated with a quality mix of expensive 1st- and 3rd-party content.  Except the TS platform seems to get about 1/10th of the updating that DCS does, so the old platform just keeps getting older.  And TS isn't free-to-play, so Dovetail ought to have more resources at their disposal.  While Train Sim does have a lot more trains than DCS has planes, the quality and especially depth of most is comical in comparison.  I even get the same frame rates in both, which is outrageous given how much worse Train Sim looks.

But I'm okay with all of that.  I will deal with the 2008 graphics and the cost and the terrible performance, as long as I just get to have the experience of driving a big steam engine over the rails.  Well, after about 3 days of VERY buggy gameplay (frequent crashes, missing ground textures on all routes, etc), this game just decided not to load at all.  Freezes stone dead the second I go to launch any scenario or quick drive or free roam, or try to edit any of the above.  Basically anything besides menus.  I've spent more time now troubleshooting why it won't play, than I have actually playing.  I've re-installed it a couple times, as well as trying a bunch of potential fixes from the hoards of other people who have fought this game, and so far nothing.  Now, when/if I do get this going again, we're already at the point where it's been unacceptably unreliable.

The saddest part is that this hot mess is still the best train sim option around.  MSTS and Trainz belong in a museum between a stegosaurus skeleton and a paleolithic flint arrowhead.  TSW looks excellent graphically but has all the content and depth of your average preschool swing set.  So if you REALLY want to drive some trains and it's not one of the few in TSW, be prepared to fight tooth and nail to get this thing to work.  When it works it's legitimately really fun.  But man is it a struggle.  Consider volunteering for a vintage rail preservation group if there's one in your area - maintaining a real steam engine is probably easier than maintaining this game.

EDIT:  Dovetail's support team did manage to resolve my issue (the freezing and the missing textures).  The game was being a princess because Windows was not updated to the newest version (even though I did update it before contacting support, thanks Microsoft).  They were able to figure this out and fix the issue very quickly, and I have no complaints about their support; they greatly exceeded my expectations.  That said, this was still the only game that was sensitive about it, and everything else I've said about the old platform and poor performance and high cost remains.  I don't recommend this unless you really like trains - and I do really like trains.

I bought this when it was on offer, and wouldn't buy it at the asking price. I added a couple of add-ons to get things that were relevent to me (i.e. London & UK), but in reality you get a lot less than they make it seem as the listed DLC is misleading. It seems a bit buggy (recent example a train stops taking power with no obvious reason why, and no help from the game) especially as for me the sound often doesn't work. Additionally, there don't seem to be many scenarios at all (forcing you to buy more DLC to expand).

The worst thing about it? The academy. Instead of giving a proper tutorial such as a 10 min, start/stop, forwards/backwards, load/unload, it is all separate 5 min scenarios. So you sit and wait while it loads, to move a train about 1 mile forward and stop it (not even in a particular place, so get used to missing stations at first) - then close and load the next scenario to do the exact same but with a different train.

Maybe it's a good game when it gets going. But you'd have to be a die hard rail fan to forgive and forget enough to get something out of it, if you just fancy a game that's "a bit different" you probably will get frustrated and stop playing.

I've owned this game since the 2019 release. That version was buggy and unstable, but still playable if I had patience. Unfortunately, I've spent over  a $100 in DLC that enhanced the game and did make it enjoyable. It was fun. And then 2020 released and the game has been a total piece of sh*t ever since. The game crashes within minutes of opening the menu interface with the same error: "Out of Memory, try 64 bit... blah blah blah". I've only ever run 64 bit, because I haven't had a 32 bit system since Windows XP was mainstream. And I know it's not my system; this same system ran the 2019 edition without these "Out of Memory" errors, though unstable and somewhat playable. Running i7 6700K, 16 GB RAM, Nvidia GTX 680. What gives? 

UPDATE: 1/19/20 - Since Steam as asked me to add/revise my review...
The game is now completely unstable. Was it an update? No idea. I've run this game on multiple high end computers, with the same result. Same thing no matter what. I open the game, it runs for approx 30 seconds, doesn't matter what I'm doing, and then it will crash in one of three ways: 
1). with an "Out of Memory" error, which is nonsense
2). Complete and total lockup of the computer, forcing a manual reset
3). With a generic Windows prompt saying the program is not responding. 

UPDATE: 1/25/20 - Persistence pays off. After troubleshooting my graphics settings, PC settings, and finally this game's settings, I've concluded the problem was hidden in the Workshop  Scenarios that game lets you subscribe to. The game will crash if there is something wrong with a Workshop Scenario, ie something did not download correctly or an item supporting the scenario is missing, or the scenario is old and the recent updates of this game no longer support certain aspects of said scenario. The corruption will crash the game, but the only error that comes up is the  dreaded "Out of Memory" error, which ironically, has nothing to do with the cause of the crash, but is the best error the game can come up with to tell you there is something wrong. 
At least for me, the proper fix is to unsubscribe to all Workshop Scenarios, use the NameMyRoute.exe tool to clear anything that has missing links, and then re-subscribe to selected Workshop Scenarios one at a time and see how the game reacts. I found that one of my favorite scenarios was killing my game and was the cause of all the instability if I managed to get past the menu screens. Too bad too, because it was a fun scenario. I got this solution from the community forums. It works and the game is fun again!
Big thanks to "stevenridpath", post #69 of the "Out of Memory Crash" thread: https://steamcommunity.com/app/24010/discussions/3/1629663905414589274/?ctp=5 in the Steam Forums for pointing this out. Good job man!

This game is now enjoyable. Tune the settings of your graphics card to get out some aliasing of the graphics and the trains look great. I will even so far to to say the crash I experienced is not the fault of the TS2020 or even the TS2019 version. It is more the fault of progress. Meaning, as the game matures, certain aspects are enhanced, modified or removed. Some of these aspects may have been integral to the Workshop Scenarios created years ago and that when these aspects are different, the game's current version cannot support that scenario. I no longer blame Dovetail for this, as they are not in control of third party creators who have the utmost intent of expanding the enjoyment of this simulator. It's not a perfect setup as time points out. 
Perhaps one way to fix this is to subscribe a favorite scenario and clone it using the Build function of the game. This should update the scenario to current aspects for the game to support. I'll experiment with this and give an update later.

Yes, I'm a railway fan. I've travelled the lines behind some of the most impressive heritage and modern traction over the years. I even had a model railway once. The problem with a model railway is although they are great fun to build and collect, in this day and age the space for a decent layout is nigh impossible and you don't get the thrill of going anywhere with a model railway either. Now you can, with Train Simulator!
You get the privilege of sitting in the cab or footplate and drive some of your favourite locomotives or Multiple Unit trains. You can travel from city to city on an express or take charge of a local branch line train through the countryside. Whatever you choose, you have to follow the rules of the line, obeying speed restrictions, signals and other hazards such as coping with poor weather conditions and gradients. In some respects this will be the closest many people will come to driving a real train. This simulator doesn't disappoint, it taught me some of the disciplines of the real railway, and fired my imagination to go on to drive a real heritage train.
You can purchase some really excellent traction from all eras in time and even drive trains and travel routes that no longer exist.  Some of the add-on routes will be very familiar to some people and you really feel that you are travelling from place to place. Where will you going on your shift today?

I have a 2019 computer that had the latest graphics card, the best fiber internet service, and suddenly my system doesn't operate correctly.

My external disc drive will randomly auto-play the holiday songs of three wise men I've had in there since Christmas; Frankie, Deano, & Sammy. . . . I am not bothered by my high sense of good taste, it's the feeling that it never played whenever it felt like it. I am running virus scan as I write this review, a mild suggestion.

I can only imagine a little kid that enjoys trains, seeing this sale festival of trains getting excited they could even afford to now play the core game. I would like to show the 72 minutes of footage from the player.me recordings I had when I timed this game review, they are fragmented from the frequent fatal errors, crashes, and restarts. I have a youtube channel of the same name that I post reviews pretty much of games that I LIKE. So no, even if I could get it to upload, it would not be a positive review, it would be highlighting what I've been telegraphing to the audience. At least with Lionel's, "Double Crossing", you had fun as a family with a product that was true to it's word, as being of the Snydley Whiplash aura of..."anti-villain"? At least he makes the opera cape look good, possibly a misunderstood character that needs his own movie, about being unfairly chased by the ruthless authorities of Canada; I digress. 

 No kid should feel perplexed, or feel cheated from not being to be able to play with a toy train.

$10, $20, you can start collecting simple freight cars, many new and in the box off eBay. Maybe $25 to $50 for an engine that runs well and has been tested. I mentioned to someone else as a joke that instead of taking out a second mortgage to collect every DLC, I spent $40 for an orange and White 8030 Illinois Central. Is it a line I know anything about? No, but I liked the train and got a promised delivery of goods. You have kids? They will remember a physical toy train and the time they spent with you more than whatever this is.
