DLC Simulator Current Year.  It's an old game with new content, it shows it's age at times especially with background assets.  Turning the graphics up tends to result in Out of Memory errors, which I find hard to believe with 6GB 1660TI and 16GB of RAM (whichever memory it's complaining about, I've got lots!).  The good news is the game doesn't look much different on Medium settings anyways.

As for the game, it has crashes sometimes, bugs with the camera at times, and failing to complete scenarios if you Resume from a save which definitely removes any usefulness of having a save.  Some locos have ungodly squeals to them that kill the ears.  Everything is over priced so wait for a sale.  Also, when buying DLC make sure to READ ALL THE WORDS because most DLC requires separate DLC to work.  If had some content that didn't work for years until I bought an add-on route associated with it.  Lesson learned.

So, that's a whole bunch of complaining but why do I still recommend the game?  Well, when you buy your favorite content, and the game is running properly, it's a nice relaxing train game.  I personally find the Free Roam to be a bit boring but for some reason having scenarios makes the game a lot more interesting to me.  I definitely don't think this game is for everyone, sometimes when I'm on a long stretch of track and I have nothing to do but watch wheels go around, I begin to question how I got here, but other times I'm just relaxed and having a great time watching Steam engines come back to life.   

It helps that this is slightly cheaper than having a real life model train collection.

I've put a lot of hours into this game because of just how fun it is. This game is perfect for any railfan. If you're not really into trains, then this game may not be for you. The physics are excellent, the game looks great, the sounds (while they can vary from loco to loco) are excellent, the list just goes on. Many tend to criticize the game for the amount of DLC available, but one must looks at it this way: YOU DON'T HAVE TO BUY IT ALL. It's like a real life store, you're not expected to buy its entire stock once you walk in. Just get what you want, pay for it and leave. Not to mention there's tons of sales throughout the year so you can probably find most of them at a discounted price. Even if there isn't a DLC for you, there's a HUGE third party community who are constantly releasing re-skins, sound packs, routes, and locomotives most of which are freeware! The route builder is pretty complex and not very beginner friendly so if you're wanting to build your own stuff for the game, I suggest you look up tutorials beforehand.

In summary: If you like trains, get this. It's high quality and very detailed. There's lots of DLC content, and there's a healthy modding community filled to the brim with freeware products.

I'm not really a train geek, just never lost my childhood interest in the heavy engineering, noise, and complexity of them. Having gotten a bit bored of the excellent Euro Truck Simulator, I thought I'd finally give it a go when it came on sale. I'm comfortable with DLC, as it means I could just concentrate on the bits that interest me - specifically my train commute for 20 years from Brighton to London Bridge. 

However, 27 hours and *some* content later, I'm not a happy customer. 

Cons:
- The engine is old... very old. My PC will happily run anything you care to mention at max settings with plenty of room to spare. TS2020 is 32-bit and looks like it only supports single core - runs okay, until you get speed/weather/scenery happening simultaneously, then we get lag. I could forgive this if it were a visual feast but...
- PS2 level graphics. Some of the DLC is nicely rendered, but the overall graphics level is very poor - you can count the pixels on some of it. External scenery is low quality and repetitive
- Bugs. There's hundreds of them. Some of it silly like DRA functioning when it feels like it, some of it completely game breaking (currently, Workshop crashes the game if you've got any scenarios in it, which don't work anyway)
- Poor Sound Quality. Some locos sound great, others sound terrible. Trackside and atmospheric sounds also vary wildly. 
- DLC (apparently) can't be stitched together. Example, buy London-Brighton, add South London and Bedford-St Pancras... which gives you the pieces to create the Thameslink service from Brighton to Bedford. Except you can't... or least I've not found out how to do it. No scenario editor (unless someone points it out to me, which is arguably even worse if it is there and I have to go hunting for it)

I could go on and on. so let's just move on to the Pros;

- Quite cheap in Steam Xmas Sale
- DLC for most things you could ever want (the complaint about DLC costing thousands is a moot point - just buy what you're interested in). That said, if I wanted to make TS2020 UK edition with all the British lines and trains, it would end up being expensive. Something made worse by the apparently inability to connect the DLC into one seamless map.

That's literally it. 

It's not complete rubbish, but it is old, buggy, poorly optimised, and not worth the money even in the Sale.

If you want to haul transport around, go get Euro Truck Simulator 2. It's everything TS2020 could have been..,
Its a really good game for people who like trains

I wish I could recommend this game, but between outdated scenarios, point gains that don't match the system (Some scenarios can earn 750 points, relegating you to a silver medal even if you complete it perfectly), and game breaking bugs (random crashes rendering some scenarios literally unfinishable), I just can't.

I won't complain about the price of buying every DLC as it could be said of any simulator game. You need only buy those you are interested in, and every other week there's a great selection on sale so you can expand your selection for not a huge outlay.

By far, the worst criticism I have though, is the performance. 
Marketed as TS2020, it would be more accurate to call it TS2004, because that would better describe the graphical fidelity of most of the routes and trains available. While the textures for the train cabs and exteriors isn't horrible, it looks like they were plastered over models created 10 years ago, and just lacks the kind of fidelity or depth you'd expect from a game released in 2015, never mind one claimed to be up to expected standards in 2020, and that's not to mention the front facing sprites used for almost every piece of background scenery, the ugly and blurry buildings, and the passengers? Don't even get me started...
Despite looking at least a decade old though, it will still run like ass, no matter how powerful your PC. I have a 390X and a Ryzen5 1600 and even with details reduced somewhat to make it more playable, I will still get FPS drops from 70~80, to 15~20, for seconds at a time.

If you like trains and have always wanted to drive one, this is the most realistic modern simulator in my opinion with a wide variety of routes and trains. (that all cost extra) That being said, Dovetail consistently implement insane and unjustified designs and restrictions that just prove to frustrate the player. The controls are set. You can not reconfigure them. At all. It is undoubtedly my biggest complaint about the game but I could go on. Driver aids are over sized / designed with constantly changing scales of distance (depending how fast you're travelling), you can not customize them or make them smaller or crop out all the useless information you don't need. The game is poorly optimised, my old rig struggled with a GTX 650 my new rig has no problems but might wanna think twice if you're buying the game for a kid to use on a more basic family computer. What really makes me angry is Microsoft Train Simulator (about 20 years old) had NONE of these problems. Dovetail bought the franchise from Microsoft reversed the default throttle up and down buttons and then decided not to let the player ever remap them. They've had YEARS to implement this very basic feature and haven't, they just churn out a steady stream of expensive DLC. The DLC quality varies massively. Just Trains develop the best ones IMO, dovetail inhouse content you never know if you're going to get a real labour of love or a rushed out weekend project. For all my many (many) complaints, there is no other game that simulates such a wide variety of the worlds railroads at such high levels of realism (on most routes, there are some truly shockingly terrible routes) if you've got a decent gaming rig and want to have a go driving a train, I have to recommend this game if only for lack of alternatives. (If anyone from Dovetail sees this REMAPABLE CONTROLS PLEEEEEEEEEASE D IS ACCELERATE FROM MSTS DAYS A IS DECELERATE LET ME CHANGE THEM ROUND LET ME CHANGE MY CONTROLS LET ME MAP BUTTONS FOR THE DOORS ON THE MUNICH LINE EXPANSION LET ME CHANGE AWS TO SPACEBAR AND HORN TO TAB LET ME DRIVE MY TRAIN MY WAY)

whether it's driving a loaded intermodal train up the Marias pass, or driving a high speed passenger train in China, Railworks is a decent game however it does have it's quirks. Here are some Pros and Cons because i'm too lazy to go into detail.

Pros:
LOTS of content, 7,000$ worth of content
Graphics are decent
Reflections and shadows look great.
Many different reigons and countries to drive in.
Trains are detailed and look good.
Fun and Addicting

Now for the Cons
Game Crashes a LOT even with the 64 bit launcher
Certain Weather settings on certain routes crash the game
Some routes are buggy
Trains fly up in the air if you crash sometimes
Sounds for most locomotives are TERRIBLE (UP challenger,Dash 9,Big Boy)
Rolling stock  sounds are pretty bad  but there are exceptions (NS coal district, Sherman hill)
Editor is hard to use and more than likely will require you to google how to use it

That concludes my review of railworks. Overall i'd give it a 6/10. That sounds bad but for a game like this that is buggy and has many quirks. It's fun and addicting and a relaxing game.

Certainly not a recommended game, the poor optimization of the game and costs of DLC exceeding $7,000 USD make this game a prime example of a game developed for the sole purpose of making money, there is no customer satisfaction in it when to enjoy the game even remotely you have to invest at least $200 in DLC to have some variety. 

The poor optimization of this game also curses this game, most times not allowing the user to minimize the game while playing otherwise it will lock up the entire computer and force you to restart it. I run a Ryzen 5 2600 3.4 Ghz CPU, 2 x 8 GB Kingston Hyper X Fury DDR4 RAM (16 GB total) running at 2666 Mhz, Gigabyte B450M Gaming Motherboard, Nvidia GeForce GTX 1050Ti 4 GB GPU, EVGA SuperNova 750W PSU 80+ Gold, and 2 x 480 GB Kingston A400 SSD's. 

To put that into perspective I can play Halo Reach in maximum graphics at 70 FPS while streaming, or Grand Theft Auto V on maximum graphics at 70 FPS while streaming. So the reason this happens is unclear, but I put it down to poor optimization, I've had this game since 2017 and nothing really changes except the title and the amount of DLC just increases meaning by the time you read this the total price for all DLC content probably ranges around $8,000 USD. 

It is a very expensive game to play, and doesn't really deliver much quality for the price you end up paying for it in the long run, so I would advise you and all others to not buy this game and instead purchase their more recent game Train Sim World which is far better than this scrap heap and probably runs a lot smoother as well.

Despite pouring 138 hours into this game I would not recommend it. Here's why: From a technical perspective this game is out of date - despite calling itself TS 2020. The tired old graphics engine has many problems; The biggest one being the texture load-in stutter that affects all routes, some more than others. I've also experienced a number of game stopping bugs which have still yet to be addressed. The developer does not seem to be have much energy or enthusiasm to address these.  

In terms of value for money this game is incredibly poor. The locomotives and routes are overpriced and lacking in quality. In order to prolong your experience in TS 2020 you are expected to by add-on's which start getting pricey. 
The locomotives themselves have only got basic features modelled most of the time (wipers, horn, headlights, Instrument lights etc). If you're looking for more advanced features like cold start ups or programming GSMR devices you have to start looking into third party add-ons. (again, you'll be spending more money)

As a simulator this game is average. As a train enthusiast it's a way for me to unwind and switch off while taking in the scenery and is such the only extent to which I can recommend it.

Another year, another money grab.  Not worth the purchase if you have already invested your time and money into the included content from this TS2018 package as you will see no difference in pricing as we have in previous years as a "Complete My Collection" bundle.  DTG has gone so far as to let users know on Facebook that they hope they enjoy what the users will spend their money on elsewhere as some, including myself, have stated they will not be buying their product because of this.  Nice new picture and menu for free for those who own TS2017.  If you do not own any of the routes or trains in this package, go for it as you are the only ones who DTG has any concern over.  If you own one or more of the routes and are after one of the others, wait for a sale when they are half off.  Over 4500 hours and 238 purchases of additional content for this game over its entire run, and I think I am done at this point.

*Update* 11/27/19
I find that the game is getting only slightly better due to the release of a ton of third party content.  This is most likely that DTG does not intend to allocate as many resources to the product as in years past with TSW now picking up steam (without any steam).  Only get it when it is on sale and same thing goes with the DLC.  I often will purchase third party releases through their own sites and if it is an exclusive to Steam or the DTG store, I will buy at full price.  Otherwise, I will wait until 50% off or greater for the product anymore as DTG releases often would only pass a QC in 2012 in terms of quality and accuracy.

I initially bought it because I played a train simulator years back and thought it must be good by todays standards... boy was I wrong.
There are a lot of tutorials which is good and necessary to handle the trains correctly, however using the knowledge in the first session was horrible. Stopping at the correct position to open the doors to let passengers in seemed to hit a specific point. On the first stop I had to go back and forth just a few meters to check if I'm in the correct spot. After adjusting it like 6 times I eventually hit an "Game Over Error" noting that the train moved while the doors were open... let me tell you THE DOORS WERE NOT OPEN. At least not visually. There was no feedback why the doors won't open and in this moment visually there were not open.

So to sum it up, if you hit a tiny mistake you will get hit by a "Game Over Error" which throws you back to the main menu. Worth mentioning that the loading screen takes longer than taking a dump, so if you make a minor mistake and get thrown back to the main menu - have fun loading the game again.

If you just compare these aspects with the price they want it's just horrible. I'm never ever going to try a train simulator again.

I got this game in 2013. I paid $100 for a package deal. One of the routes I paid for was Donner Pass. Back when I first got the game I had trouble with one of the levels. As I played I got further and further behind schedule. Finally I restarted the level (AN OFFICIAL LEVEL) floored the pedal so to speak, (This causes you to get major speed penalties) and noticed that I still got further and further behind schedule.

I posted a comment on steam to see if anyone else had this problem and even got in touch with the developers of the game. Players took screen shots, posted the problem and it seemed like they where going to look into it. Several months go by, and no response from the developers on this issue. The players however found out the problem was it was a passenger train level with a passenger time frame but with freight train speed restrictions.

The PLAYERS have posted ways to fix it and made patches that make it possible however this prevents it from counting as the mission, (no trophies, completion, etc.) I have found out that many of the OFFICIAL routes you can buy have issues like this. (They must not test them?)

Fast forward to 2019, six years later, and it still has not been fixed. To make matters worse I have noticed even more bugs now than I did back then. For example, you have a button you need to press in order to confirm messages like speed changes or if your inactive too long. Problem is this doesn't always light up or make any noise to alert you and will randomly apply emergency brakes.

The track switch levers sometimes are invisible making it hard to change lanes in freight yards.

These issues make it hard to enjoy the game. It's been 6 years and I have logged 51 hours in that time. Considering the levels I play last 1 to 3.5 hours that's not alot. For comparison, I bought a new game last week, and already logged 44 hours in it.

Long story short, the developers rush half baked and untested levels out to make money. They don't fix there bugs, or do any customer support. Every year they claim they are giving you a free upgrade to the latest game witch I can't tell the difference from the game I got 6 years ago. No free DLC for being a loyal customer for so long. Not easy trying to make your own levels or routes. $100 gets you the base game and 3 routes, 1 of witch is bugged and impossible to beat (get Gold, or Silver star on)

I tend to play a few hours every year or so in hopes that they finally fixed the bugs with the content I paid over 100 dollars to play. This game could be fun if you got rid of the bugs.

1. If you want to drive trains, and don't care about completing any missions, then you might enjoy this game

2. If you don't care about collecting all DLC ($10,000+) or getting all the trophies, then you might enjoy this game

3. If you don't care about bugs that make the game hard to play, (They will NEVER be fixed) this game you may like

Otherwise, DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY!

I'd only recommend this game if my package cost ($20 not $100) and the DLC only cost ($5 not $20)

Even then, I would expect the levels I buy to actually work.

Just a little Story about this Game...

I got this game (my first on Steam actually) back when it was Railworks 3: Train Simulator 2012. This game was amazing back then. It was the best Train Simulator out there at the time and I absolutely enjoyed the heck out of it (hence the 300 hours in the game). Then as time went on, I got a few DLC's (Northeast Corridor and Donner Pass were by far my favorites) and kept on playing it for a good while. Then 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, and now 2020 and it just seems the same. The same trains, the same physics, the same overpriced DLC. Just. the. same. I wish there was a little change. I got super excited the first time I saw the number go up from 2012 to 2013. Now its just a new realization of extra DLC they want you to buy. Don't get me wrong, the game is O.K at best and is fantastic if your a kid who loves trains but if you've grown up like me, you just want to see some change in this beautiful game. Dovetail has provided some great memories for me and I just wanted to see something new. Hope this review helps some people :)

Any new online train enthusiasts will be thoroughly thrilled with the digital world of TRAIN SIM and, though it may not be quite like using your hands to build your own railroad world like hobbyists have done in the past, turning on your computer and selecting a scenario, route and loco has just as much fun and adventure in it as getting your hands 'dirty' in the garage or back yard. It doesn't quite replace the hands-on type of rail hobby most people are familiar with but the online version can become just as addictive and as much fun as any Lionel or HO-gauge trains earlier generations have played with. The big difference is that you have a ton of routes and scenarios to drive your choice of engine and consists on. 'Mix and Match' options really open up the world to you as well as setting your own consists and, with each game update, more options become available and your 'Train World' continues to grow. Great simulation and I hope to see more of this in the near future.

I played this game a lot more since I got it for my 14th birthday back in 2014. Still totally worth it. Though I'd personally recommend some of the third party DLC such as from Caledonia Works, Digital Traction, and SteamSoundsSupreme if you want some really good British steam engines, such as:

1. the Stirling Single (and soon to be released C1 Atlantic) by Caledonia Works
2. the LNER B12 by Digital Traction (there are better choices though)
3. Enhancement Packs by SteamSoundsSupreme that improve existing DLC like the 14xx/A3. 
4. There's also the City Class (the one with City of Truro) over at JustTrains.

also. As the LGR curator said "Memes, excessive DLC, and accidental nuclear events aside, this is actually a fantastic locomotive simulator. Just relaxing, at least how I play it."

This game offers the best train driving experience you can get on Steam, some of the included content is incredibly entertaining and I've enjoyed many hours of fun gameplay. However, there are 2 reasons why I cannot recommend this game: Bugs and Value for Money

Every single time I start the game I have to delete cache files or it will freeze, and heaven forbid you want to tab out while playing because that crashes the game too. Even just accessing the workshop in game often freezes the whole PC. On top of all of that, 99% of the crashes cause the whole system to freeze, making it impossible to access Task Manager or close the application, the only way to un freeze my PC is to sign out from Windows altogether.

Support from Dovetail is minimal at best and nonexistent at worst, which considering the amount of money I have put into the game is a real slap in the face. Bugs that have been known and identified for years still remain unfixed, and since Dovetail have replaced the game with Train Sim World it's highly unlikely they ever will be.

All of that wouldn't be so bad if the game and its DLC weren't so unreasonably expensive for what you get. Routes that cost £25 will offer you perhaps 10-15 hours of playtime, obviously depending on the specific route, but the overwhelming majority of them will disappoint you if you were expecting £25 worth of content. The cheaper routes unfortunately aren't much better as the graphics and details are very dated and lacking most of the interactive features of newer more expensive routes.

One of the features intended to extend the gameplay hours of the content you own is the Steam Workshop. There are some very well put together scenarios that can help the DLC not go stale so fast, however the vast majority of them require you to have many different DLCs in your library, and if you don't have one of them, the whole scenario won't work. This means you will have to spend even more money buying DLC you didn't even want just to play anything other than the default scenarios. This presents a significant barrier to entry for anyone wanting to use the Workshop, expect to be required to buy 2 or even sometimes more full price routes as well as 3 or more extra locomotives (priced anywhere from £5 to £15 each) for the most popular scenarios. Even finding scenarios can be a challenge as the filtering system is not operational (the drop down menu has a graphical glitch) and the search bar will return "no results found" unless you know what you're looking for, as well as the fact that unless the publisher lists it, there is no way to see the required DLC for each workshop scenario before downloading it, meaning you end up downloading and deleting a lot of scenarios before you find one you can actually play.

So in summary, the game so has many issues that make it difficult to play, even for the most dedicated enthusiast. The only way I could ever recommend this steaming pile to you is if you are: technically savvy enough to fix broken games yourself, have heaps of cash and nothing better to do with it, and love trains enough to go through the most infuriating process just to play the game. If any one of those things doesn't apply to you, save your money and time for a better, less broken game

Don't get me wrong, this game is by far not perfect. It's age is reflected in some occasional bugs I've encountered, including numerous strange game crashes and a mysterious train-flying-into-air glitch. There's also the DLC, which, in terms of price relative to quality, is debatable. Although I could talk for some time about things I wish were different, added, or removed from the game, overall, I still love it. In my opinion, it is still the best train simulator on the market with the most available detail for your personal railfanning experience, so long as you're willing to spend the money. Overall, a good 6/10. It may not sound like much, but it's still better (in my opinion) than what else is out there in terms of detail.

[b]Train Simulator[/b]
---
    Right off the bat, the game is great; a wonderful feeling of the weight behind you, sunlight flickering through the shadows inside the cab, and great scenery at somewhat reasonable graphics delivery.

    The whole shebang is not unlike how Microsoft Train Simulator used to feel. Cycling through the views feels right at home and then some, along with a great majority of locomotives' physics. There exists a varied and plentiful selection of routes and locomotives from many points on the globe. No one route is outlandishly difficult from one another...so far. Which is nice.

[i]The only gripes (2) I've continuously had:[/i]
○ The sounds on many addon locos flat out suck or at least snuff out the immersion in the game. On some tracks, the sounds are fantastic, but for the price of some of these routes I would expect the included rolling stock to have its own distinct sound set.
○ Not a huge deal. When running with multiple monitors, the game has thrown an empty error message and crashed after alt-tabbing out of the program. Again, not really a big deal! It's probably just my VRAM running dry.
---

The main issue is the different signaling used on different railroads. 

Yes there are similarities around the world, fine, and I think we understand that. However there are many differences that can cause one to lose appreciable time trying to research online and decrease the fun of the simulation. True in both the track side signaling and also signaling is some more modern locomotives.

One can go on line to look up signaling for specific railroads world wide and that can be time consuming. It also will lead to less enjoyment in the game and in the end loosing customers. Steam and Dovetail are in the business of making money, not loosing customers. This true of those coding the Apps as a business and those who love railroading.
 
The folks developing the simulations/apps already know know what the signaling is because they display it to me the user and expect the appropriate actions to be taken. Merit for the right actions and demerit for inappropriate actions and sometime game over.
 
Can not the developers provide signaling information with the simulation/app? That could lead to a data base that could be available to TS Community thus making the experience better.

Now if this info already exists then I have not looked in the right place withing Steam or Dovetail (my bad).
Maybe that I can be directed to correct place.

If you can get past the Nintendo-like interface, the inconsistent menus, the scenarios that don't work, the user-created content that won't load, the moronic passengers that goose-step up and down and appear and disappear at random, the constant adverts for new content, the anodyne tips, the loading times that make you want to punch your monitor, the inane chatter on the radio and the low-fi cab reconstructions, there is some fun to be had driving the trains. But far too much effort is spent developing chargeable add-ons and none on fixing the basics.

UPDATE: After a 15GB download, if you run the 32-bit version it works. If you run the 64-bit version (on Windows 10 64-bit) then it hangs and neither version will start. I think I'll have to give up at this point. I'm not buying the re-written version either, Dovetail really doesn't deserve my money.

UPDATE 2: This may be because I was running my Steam library from a network share. I don't think TS works from a network share without getting corrupted. The solution is to have your Steam library on your PC.

I simply cannot recommend this program anymore. I tried, I really did. I only "took what I needed" from the laughably overpriced DLCs and used them ad nauseum. Then I came for others, and absolutely could not justify spending what they were asking for even just one route or locomotive pack, even on sale. If you enjoy choice and variety in your simulation programs, you will get bored very fast playing this. If, however, you enjoy using the same stuff over and over and don't mind paying out the nose for mediocre pieces of digital content to be used in a program that hasn't changed in years, have at it.

The "take what you need" defense is 100% laughable, and does not need to argued by anyone anymore unless you just enjoy embarrassing yourself. If the DLCs were a few dollars a piece, I could maybe get on board with it. But when one route costs as much as or more than the base game itself, that makes this whole scheme absolutely impossible to defend. I am simply astonished that anyone would pay upwards of $40 or more for one route or one locomotive pack. I don't care if that's all you plan on using, you are a 100% bona-fide FOOL if you allow yourself to be swindled into putting that kind of money into this simulator. The Dovetail execs are lounging on a beach chair in Cancun sipping an overpriced pina colada at your expense right now, snickering at how easily duped you are. Stop defending this scheme, seriously. This is NOT HO-scale model railroading. For the love of god, stop pretending it is, and stop acting like having some "hobbyist" mentality somehow makes submitting to this scheme a smart idea.

Furthermore, this simulator has not changed in years. The functionality, graphics, and features are all the same with minimal to no improvement. I won't get into specifics- you can find those in a bunch of reviews- but I think it's pretty telling that Dovetail continues to rebrand this program every year without changing it.

Bottom line: the criticisms are legit, the defenders are wrong, and unless you have some kind of fetish for highway robbery, look elsewhere. It's pretty telling that the top review on here makes the same pathetic "take-what-you-need" argument but the reviewer disabled comments; I certainly would not want to have to defend that position.

A farewell to TS w/an evaluation and conclusion!
I started from scratch strictly with EU & UK lines only. Fail and error was the name of the day. All the way I have been impressed with the realism and details of the lines. There are some faults, but I am not sure who to blame? In the back of my head is the ghost of the sloppiness of the game creators. Anyway there are 2 mischiefs, in UK lines the borderline of a speed restriction (points) are often moved forward. Also in many games the platforms and likewise it out of sync with the HUD. In German lines it is unmarked not always apprehensive speedrestictions. Cost a bundle in XP. As a game creator I could think out some less childish challenges, ie your stopping line at the platforms, signals etc.
The biggest flaw of TS is the game quality. It is a paradox that there are some brilliant games - especially with freight trains, and then it is a downhill avalanche to amateurism - and often games that are not quality controlled. Too many mistakes. Rock bottom of lack of creativity is a HST timetable for a DMU, or timetables that are totally unrealistic.
And now to the kill of a product. DVG service/support is non existant. Waste of time. I purchased a line after I had purchased the needed locos. The games can not upload. I have 30 other games on different lines with the same problem. I do not bother to try DVG again.
Nevertheless I had a lot of fun and challenges even though that TS (DVG) is an overpriced third class product.
I will end with an oddity, my score: Level 86  - 561,520 XP - 559 gold - 18 silver and 9 bronce. If you make a mental calculation, f.ex. 560 x 1,000, then you do not have to be a math genius something is wrong. The explanation is simple: Some lines/games do not credit the won XP to your total. Only the medal. How much is the game worth then?
Keep rolling and enjoy. Kindest regards Harry, DK

Yeah, yeah, we know - there are a lot of DLCs for this game. If you're voting thumbs-down just for that, then you don't know how to write a review. These reviews are supposed to be about the game itself, not what you personally think of their marketing techniques. I don't need a review on Dovetails' business practices, thank you very much. I'm buying a game, not stocks and bonds.

Having said that, do not let the huge amount of DLCs dissuade you from buying this game. Of course, if you're into high-action, explosion-a-minute, twitch games, then give this game a pass. You won't like it. This is a game of laid-back relaxation, a game for those who are train hobbyists or simply for people who like to get away from fighting bad guys all the time. It's not for everyone and if it's not for you, then you should stop giving the game a thumbs-down just because it isn't your cup of tea. Not every game on steam has to cater to your specific wishes, ya know?

As for the DLCs - no one expects you to buy every last one of them. This isn't like most games where you strive to get all the expansions and add-ons. If you approach the DLCs with that kind of mentality then, yeah, one might be inclined to whine and moan. But rail enthusiasts often know about the different routes, the different trains, the different eras - and they pick the DLCs that they like best. 

If the base game included ALL of those DLCs, it would be prohibitively expensive. Instead, Dovetail, broke the game up into a bunch of DLCs so it could be affordable for most people. Complaining about the DLCs is like complaining because the game has *too* much variety and diversity, *too* many choices. Complaining about the DLCs is basically saying, "The game should ONLY have as many routes as can be stuffed into the base game and perhaps a couple of $10 expansions and half a dozen $5 DLCs, but NO MORE!"  Why should anyone deny the massive amount of choice and customization this game offers? Are you just greedy and upset that you can't buy ALL the DLCs? 

Now ... I will admit that some of the DLCs are rather pricey and expensive. Do I like that? No, of course not. But they're expensive because you actually have people in the field surveying the routes, other people designing and creating trains and their characteristics, still others are building thousands of graphic models for the scenery, and still more are dealing with the game mechanics itself. This kind of game is NOT cheap to make - this isn't some slap-together game where everything is approximated rather than made as real as the game can make it. Yes, I wish I had the money to buy all the DLCs, but I will have to content myself with buying just a few - and a few more here and there when money allows.

As for myself, I'm glad there are a lot of DLCs because that means there will almost always be a new route to explore, a new little journey to undertake. As I said, if you're not into games like this, to each his own, but to bash the game for its DLCs is really the wrong attitude to have. My only gripe is that some of them are rather expensive - but - wait for a sale. Simple as that.

Are there some bugs? Sure - here and there. I've not encountered anything game-breaking. And by all means, show me a game that doesn't have bugs even years after its initial release and I'll show you some beach-front property in Kansas you might like to buy. In addition, the base game should come with more routes - that I will admit - but even that isn't enough for me to give the game a thumbs-down. I've read some of the reviews here that talk about this game as if it is a buggy piece of trash, some impromptu game with bad mechanics, bad AI, bad graphics, blah blah. 

All of that is false. Yes, it is slightly - slightly, mind you - aged. But so what. If a game like this, which has to load textures and graphics quickly, had 2019 photo-realistic graphics, only the very best and most powerful rigs could even run it. 

As others have said, if you like trains - even if your interest is rather casual - and if you enjoy a game now and then where you're not always saving the word and being attacked by something every time you move, I'd recommend this to anyone of like mind. Ignore the mouth-foaming negative reviews that are mostly about the DLCs than the game itself.

The only other piece of advice I would give to anyone considering this game is to read carefully the DLC description or anything you might download from the workshop - make sure you own any necessary DLCs before hitting that purchase button. Otherwise you might end up buying and/or downloading something you can't use. Yep, I'm speaking from experience here.

So, without further ado, allow me to extend a welcome to the rails for those first-time buyers who decided to take the plunge.

I like trains. I really like trains. Even now I am taking a break from sketching up another draft of a HO scale container and iron ore layout. But this game…it has major problems that will never be addressed sadly. For one, the prices are absolutely absurd. There is no reason for the DLC to be as priced as it is. Shure maps can be big an expansive but there is nothing in them. Detail is very low and I am no even going to start on the absurdly low-resolution textures. IF Train Simulator wants to tout itself as being 2020, then it needs to go back and fix the established problems. First of all, Old DLC is just that, old. It needs a graphical overhaul if it wants to be on par with later stuff. Some maps do not have a free roam option for some entirely unknown reason. Not there are larger completely unaddressed problems in specific maps. The “Ohio Steel 2” rout add on, (what happened to 1 by the way?) consistently has structures, track, and bridges missing, graphically bugged, or plastered with the wrong textures. “Corris Railway” Rout also has this to a lesser extent. “Doncaster Works” is an actual nightmare. Turntables not working, freight cars sailing off into the sky on a tap, objective related wagons being completely intangible so you drove right through them, and the trains rocketing off into the stratosphere if they tap buffers. Speaking or turntables, could you PLEASE fix your game so if I rotate one, it does not make the load on it sometimes just fall over because a 200 ton diesel should not just fall over because of slow rotation. Some trains like the “OBB 4023 ‘Talent’” have no simple controls like everything else and must be run realistically. And combined with no instructions and the itty bitty resolution and weird lighting, it becomes an maddening case of trial and error. As well as despite this game rebranding itself every year, it makes no effort to improve or reward the player in any way.

I bought this when it was on offer a few years back. It had, like it does now, various DLC included (Hitachi high speed train, test track etc in my case) whch was fun. Imagine my surprise when it upgraded to next release and all the extra bits that came with the game disappeared from the choices available. 

Yup! When it upgrades to the new version (which it will automatically unless you tell it not to), you lose access to those extra trains/tracks your version came with. They're still installed (you can see them in the "DLC" section of your library) but you can't use them. And, of course, you can't install the old version to get your content back either.

Similarly, you don't get the new DLC which are listed on the store page for the new version (e.g. the SNCF train in the 2017 version). After the first year, you're left with nothing but the base game and content, and no alternative but to buy DLC again if you want to have the same trains/tracks that you purchased the game with.

Another niggle is that you can only use specific trains on each route so if you want to drive a diesel on the Dorset line, or a freight train on the West Coast line from Paddington to Oxford, you're out of luck. Same track guage, no go on the driving.

The interface isn't great when choosing a train/route combo either. When I was doing a free drive, I managed to confuse the system so much that I couldn't get the list to show all the trains again so I had to restart the game completely.

Other bugs I've found include (but are not limited to):
- Showing trains that, by all accounts are installed, but choosing one of them selects a different train (Big Boy 2-10-0 selected a German train)
- Being able to choose a train and route which you haven't actually purchased but still allowing you to drive the route in the train, but with no scenery (Chatham to Victoria with the HST give you invisible tracks, no grass/bridges/signals etc)

The only improvement I've found in the 2017 release is a major improvement in loading times. I don't now have a chance to make a cup of coffee

This game is listed in the 2017 Guinness Book of Gaming Records as having the most expensive DLC (if you buy all of it). It's already out of date - it's listed as only having about £1300 worth. It's over £3000 now!

To sum up, if you want to simulate driving a train, visit your local model store and start splashing the cash there. At least that way you won't lose stuff that you've paid for when you buy a new train. Alternatively, become a member of your local heritage train line and go down that route - you'll get more satisfaction from it

So, as you can see, I've racked up a lot of hours. It's a fun game - BUT the company behind it should really address some community concerns. Namely in the way they re-release content which makes for an obvious business strategy of 'lets charge everyone twice!':

[list]
[*] Maintaining two games in parallel (Train Sim World) doesn’t make sense. DLC is not compatible between them
[*] Class 20 re-released more than once
[*] Class 66 re-released more than once
[*] Class 158 re-released more than once
[*] Class 390 re-released more than once
[*] Whenever these re-releases occur, they make old DLC redundant, including all scenarios that include them
[*] Routes routinely re-released as ‘bigger, improved’, but require full price payment. They effectively make previous purchases redundant. This could easily be avoided with incremental\subsidised discounts for existing DLC owners
[*]  Little investment in graphics engine since release over 10 years ago (lighting within tunnels, assets ‘floating’ off the ground etc) – The developer answer will be to switch to Train Sim World, which would wipe out any existing investment in DLC

I am really torn about what to say about this game.
To be honest, I am not overly interested in trains and see them merely as a way to get form A to B. However, I was won over by the attention to detail in the scenery and wanted to give it a go.
Overall, I am doing much better than I thought I would; mostly, for me, though, it is enjoying looking at the scenery that makes it an interesting game. Based on this alone, I would give it a thumbs up.
However, there are two glaring problems I am facing; one of these issues I will guess is down to my lack of knowledge regarding trains; the other definitely is not.
Firstly, I seem to be having issues with speeding despite scrupulous attention to the limits - even to the point of being a bit overly-cautious. My issue is when a speed limit is imposed without it showing on my information overview in front of me. For example, I was moving down from 100 KPH to 60 KPH which was the next indicated speed limit. I was well within limits and was going to comfortably be below 60 KPH by the time the limit became valid. Then, without any notice, or any indication, the limit changes to 50 KPH. This means I am now speeding but there has been no indication on the tracking information at all that this limit was going to come into effect. I am probably missing something but, I have to say, I feel a bit cheated.
The second problem is what has convinced me to give this a thumbs down - the doors. When stopping at a station, I let the passengers depart and alight and physically watch the doors as they close before commencing the journey. More than once I have then failed the game because I have started to move with the doors open! I mean, I saw the doors close so how can this be?
Very frustrating when I was halfway through an hour-long game only to have it ended by what I can only assume is a bug.
Frustrating, as this could be a nice way to pass an hour or so if not for these irritating problems.
If anyone can suggest what I am doing wrong that would be a big help and might change my overall judgment.

It's simple:
Pros:
- A lot of selections of trains and routes ... A LOT!!
- Realistic routes with goggle maps GPS for tracking
- Realistic feel of having thousands of tons of freight behind you
- Cheaper than buying/making a Train set at home  IE. : Hours of set up time - Maintenance of track, trains, wires, and dusting
- Easy to play
- Some very complicated Engines (FEF-3 - author "Smokebox") if you want a challenge
- Hours of play
- Your kids can play (ages 5 and up)
- Can watch movies while playing and not DIE.
- Can be very relaxing
- Can customize your own routes or add scenarios to existing routes

Cons:
- Can be expensive if you want to "catch them all"
- Graphics can be one level above "minecraft" at times (5% or less)
- Sometimes the objectives don't work correctly (5% or less - very dependent on publisher)
- Friends will make fun of you for playing train stimulator for hours
- Can take up a lot of memory

Summary:

If you can get past the simplicity and understand that owning a train set at home costs more than what this game offers for a fraction of the price. Hours of fun anywhere you have a computer with steam. I was even able to drive a Train on real route with a laptop while riding a train and beating the train to destination. Greatest Nerd Challenge Accepted and BEAT!

After returning to this account I had decided to try this game out again as I have around 500 hours from it (yes very sad child I was/am) After a good run and turning graphics right down I have discovered that it runs perfectly on my laptop which still baffles me... 

There is a massive community to this game where there are literally of thousands of additions to the workshop with scenarios that can be interesting and fun (from what I remember) 

However, if you have any issues with money then avoid this game at all costs as you will be spending around £10 just for one single bloody train that you will most likely get bored of in the near future. The routes can be very expensive as well where you will find the newer additions cost alarmingly more than the routes from the times of 2012 e.g. Paddington to Oxford. During sales. yes the prices can be dirt cheap and we are talking grannies pocket money cheap but that is only in the sales REMEMBER!

Overall, this can be a great game if you enjoy your trains but once you hit that stage where you get bored of it you will most likely regret buying everything for this game. I do recommend this game if you are young and you're very committed to trains and you have decent cash but if you are none of those then don't buy this game.

For all the gaming simulation aficionados out there, pondering whether they should purchase the newest, most up-to-date edition of Train Simulator; Don't!

...it saddens me to say what follows, but you might as well save your hard earned greens, and better off looking elsewhere for your gaming needs; Train Simulator's an old game, powered by an old engine, and it shows; Bad. 

Providing the player with anything but subpar visuals, which do not, in any way or form, justify neither the most atrocious performance imaginable, nor the longest, most absurd load times to be experienced in gaming; Upwards to 10 minutes plus...

Once in game, if lucky enough not to experience a suden crash; What it provides the player, is indeed impressive in terms of detail and scale, such however, cannot excuse what's been said above, not in this day and age...

Technology has come a long way; There are, in this moment in time, vastly superior lookers out there, and there have been for years; Games of all sorts and kinds one can imagine, providing the player not only vastly larger, but far more dynamic areas to roam their way through and interact with...

Train Simulator 2019, has been tested on more than capable hardware too; Game is, in its current state, barely playable, unstable and crashes more often than not... as such, I cannot, for the life of me, stress this enough, the product in question's but an absolute disgrace in terms of functionality! ...a train wreck of sorts messily held together, and most definitely not worth your attention..

...again, nothing but a tired product way past its prime and in clear need to be scraped entirely; All just so a new project, built from the ground up, powered by an entirely new engine, and properly coded can rise...
BEST GAME ON STEAM

First, let's just put this out there - when I look at all the DLC that I have not yet added to my library, it totals over $4,000 ... during the 2019 Steam Summer Sale. Normally, it's over $9,000. That's over $900 a year for a game that is a decade old at this point. And you will need at least a handful of DLC to really flesh out the content that is part of the base game. I would actually recommend getting the three Holiday themed DLC packs (one Halloween and two Christmas), you get the most bang for the buck with those, and don't even need the base game to play them. One plus is that I originally bought the 2017 version of the game with a sim bundle and was automatically upgraded to 2019 when that released on Steam, so if this continues, that's a plus.

That being said, right now, TS2019 is the premier Train Sim out there, along with TSW. You need to be very careful in your choice of which DLC to purchase. Each Engine pack usually comes with 3-4 scenarios to play, but at $20 a pop, that is still pretty expensive for a bare minimum amount of content. The scenario packs generally have a handful of routes to drive, but the problem comes when you need a specific route DLC AND a specific Engine DLC (or two) in order to have access to every route that is included. So a $10 scenario pack can wind up costing you $40 or more in order to play everything included in the pack. Another issue is that almost none of the routes/scenarios in any of the DLC are drivable in all four of the game modes.

There are four games modes that you can drive in:
Quick Drive - you can pick a route and an Engine and just go from point A to point B anywhere on the route.
Career - A points based version of routes where you are scored on your ability to follow the rules of the rails and complete assigned tasks.
Standard - A non-points based version of Career mode.
Free Roam - Just like it says. Pick a route and just drive the train without having to worry about the rules or the need to complete any tasks.

That offers a lot of possibilities, but as mentioned, almost none of the scenarios and routes are available in all four modes. So if you have a favorite route you like driving, you may only be able to drive it in Career mode or Quick mode. Or a route may only be available in Standard mode. For the cost of the DLC, there should be no reason not to have each and every route available to drive in each mode to its fullest extent.

In the end, I would recommend this game. It is fun to experience the ability to command a variety of engines, and learn the differences between driving a classic steam engine and a modern electric engine. However, you will need DLC to really get more than a paltry base amount of content, and you really need to be picky about what content you want to add to the game. If there are routes and engines near your real life area you want to drive, just stick with that at first and add on later. I would definitely recommend waiting until the stuff you want goes on sale - it does so often enough throughout the year to make waiting until then the smart thing to do.

Do you like trains? Do you like simulators? Then this game is for you. I personally find the game very relaxing to play after a long day at work when i need to unwind. As far as the DLC thing goes, you aren't meant to buy it all (Though i'm sure they'd love you if you did haha). You buy what interests you as far as trains go. I love diesel trains, so i buy DLC that fits that. I have some interest in Steam engines, so i MIGHT get some of that. I have little love for electric locomotives so i have no reason to even look at that. Same for routes. I'm north american, so i just focus on american/canadian routes and the UK and German/ Rest of the world routes i'm not very worried about. You just do you with the DLC. My biggest complaint is that the game seems poorly optimized and even people with pretty good rigs seem to have issues with their FPS when normally they would not, myself included.

When I wrote my first review I really thought I would leave it at thumbs down. but after a couple of months playing this simulator.  DTG has made some big improvements to game play.. I still wish they would upgrade some of the routes though. The editor in 64 bit is a lot better especially  building routes.. Some routes are better then others for instance the U-Bahn Frankfurt that just came out recently has a lot to it. Trains have information systems and passenger systems on them. This is great for atmosphere. I wish many of the other routes had this as well. I drive the ICE trains a lot and wish they had these information systems on them.  

The Train Sim community. I find a lot of people are really harsh when it comes to opinion and proposals. I have written several issues and things I would like to see in the sim.  but I get told oh its not possible or something like that when thats been proven wrong. I was told trains could not have information systems on them because the engine is too old. Yes but since 64bit has been put in there they can do all sorts of things and the simulator seems to be fine.  

So yes try this simulator out.. Well done Dovetail.

dear guys @dovetail, 

what to do on a sunny summer morning. of cause checking out the steam summer sale and deciding to give your train sim a try.
as a flight simmer I guess there is always time for a change.
which brings me to your product. 
I always figuerd that inthusiats are the most capable people in trying to recreate their beloved hobby into an pc game.
thats why I was shocked to find out that your game lacks "sooo" much love to detail.

gameplay/physics: are you really sure that locomotives behave that way? terrain inclination? air resistence? 

sound: since i am a sound designer myself, i find your lack of affort very offensive (train passes by in the opposite direction: great sound for that, but when it passed by just nothing? tunnels: nothing ? why? not to mention the constant noise floor of something) HIRE ME ! 

graphics: since this game is somewhat expensive, it would be great if its visuals were appropriately, dont you think?

over all, if this would be a platform for open source material like some other kind of sims, so you could add some content from people who care (more!), I would be tempted to play it again... 

in the meantime I think I`ll pass.
